original.problem:
2.9. Solve the problem of task 8 for differential expressions:
a) $\frac{x d y-y d x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}$
b) $\frac{(x+2 y) d x+y d y}{(x+y)^{2}}$.

Solution.

a) We directly verify that

$$
\frac{x d y-y d x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}=d\left(\operatorname{Arctg} \frac{y}{x}\right)
$$

where

$$
\operatorname{Arctg} \frac{y}{x}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\operatorname{arctg} \frac{y}{x} ; x>0, y \geqslant 0 \\
\pi+\operatorname{arctg} \frac{y}{x} ; x<0, y \geqslant 0 \\
-\pi+\operatorname{arctg} \frac{y}{x} ; x<0, y<0 \\
\operatorname{arctg} \frac{y}{x} ; x>0, y<0
\end{array}\right.
$$

The function $\operatorname{Arctg} \frac{y}{x}$ is continuous in the plane $R_{2}$, except for the non-negative $O X$ axis. Indeed,

$$
\lim _{\substack{x>0 \\ y \rightarrow 0+0}} \operatorname{Arctg} \frac{y}{x}=0 ; \lim _{\substack{x>0 \\ y \rightarrow 0-0}} \operatorname{Arctg} \frac{y}{x}=2 \pi
$$

Thus, $u(x, y)=\operatorname{Arctg} \frac{y}{x}+C$ for all points $(x, y) \in R_{2}$, except for the points on the non-negative $O X$ axis (in this case, it is said that the potential is defined on the plane cut along the non-negative $O X$ axis).

b) In the plane $R_{2}$, cut along the line $x+y=0$ (i.e., with removed points $(x,-x), x \in R$), the condition for potentiality is satisfied $Q_{x}=P_{y}$. We define two functions $u_{1}(x, y)$ (for the half-plane $x+y>0$) and $u_{2}(x, y)$ (for the half-plane $x+y<0$), satisfying the conditions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d u_{1}=\frac{(x+2 y) d x+y d y}{(x+y)^{2}}: x+y>0 \\
& u_{1}(x, y)=\int_{A B C} \frac{(x+2 y) d x+y d y}{(x+y)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $A B C$ is a broken line connecting the points $A(0,-1)$; $B(x,-1)$ and $C(x, y): x+y>0$.

We perform the corresponding calculations:

$$
\begin{gathered}
u_{1}(x, y)=\int_{A B} \frac{(x-2) d x}{(x-1)^{2}}+\int_{B C} \frac{y d y}{(x+y)^{2}}+C_{1}=\int_{0}^{x} \frac{(t-2) d t}{(t-1)^{2}}+ \\
+\int_{-1}^{y} \frac{t d t}{(x+t)^{2}}+C_{1}=\left.\left(\ln |t-1|+\frac{1}{t-1}\right)\right|_{0} ^{x}+\left.\left(\ln |x+t|+\frac{x}{x+t}\right)\right|_{-1} ^{y}+C_{1}= \\
=\ln |x-1|+\frac{1}{x-1}+1+\ln |x+y|-\ln |x-1|+\frac{x}{x+y}-\frac{x}{x-1}+C_{1}= \\
=\ln |x+y|+\frac{x}{x+y}+C_{1}=\ln (-x-y)+\frac{x}{x+y}+C_{1} \\
u_{2}(x, y)=\int_{A_{1} B_{1}} \frac{x+2}{(x+1)^{2}} d x+\int_{B_{1} C_{1}} \frac{y d y}{(x+y)^{2}}+C_{2} \doteq \int_{0}^{x} \frac{(t+2) d t}{(t+1)^{2}}+ \\
+\int_{1}^{y} \frac{t d t}{(x+t)^{2}}+C_{2}=\left.\left(\ln |t+1|-\frac{1}{t+1}\right)\right|_{0} ^{x}+\left.\left(\ln |x+t|+\frac{x}{x+t}\right)\right|_{1} ^{y}+C_{2}= \\
\quad=\ln |x+1|-\frac{1}{x+1}+1+\ln |x+y|+\frac{x}{x+1}+C_{2}=\ln (x+y)+\frac{x}{x+y}+C_{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\text { a) } \int_{L}\left(4 x y-15 x^{2} y\right) d x+\left(2 x^{2}-5 x^{3}+7\right) d y, \\
L: y=x^{3}-3 x^{2}+2 \text { from } A(1-\sqrt{3}, 0) \text { to } B(1,0) ; \\
\text { b) } \int_{L} x d y+y d x, L:\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x^{2} \sin \frac{1}{x}+\frac{4}{\pi^{2}}, x \neq 0, \\
\frac{4}{\pi^{2}}, x=0
\end{array}\right. \\
\text { from } A\left(0, \frac{4}{\pi^{2}}\right) \text { to } B\left(\frac{2}{\pi}, \frac{8}{\pi^{2}}\right) ; \\
\text { c) } \int_{L}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y, \\
L: x^{2}+y^{2}=2 x, y \leqslant 0 \text { from } A(0,0) \text { to } B(2,0) .
\end{gathered}
$$
original.solution:
Solution.

a) Since

$$
Q_{x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(2 x^{2}-5 x^{3}+7\right)=4 x-15 x^{2}=P_{y}=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(4 x y-15 x^{2} y\right)
$$

it is convenient to apply Green's formula, first connecting points $A$ and $B$ with a segment of the $O X$ axis (Fig. 2.10).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_05b7516b505cf6654012g-131.jpg?height=350&width=444&top_left_y=1047&top_left_x=161)

Fig. 2.10

For the positively oriented piecewise smooth contour $A B C$ (the region $\Omega$ bounded by it remains to the left), the contour integral according to Green's formula is equal to the corresponding double integral over the region $\Omega$, specifically:

$$
\oint_{A B C A} P d x+Q d y=\iint_{\Omega}\left(Q_{x}-P_{y}\right) d x d y
$$

In our case, due to the condition of potentiality $Q_{x}=P_{y}$, the right-hand side becomes zero. Therefore,

$$
\oint_{A B C^{A}} P d x+Q d y=\int_{A B} P d x+Q d y+\int_{B C A} P d x+Q d y=0 .
$$

Thus, the required integral

$$
\int_{L} P d x+Q d y=\int_{A C B} P d x+Q d y
$$

reduces to the integral over the segment $A B$, i.e.,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{L}\left(4 x y-15 x^{2} y\right) d x+\left(2 x^{2}-5 x^{3}+7\right) d y= \\
& =\int_{A B}\left(4 x y-15 x^{2} y\right) d x=\int_{1-\sqrt{3}}^{1} 0 d x=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

b) In this example, the condition of potentiality $Q_{x}=P_{y}$ is also satisfied throughout the plane $R_{2}$. We close the line $L$ with the broken line $A O C B$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A O: x=0, \quad 0 \leqslant y \leqslant \frac{4}{\pi^{2}} \\
& O C: \quad y=0, \quad 0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{2}{\pi} \\
& C B: \quad x=\frac{2}{\pi}, \quad 0 \leqslant y \leqslant \frac{8}{\pi^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

According to Green's formula, the required integral is equal to $\int_{L} x d y+y d x=\int_{A O C B} x d y+y d x=\int_{A O}^{\cdot y} x d y+\int_{O C} y d x+\int_{C B} x d y=$

$$
=\int_{\frac{4}{\pi^{2}}}^{0} 0 \cdot d y+\int_{0}^{\frac{2}{\pi}} 0 \cdot d y+\int_{0}^{\frac{8}{\pi^{2}}} \frac{2}{\pi} d y=\left.\frac{2}{\pi}\right|_{0} ^{\frac{8}{\pi^{2}}}=\frac{16}{\pi^{3}}
$$

c) In this example,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q_{x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(x y+x-y)=y+1 \\
& P_{y}=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(x y+x+y)=x+1 \\
& Q_{x}-P_{y}=y-x
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_05b7516b505cf6654012g-132.jpg?height=251&width=433&top_left_y=1235&top_left_x=702)

Fig. 2.11

We connect points $A$ and $B$ with the curve $L$ by a segment of the $O X$ axis, obtaining a contour (Fig. 2.11).

According to Green's formula,

$$
\oint_{A C B A}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y=\iint_{\Omega}(y-x) d x d y
$$

Further,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\oint_{A C B A}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y= \\
=-\int_{A C B}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y+\int_{B A} x d x= \\
=\int_{L}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y+\int_{0}^{2} x d x= \\
=\int_{L}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y-2
\end{gathered}
$$

Considering Green's formula, we get

$$
\int_{L}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y=2+\iint_{\Omega 2}(y-x) d x d y .
$$

To calculate the double integral, we switch to polar coordinates $x=r \cos \varphi, y=r \sin \varphi, 0 \leqslant r \leqslant 2 \cos \varphi ; \varphi \in\left[-\frac{\pi}{2}, 0\right]$.

$$
\begin{gathered}
\iint_{\Omega}(y-x) d x d y=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0}(\sin \varphi-\cos \varphi) d \varphi \int_{0}^{2 \cos \varphi} r^{2} d r= \\
=\frac{8}{3} \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0}(\sin \varphi-\cos \varphi) \cos ^{3} \varphi d \varphi=\frac{8}{3} \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0}\left(-\cos ^{3} \varphi\right) d(\cos \varphi)- \\
-\frac{8}{3} \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{0} \cos ^{4} \varphi d \varphi=-\left.\frac{2}{3} \cos ^{4} \varphi\right|_{-\frac{\pi}{2}} ^{0}-\frac{8}{3} \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cos ^{4} \varphi d \varphi .
\end{gathered}
$$

The last integral is equal to $\frac{3 \pi}{16}$ (it is calculated in detail in problem 3a). Therefore,

$$
\int_{L}(x y+x+y) d x+(x y+x-y) d y=2-\frac{2}{3}-\frac{\pi}{2}=\frac{8-3 \pi}{6} .
$$

original.solution:
Solution.

a) From symmetry considerations, it is clear that $x_{c}=y_{c}=0$. We will determine $z_{c}$ using a surface integral of the first kind:

$$
z_{c}=\frac{\iint_{\sigma} z \cdot p d S}{\iint_{\sigma} p d S}
$$

The area element of the hemisphere is

$$
d S=\sqrt{1+z_{x}^{2}+z_{y}^{2}} d x d y=\frac{R d x d y}{\sqrt{R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}}}
$$

## Calculate the mass of the hemisphere:

$$
\iint_{\sigma} p d S=k R \iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant R^{2}} \frac{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) d x d y}{\sqrt{R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}}}
$$

We introduce polar coordinates $x=r \cos \varphi, y=r \sin \varphi$ with the range of variables $0 \leqslant z \leqslant R, \varphi \in[0,2 \pi]$ :

$$
\begin{gathered}
k R \iiint_{\left.x^{2}\right\lrcorner y^{2} \leqslant R^{2}} \frac{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) d x d y}{\sqrt{R^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}}}=k R \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi \int_{0}^{R} \frac{r^{3} d r}{\sqrt{R^{2}-r^{2}}}= \\
=\pi k R \int_{0}^{R^{2}} \frac{d t}{\sqrt{R^{2}-t}}=-\left.2 \pi k R \sqrt{R^{2}-t} \cdot t\right|_{0} ^{R^{2}}+2 \pi k R \int_{0}^{R} \sqrt{R^{2}-t} d t= \\
=-\left.\frac{4}{3} \pi k R\left(R^{2}-t\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\right|_{0} ^{R^{2}}=\frac{4}{3} \pi k R^{4}
\end{gathered}
$$

We find the $z_{c}$ coordinate of the center of mass of the hemisphere:

$$
\begin{gathered}
z_{c}=\frac{3}{4 \pi k R^{4}} \iint_{\sigma} z \cdot \rho d S=\frac{3}{4 \pi R^{3}} \iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant R^{2}}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) d x d y= \\
=\frac{3}{4 \pi R^{3}} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi \int_{0}^{R} r^{3} d r=\frac{3}{8} R .
\end{gathered}
$$

b) In the case of the cone, just like for the hemisphere, $x_{c}=$ $=y_{c}=0$.

First, we determine the mass of the cone using a surface integral:

$$
M=\iint_{\sigma} p d S=\frac{b}{a} p_{0} \iiint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant a^{2}} \sqrt{2} d x d y=\sqrt{2} p_{0} \pi a^{2} \cdot \frac{b}{a}=\sqrt{2} p_{0} \pi a b .
$$

(The area element of the cone is calculated in problem 2.12.b.)

We calculate the $z_{c}$ coordinate of the center of mass of the homogeneous cone $a z^{2}=b^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) ; z \in[0, b]:$

$$
\begin{gathered}
M \cdot z_{c}=\iint_{\sigma} z \cdot p d S=p_{0} \quad \iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant a^{2}} \frac{b}{a} \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \cdot \sqrt{2} \cdot \frac{b}{a} d x d y= \\
=\sqrt{2} \frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}} p_{0} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi \int_{0}^{a} r^{2} d r=\frac{2 \sqrt{2} \pi p_{0} b^{2} a}{3}
\end{gathered}
$$

Therefore,

$$
z_{c}=\frac{2}{3} b
$$

Problems on calculating surface integrals of the second kind.

original.solution:
Solution.

a) For $z=0$ we obtain the planar field $\vec{A}=x^{2} y^{2} \dot{i}+\ddot{j}$, where $P=x^{2} y^{2}, Q=1$. To compute the circulation of this field along the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}$, we can use Green's formula (2.62):

$$
\begin{gathered}
\oint_{x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}} \vec{A} \cdot d \vec{l}=\iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant a^{2}}\left(Q_{x}-P_{y}\right) d x d y=-2 \iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant a^{2}} x^{2} y d x d y= \\
\quad=-2 \int_{-a}^{+a} x^{2} d x \int_{-\sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}}^{+\sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}} y d y=-\left.2 \int_{-a}^{+a} x^{2} d x y^{2}\right|_{-\sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}} ^{\sqrt{a^{2}-x^{2}}}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

b) By Stokes' formula, the circulation of the vector field along the triangle $A B C$ is equal to the flux of $\operatorname{rot} \ddot{A}$ through the plane of the triangle $A B C$ with the outward normal (the normal forms an acute angle with the $O Z$ axis), i.e.,

$$
\oint_{A B C} \dot{A} \cdot d \dot{l}=\iint_{S_{A B C}}(\operatorname{rot} \dot{A} \cdot \dot{n}) d S
$$

We will calculate the necessary quantities entering the right-hand side of Stokes' formula:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{rot} \dot{A}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
i & j & \dot{k} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\
x-2 z & x+3 y+z & 5 x+y
\end{array}\right|=-\dot{j} \cdot 7+\dot{k} ; \\
& S_{A B C}: x+y+z=1 ; \\
& \vec{n}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}(1,1,1) ; \\
& d S=\sqrt{1+z_{x}^{2}+z_{y}^{2}} d x d y=\sqrt{3} d x d y .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the sought circulation is:

$$
\oint_{A B C} \dot{A} \cdot \vec{l}=-6 \int_{\substack{x+y \leqslant 1 \\ x \geqslant 0 \\ y \geqslant 0}} d x d y=-6 \int_{0}^{1} d x \int_{0}^{1-x} d y=-3
$$

General problems related to scalar and vector fields.

Thus, the classification for this problem is:

**HARD**

original.problem:
2.8. Check that the differential expression is a complete differential of some function $u(x, y)$ and determine it:

a) $\left(3 x^{2} y+1\right) d x+\left(x^{3}-1\right) d y$

b) $y^{2} e^{x y} d x+e^{x y}(1+x y) d y$.
original.solution:
Solution.

a) In this case, $P=3 x^{2} y+1, Q=x^{3}-1$. As is known ( $\S 2.5$ ), the differential expression $P d x+Q d y$ is a complete differential of some function $u(x, y)$ if $Q_{x}=P_{y}$. Let's check this condition:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Q_{x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x^{3}-1\right)=3 x^{2} \\
& P_{y}=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(3 x^{2} y+1\right)=3 x^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The condition is satisfied. The desired function $u(x, y)$ will be determined using a line integral of the second kind, and as the line $L$ we choose a broken line connecting the points $O(0,0) ; A(x, 0) ; B(x, y)$ :

$$
\begin{gathered}
u(x, y)=\int_{O A B}\left(3 x^{2} y+1\right) d x+\left(x^{3}-1\right) d y+C= \\
=\int_{O A}\left(3 x^{2} y+1\right) d x+\int_{A B}\left(x^{3}-1\right) d y+C
\end{gathered}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_05b7516b505cf6654012g-128.jpg?height=280&width=358&top_left_y=703&top_left_x=469)

Figure 2.9

On the segment $O A$, $y=0$ and $d y=0$, on the segment $A B$, $d x=0$ (Figure 2.9). Finally, we get:

$$
u(x, y)=\int_{0}^{x} d t+\int_{0}^{y}\left(x^{3}-1\right) d t+C=x+\left(x^{3}-1\right) y+C
$$

b) Let's check the condition for the potential of the field

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \overrightarrow{\mathcal{A}}=(P, Q)=\left(y^{2} e^{x y}, e^{x y}(1+x y)\right): \\
& Q_{x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(e^{x y}(1+x y)\right)=y e^{x y}(1+x y)+y e^{x y}=y e^{x y}(2+y x), \\
& P_{y}=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(y^{2} e^{x y}\right)=2 y e^{x y}+y^{2} x e^{x y}=y e^{x y}(2+x y) .
\end{aligned}
$$

As in case a), to determine the desired potential $u(x, y)$, we will compute the work of the field along the broken line connecting the points $O(0,0) ; A(x, 0) ; B(x, y)$ :

$$
\begin{gathered}
u(x, y)=\int_{O A} y^{2} e^{x y} d x+\int_{A B} e^{x y}(1+x y) d y+C= \\
=\int_{0}^{y} e^{x t}(1+x t) d t+C=\frac{1}{x} \int_{0}^{x y} e^{\tau}(1+\tau) d \tau+C=\left.\frac{1}{x}\left(e^{\tau}(1+\tau)-e^{\tau}\right)\right|_{0} ^{x y}+ \\
+C=\frac{1}{x}\left(e^{x y}(1+x y)-e^{x y}\right)+C=y e^{x y}+C
\end{gathered}
$$

llm_response:
This problem involves checking if a given differential expression is a complete differential and then deriving the potential function \( u(x, y) \). 

In part (a) of the solution, after demonstrating that the equality \( Q_x = P_y \) holds, the solution proceeds to compute \( u(x, y) \) using a line integral. This approach does not merely involve computation but also requires understanding properties of differential forms and potential functions, which can be complex and require a rigorous mathematical argument.

In part (b), a similar process occurs where the necessary condition is checked and the potential function \( u(x, y) \) is derived. Again, this involves computation along with demonstrations concerning the conditions for the potential to exist.

Since the solution to this problem is not just straightforward differentiation but requires proving properties and computations based on differential forms, the classification should reflect the complexity.

**Classification: HARD**

original.solution:
Solution.

a) We use the Gauss-Ostrogradsky formula:

$$
\iint_{S} \vec{r} \cdot \vec{n} d S=\iiint_{V} \operatorname{div} \vec{r} \cdot d V
$$

Obviously, $S=S_{6 \text{ok}} \cup S_{\text {osn }}(S_{\text {bok }}, S_{\text {osn }}$ - the lateral surface and the base surface of the cylinder) and by the additivity property of the surface integral, we get:

$$
\iint_{S} \vec{r} \cdot \vec{n} d S=\iint_{S_{\infty o x}} \vec{r} \cdot \vec{n} d S+\iint_{S_{\propto \times}} \vec{r} \cdot \vec{n} d S
$$

The integrals

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \iint_{S_{\circ x n}} \dot{r} \cdot \vec{n} d S \text { and } \iiint_{V} \operatorname{div} \vec{r} \cdot d V: \\
& \iint_{S_{\mathrm{ocH}}} \vec{r} \cdot \ddot{n} d S=\iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant R^{2}} H d x d y-\iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant R^{2}}(-H) d x d y=2 H \pi R^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

(see the solution of problem 2.15),

$$
\iiint_{V} \operatorname{div} \dot{r} \cdot d V=\iiint_{V} 3 d x d y d z=3 \iiint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant R^{2}} d x d y \int_{-H}^{H} d z=3 H \pi R^{2}
$$

Thus, for the sought flux through the lateral surface of the cylinder, we obtain the value

$$
\iint_{S_{(x * k}} \vec{r} \cdot \dot{n} d S=\iiint_{V} \operatorname{div} \ddot{r} \cdot d V-\iint_{S_{(<\times k}} \ddot{r} \cdot \dot{n} d S=\pi R^{2} H
$$

b) We compute the flux of the radius vector through the base of the cone $(z=1)$:

$$
\iint_{S_{\mathrm{orH}}} \dot{r} \cdot \dot{n} d S=-\iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant 4} d x d y=-4 \pi
$$

The sign "−" indicates that $\dot{n}$ is the inward normal. Now, similarly to the previous solution, we use the Gauss-Ostrogradsky formula and the additivity of the surface integral. In the calculations, we use the outward normal $\dot{n}$, then simply change the sign to the opposite:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\iint_{S_{\text {6ox }}} \vec{r} \cdot \vec{n} d S=\iiint_{V} \operatorname{div} \ddot{r} \cdot d V-\iint_{S_{\mathrm{och}}} \vec{r} \cdot \vec{n} d S= \\
=3 \iiint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant 4} d x d y \int_{\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}}^{1} d z-4 \pi= \\
=3 \iiint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant 4} d x d y-4 \pi-\frac{3}{2} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2} r^{2} d r d \varphi=8 \pi-\left.\frac{3}{2} 2 \pi \cdot \frac{r^{3}}{3}\right|_{0} ^{2}=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

c) We apply the Gauss-Ostrogradsky formula. Since $\operatorname{div} \vec{r}=3$, the flux of the radius vector through the surface of the cube will be equal to three times the volume of the cube with side $2 a$. Thus,

$$
\iint_{S} \ddot{r} \cdot \ddot{n} d S=24 a^{3}
$$

## Problems related to Stokes' formula.

original.problem:
2.28. Under the action of gravity $\dot{g}$, directed opposite to the $O Z$ axis, a body of unit mass slides down a spiral:

$$
x=a \cos \varphi, y=a \sin \varphi, z=b(2 \pi-\varphi)
$$

from point $A(a, 0,2 \pi b)$ to point $B(a, 0,0)$.

Find the work of the field during such a displacement.
original.solution:
Solution. The vector field $\vec{F}$ of gravitational force has components:

$$
\vec{F}=(0,0,-g)
$$

where $g \approx 9.81 \frac{\mathrm{M}}{c^{2}}$.

Obviously, $\operatorname{rot} \vec{F}=\overrightarrow{0}$, hence this field is potential. Let's determine its potential:

$$
\varphi=\int_{0}^{x} 0 d t+\int_{0}^{y} 0 d t-\int_{0}^{z} g d t+C=C-g \cdot z \quad(C=\text { const })
$$

The work of the field $\vec{F}$ when moving a body from $A$ to $B$ is equal to the difference in potentials at these points:

$$
A=\varphi(B)-\varphi(A)=C-(C-g \cdot 2 \pi b)=2 \pi g b
$$

llm_response:

The solution derives the gravitational force, establishes the potential, and then computes the work done as the difference in potential between two points. This process requires knowledge of vector fields, potential energy, and line integrals, which does not merely involve computation but also some conceptual understanding of physics and vector calculus.

This implies that the problem requires reasoning and some properties to be proven about the gravitational field and work done by it, thus fitting under the classification of having a deeper property-based solution rather than straightforward computation.

Therefore, I classify this problem as:

HARD

original.problem:
3.11. Are the functions differentiable:
a) $f(z)=y^{2}+x^{2}+2 i x y$

b) $f(z)=e^{3 x} \cos 2 y-i e^{3 x} \sin 2 y$

c) $f(z)=n^{2} z^{n}, n \in \mathbb{N}$,

d) $f(z)=2 \operatorname{sh} \cos z+2 \operatorname{ch} \sin z$.
original.solution:
Solution.

a) For a function of a complex variable $f(z)$ to be differentiable in some domain $D$ of the complex plane, it is necessary and sufficient that the real and imaginary parts of the function $f(z)$ be differentiable and that the Cauchy-Riemann conditions be satisfied.

Consider the function $f(z)=y^{2}+x^{2}+2 i x y$. It is clear that the functions $u(x, y)=\operatorname{Re} f(z)=y^{2}+x^{2}, v(x, y)=\operatorname{Im} f(z)=2 x y$ are differentiable $\forall x, y \in \mathbb{R}$, but the Cauchy-Riemann conditions are not satisfied:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial x}=2 x, \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial y}=2 y, \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}=2 y, \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}=2 x \\
\frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}, \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial y} \neq-\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, the function $f(z)$ is not differentiable.

b) Consider the function $f(z)=e^{3 x} \cos 2 y-i e^{3 x} \sin 2 y$. It is clear that the functions $u(x, y)=e^{3 x} \cos 2 y, v(x, y)=-e^{3 x} \sin 2 y$ are differentiable $\forall x, y \in \mathbb{R}$, but the Cauchy-Riemann conditions are not satisfied:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial x}=3 e^{3 x} \cos 2 y, \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial y}=-2 e^{3 x} \sin 2 y \\
\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}=-3 e^{3 x} \sin 2 y, \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}=-2 e^{3 x} \cos 2 y \\
\frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial x} \neq \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}, \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial y} \neq-\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, the function $f(z)$ is not differentiable.

c) Let's separate the real and imaginary parts of the function $f(z)=n^{2} z^{n}:$

$$
\begin{gathered}
f(z)=n^{2} z^{n}=e^{r e^{r i v} \ln n}\left(r e^{i \varphi}\right)^{n}=e^{r \ln n \cos \varphi+i r \ln n \sin \varphi} r^{n} e^{i n \varphi}= \\
=n^{r \cos \varphi} r^{n} e^{i(r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)}=n^{r \cos \varphi} r^{n} \cos (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)+ \\
+i n^{r \cos \varphi} r^{n} \sin (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi) .
\end{gathered}
$$

It is clear from this that the functions $u(x, y)=$ $=\operatorname{Re} f(z), v(x, y)=\operatorname{Im} f(z)$ are differentiable for $r \geqslant 0, \varphi \in[0,2 \pi)$. The Cauchy-Riemann conditions are satisfied, indeed:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial u(r, \varphi)}{\partial r}=n^{r \cos \varphi} r^{n}\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\cos (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)\left(\cos \varphi \ln n+\frac{n}{r}\right)- \\
-\ln n \sin \varphi \sin (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)
\end{array}\right) \\
& \frac{\partial u(r, \varphi)}{\partial \varphi}=-r^{n} n^{r \cos \varphi}\binom{r \ln n \sin \varphi \cos (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)+}{+(r \ln n \cos \varphi+n) \sin (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)}, \\
& \frac{\partial v(r, \varphi)}{\partial r}=n^{r \cos \varphi} r^{n}\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sin (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)\left(\cos \varphi \ln n+\frac{n}{r}\right)+ \\
+\ln n \sin \varphi \cos (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)
\end{array}\right\} \\
& \frac{\partial v(r, \varphi)}{\partial \varphi}=r^{n} n^{r \cos \varphi}\binom{(r \ln n \cos \varphi+n) \cos (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)-}{-r \ln n \sin \varphi \sin (r \ln n \sin \varphi+n \varphi)} \\
& \frac{\partial u(r, \varphi)}{\partial r}=\frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial v(r, \varphi)}{\partial \varphi}, \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial u(r, \varphi)}{\partial \varphi}=-\frac{\partial v(r, \varphi)}{\partial r}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the function $f(z)$ is differentiable.

Note: One could also use the algebraic form of the complex number $z=x+i y$ and the formula:

$$
(x+i y)^{n}=\sum_{k=0}^{\left[\frac{n}{2}\right]} C_{n}^{2 k}(-1)^{k} x^{n-2 k} y^{2 k}+
$$

$$
+i\left\{\sum_{k=0}^{\left[\frac{n}{2}\right]} C_{n}^{2 k-1}(-1)^{k+1} x^{n-2 k+1} y^{2 k-1}+\frac{y^{n}}{2}(-1)^{\left[\frac{n}{2}\right]}\left(1+(-1)^{n+1}\right)\right\}
$$

d) Let's separate, as before, the real and imaginary parts of the function $f(z)=2 \operatorname{sh} \cos z+2 \operatorname{ch} \sin z$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(z)=2 \operatorname{sh} \cos z+2 \operatorname{ch} \sin z=e^{\cos z}-e^{-\cos 2}+e^{\sin 2}+e^{-\sin 2}= \\
& =e^{\cos (x+i y)}-e^{-\cos (x+i y)}+e^{\sin (x+i y)}+e^{-\sin (x+i y)}= \\
& =e^{\cos x \cos i y-\sin x \sin i y}-e^{-\cos x \cos i y+\sin x \sin i y}+e^{\sin x \cos i y+\cos x \sin i y}+ \\
& +e^{-\sin x \cos i y-\cos x \sin i y}=e^{\cos x \operatorname{ch} y-i \sin x \operatorname{sh} y}-e^{-\cos x \operatorname{ch} y+i \sin x \operatorname{sh} y}+ \\
& +e^{\sin x \operatorname{chh} y+i \cos x \operatorname{sh} y}+e^{-\sin x \operatorname{chh} y-i \cos x \operatorname{sh} y}=e^{\cos x \operatorname{ch} y}(\cos \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\}- \\
& -i \sin \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\})-e^{-\cos x c h y}(\cos \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\}+ \\
& +i \sin \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\})+e^{\sin x \operatorname{ch} y}(\cos \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\}+i \sin \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\})+ \\
& +e^{-\sin x \operatorname{ch} y}(\cos \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\}-i \sin \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\})= \\
& =e^{\cos x \operatorname{ch} y} \cos \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\}-i e^{\cos x \operatorname{ch} y} \sin \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\}- \\
& -e^{-\cos x \operatorname{ch} y} \cos \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\}-i e^{-\cos x c h y} y \sin \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\}+
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
+e^{\sin x \operatorname{ch} y} \cos \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\}+i e^{\sin x \operatorname{ch} y} \sin \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\}+ \\
+e^{-\sin x \operatorname{ch} y} \cos \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\}-i e^{-\sin x \operatorname{ch} y} \sin \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\}= \\
\quad=2 \cos \{\sin x \operatorname{sh} y\} \operatorname{sh}\{\cos x \operatorname{ch} y\}+ \\
+2 \cos \{\cos x \operatorname{sh} y\} \operatorname{ch}\

Each function's differentiability is not just a mechanical computation, but a formal proof showing whether certain conditions hold or do not hold for specific functions.

The associated solutions require substantial reasoning and verification of conditions rather than straightforward differentiation.

Thus, we can classify the problem as follows:

HARD: The solution requires proving a property related to differentiability and checking conditions, which requires careful reasoning beyond simple computations.

original.problem: 3.12. Given the real part $u(x, y)=x^{2}-y^{2}+2 x$ of a differentiable function $f(z)$. Find $f(z)$.
original.solution:
Solution.

Since the function $f(z)$ is differentiable, the Cauchy-Riemann conditions are satisfied, i.e.,

$$
\frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}, \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial y}=-\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}
$$

or, in the context of our problem:

$$
\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}=2 y, \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}=2 x+2
$$

For the expression

$$
\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x} d x+\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y} d y
$$

to represent the total differential of some function $U(x, y)$ (called the potential function), it is necessary and sufficient, as is known from the course of classical analysis, that the condition (see Chapter 2)

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial y} \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}
$$

is satisfied, which is the case here. We will reconstruct the potential function $U(x, y)$ from its total differential by taking a line integral of the second kind over the contour $L=L_{1}+L_{2}$, where

$$
L_{1}:\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=t, \\
y=y_{0}, \\
t \in\left[x_{0}, x\right] ;
\end{array} \quad L_{2}:\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=x \\
y=t \\
t \in\left[y_{0}, y\right]
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

We have:

$$
\begin{gathered}
U(x, y)=\int_{L} \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x} d x+\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y} d y=\int_{L} 2 y d x+(2 x+2) d y= \\
=\int_{L_{1}} 2 y_{0} d t+\int_{L_{2}}(2 x+2) d t=2 y_{0} \int_{x_{0}}^{x} d t+(2 x+2) \int_{y_{0}}^{y} d t= \\
=2 y_{0}\left(x-x_{0}\right)+(2 x+2)\left(y-y_{0}\right)= \\
=(2 x y+2 y)-\left(2 y_{0} x_{0}+2 y_{0}\right)=U_{1}(x, y)-U_{1}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right) .
\end{gathered}
$$

It is clear from this that

$$
U(x, y)=U_{1}(x, y)+c=2 x y+2 y+c, c \in \mathbb{X} .
$$

It is not difficult to see that this is the imaginary part of the function $f(z)$, from which it follows that

$$
\begin{gathered}
f(z)=x^{2}-y^{2}+2 x+i(2 x y+2 y+c)=x^{2}- \\
-y^{2}+2 x+i(2 x y+2 y)+C= \\
=\left(x^{2}+2 x(i y)+(i y)^{2}\right)+2(x+i y)+C=(x+i y)^{2}+ \\
+2(x+i y)+C=z^{2}+2 z+C, C=i c .
\end{gathered}
$$

llm_response:
This problem involves finding a complex function \( f(z) \) given its real part and using the Cauchy-Riemann equations. The solution requires verifying properties of analytic functions and integrating to reconstruct the imaginary part, which involved multiple steps and justifications.

This solution does not simply involve executing a computation or differentiating a function, nor does it require a proof of some property that isn't computational. However, the process relies significantly on justifying relationships (Cauchy-Riemann conditions) and the existence of potential functions through integration.

Given that this problem is not just about calculating derivatives or simple computations but about confirming relationships between parts of analytic functions, this problem falls into a category beyond mere computation and requires some conceptual justification which doesn't lend itself to straightforward verification in a formal proof assistant.

Therefore, I classify this problem as:

**HARD**

original.problem:
3.15. Check the fulfillment of the Cauchy-Riemann conditions for the following functions of a complex variable:
a) \( f(z) = \sin^2 z \)
b) \( f(z) = \ln z \)
c) \( f(z) = 4^{z^2 + 2iz} \)
original.solution:
Solution.

a) Let's separate the real and imaginary parts of the function $f(z)$:

$$
\begin{gathered}
f(z)=\sin ^{2} z=\left\{\frac{e^{i z}-e^{-i z}}{2 i}\right\}^{2}=-\frac{1}{4}\left\{e^{2 i z}-2+e^{-2 i z}\right\}= \\
=-\frac{1}{4}\left\{e^{2 i(x+i y)}-2+e^{-2 i(x+i y)}\right\}=-\frac{1}{4}\left\{e^{2 i x-2 y}-2+e^{-2 i x+2 y}\right\}= \\
=-\frac{1}{4}\left\{e^{-2 y}(\cos 2 x+i \sin 2 x)-2+e^{2 y}(\cos 2 x-i \sin 2 x)\right\}= \\
=-\frac{1}{4}\left(\cos 2 x\left(e^{-2 y}+e^{2 y}\right)-2\right)-i \frac{\sin 2 x}{4}\left(e^{-2 y}-e^{2 y}\right)= \\
=\frac{1-\cos 2 x \operatorname{ch} 2 y}{2}+i \frac{\sin 2 x \operatorname{sh} 2 y}{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Let's check the Cauchy-Riemann conditions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial x}=\sin 2 x \operatorname{ch} 2 y, \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial y}=-\cos 2 x \operatorname{sh} 2 y \\
& \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}=\cos 2 x \operatorname{sh} 2 y, \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}=\sin 2 x \operatorname{ch} 2 y
\end{aligned}
$$

The Cauchy-Riemann conditions are satisfied for the function

$$
f(z)=\sin ^{2} z
$$

b) By definition, it is true that:

$$
f(z)=\operatorname{Ln} z=\ln |z|+i(\arg z+2 \pi k), k \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

It is not difficult to show that for the principal value of the argument of a complex number $z$, the following representation holds (assuming $\arg z \in[0,2 \pi)$):

$$
\arg z=\left[\begin{array}{l}
\frac{\pi}{2}(1-\operatorname{sign} x)+\operatorname{sign}(x y) \operatorname{arctg}\left|\frac{y}{x}\right|, x \neq 0 \\
\frac{\pi}{2} \operatorname{sign} y, x=0, y \neq 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

$$
\arg z=\lim _{\substack{n \rightarrow u \\ \sim y}}\left\{\frac{\pi}{2}(1-\operatorname{sign} \xi)+\operatorname{sign}(\xi \eta) \operatorname{arctg}\left|\frac{n}{\xi}\right|\right\},(x, y) \neq(0,0)
$$

Let's check the Cauchy-Riemann conditions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial x}=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}, \quad \frac{\partial u(x, y)}{\partial y}=\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \\
& \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x}=\frac{-y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}, \quad \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The Cauchy-Riemann conditions are satisfied for the function

$$
f(z)=\ln z
$$

Note. In deriving the formulas for

$$
\frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial x} \text { and } \frac{\partial v(x, y)}{\partial y}
$$

the following formulas and properties were used:

1) $\operatorname{sign}(x y)=\operatorname{sign} x \operatorname{sign} y$;
2) $\operatorname{sign} \frac{y}{x}=\operatorname{sign} y \operator

original.solution:
Solution.

a) $\operatorname{div} \ddot{A}=\frac{\partial(y+z)}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial(x+z)}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial(x+y)}{\partial z}=0$.

Therefore, the field $\vec{A}$ is solenoidal. Let's find its vector potential $\vec{B}$. As is known ( $\$ 2.4$ ), the vector potential is defined up to an additive term $\operatorname{grad} \varphi$, where $\varphi(x, y, z)$ is an arbitrary differentiable function. Therefore, we will seek the simplest expression for the vector potential $\vec{B}\left(B_{1}, B_{2}, B_{3}\right)$. In particular, let $B_{3}=0$. The components $B_{1}$ and $B_{2}$ will be determined from the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{rot} \vec{B}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\vec{i} & \vec{j} & \vec{k} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\
B_{1} & B_{2} & B_{3}
\end{array}\right|=-\frac{\partial B_{2}}{\partial z} \vec{i}+\frac{\partial B_{1}}{\partial z} \dot{j}+\left(\frac{\partial B_{2}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial B_{1}}{\partial y}\right) \vec{k}= \\
& =(y+z) \vec{i}+(x+z) \vec{j}+(x+y) \vec{k}
\end{aligned}
$$

From this, we obtain:

$$
\frac{\partial B_{2}}{\partial z}=-y-z \Rightarrow B_{2}=\int(-y-z) d z+f(x, y)
$$

where $f(x, y)$ is an arbitrary differentiable function;

$$
\frac{\partial B_{1}}{\partial z}=x+z \Rightarrow B_{1}=\int(x+z) d z+g(x, y)
$$

where $g(x, y)$ is an arbitrary differentiable function.

After integration, we determine $B_{1}$ and $B_{2}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& B_{1}=x z+\frac{z^{2}}{2}+g(x, y) \\
& B_{2}=-y z+\frac{z^{2}}{2}+f(x, y)
\end{aligned}
$$

To determine the functions $g$ and $f$, recall that there is still one unsatisfied condition:

$$
\frac{\hat{\partial} B_{2}}{\partial x}-\frac{\hat{c} B_{1}}{\partial y}=x+y \Rightarrow \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(-y z+\frac{z^{2}}{2}\right)-\frac{\hat{c}}{\partial y}\left(x z+\frac{z^{2}}{2}\right)+\frac{\hat{\partial} g}{\partial x}-\frac{\hat{c} f}{\partial y}=x+y
$$

We are interested in the simplest partial expression for the functions $g$ and $f$. For example, we can set

$$
g=\frac{x^{2}}{2} \text { and } f=-\frac{y^{2}}{2},
$$

then $\frac{\partial g}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}=x+y$. Thus, the sought vector potential $\vec{B}$ has the form:

$$
\vec{B}=\left(x z+\frac{z^{2}}{2}+\frac{x^{2}}{2},-y z-\frac{z^{2}}{2}-\frac{y^{2}}{2}, 0\right)+\operatorname{grad} \varphi
$$

b) Let's calculate $\operatorname{div} \vec{A}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{div} \vec{A} & =\frac{\partial\left(y e^{x^{2}}\right)}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial(2 y z)}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial\left(2 x z y e^{x^{2}}+z^{2}\right)}{\partial z}= \\
& =2 x y e^{x^{2}}+2 z-2 z-2 x y e^{x^{2}}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

The field $\vec{A}$ is solenoidal. The vector potential $\vec{B}$ will be sought in the same way as in case a):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{rot} \dot{B}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\vec{i} & \vec{j} & \vec{k} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\
B_{1} & B_{2} & 0
\end{array}\right|=-\frac{\partial B_{2}}{\partial z} \vec{i}+\frac{\partial B_{1}}{\partial z} \vec{j}+\left(\frac{\partial B_{2}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial B_{1}}{\partial y}\right) \vec{k}= \\
& =y e^{x^{2}} \vec{i}+2 y z \vec{j}-+\left(2 x y z e^{x^{2}}+z^{2}\right) \dot{k} .
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& B_{2}=-\int y e^{x^{2}} d z+f(x, y)=-y z e^{x^{2}}+f(x, y) \\
& B_{1}=\int 2 y z d z+g(x, y)=y z^{2}+g(x, y) \\
& \frac{\partial B_{2}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial B_{1}}{\partial y}=\frac{\hat{c}}{\partial x}\left(-y z e^{x^{2}}+f\right)-\frac{\hat{c}}{\partial y}\left(y z^{2}+g\right)=-2 x y z e^{x^{2}}-z^{2}+f_{x}^{\prime}-g_{y}^{\prime} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The simplest choice for the functions $f$ and $g$ is zero, i.e., $f=g=0$. Finally, we obtain:

$$
\vec{B}=\left(y z^{2},-y z e^{x^{2}}, 0\right)+\operatorname{grad} \varphi
$$

where $\varphi=\varphi(x, y, z)$ is an arbitrary differentiable scalar field.

$$

where $L$ is the unit circle centered at the origin.
original.solution:
Solution. The integrand can be represented in the form

$$
\frac{f(z)}{(z-a)^{3}}
$$

where $f(z)=6^{-3} \sin 3 z, a=\frac{\pi}{6}$. The function $f(z)$ is a single-valued analytic function in the domain $D$, such that

$$
D=\left\{z \in \simeq \| z \left\lvert\, \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}\right.\right\}
$$

and $L \subset D$ is a closed continuous line bounding the region $G=\{z \in C \| z \mid<1\} \subset D$. Thus, all conditions of Cauchy's integral formula are satisfied, and by its corollary, we have:

$$
\int_{L} \frac{\sin 3 z}{(6 z-\pi)^{3}} d z=\frac{2 \pi i}{2!} f^{n}(a)=i \pi f^{n}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=-\frac{i \pi}{24}
$$

original.problem:
### 3.24. By computing the integral

$$
\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{a}\right)}
$$

over the contour \( L=\{z \in \overline{S} \mid z \mid=1\} \), prove that for \(\alpha \in (0,1)\) the following equality holds:

$$
\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{d \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi}=\frac{2 \pi}{1-\alpha^{2}}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The integral

$$
\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)}
$$

can be transformed as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)}=\frac{\alpha}{2 \pi i\left(1-\alpha^{2}\right)} \int\left(\frac{1}{z-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-\frac{1}{z-\alpha}\right) d z=
\end{aligned}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_05b7516b505cf6654012g-223.jpg?height=114&width=502&top_left_y=1092&top_left_x=397)

The integral

$$
J_{1}=\int_{L} \frac{d z}{z-\frac{1}{a}}
$$

is equal to zero, because for $\alpha \in(0,1)$, the integrand

$$
f(z)=\frac{1}{z-\frac{1}{\alpha}}
$$

is analytic in the region

$$
D=\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} \| z \left\lvert\,=\frac{1}{\alpha}+\delta\right., \quad \alpha \in(0,1), \quad \delta>0\right\}
$$

which encompasses the contour $L$.

According to Cauchy's integral formula, the integral $J_{2}=\int_{L} \frac{d z}{z-\alpha}$ is equal to $J_{2}=2 \pi i f(\alpha)=2 \pi i$.

Thus,

$$
\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)}=\beta\left\{J_{1}-J_{2}\right\}=\frac{\alpha}{2 \pi i\left(1-\alpha^{2}\right)}(0-2 \pi i)=\frac{\alpha}{\alpha^{2}-1} .
$$

Transform the integral

$$
\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_05b7516b505cf6654012g-224.jpg?height=52&width=779&top_left_y=635&top_left_x=163)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)}=\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)}=\beta\left\{\int_{L} \frac{d z}{z-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-\int_{L} \frac{d z}{z-\alpha}\right\}= \\
& =\beta\left\{\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{i e^{i \varphi} d \varphi}{e^{i \varphi}-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{i e^{i \varphi} d \varphi}{e^{i \varphi}-\alpha}\right\}= \\
& =i \beta\left\{\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{(\cos \varphi+i \sin \varphi) d \varphi}{\cos \varphi-\frac{1}{\alpha}+i \sin \varphi}-\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{(\cos \varphi+i \sin \varphi) d \varphi}{\cos \varphi-\alpha+i \sin \varphi}\right\}= \\
& =i \beta\left\{\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{(\cos \varphi+i \sin \varphi)\left(\cos \varphi-\frac{1}{\alpha}-i \sin \varphi\right) d \varphi}{\left(\cos \varphi-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)^{2}+\sin ^{2} \varphi}-\right. \\
& =i \beta\left\{\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{1-\frac{1}{\alpha} \cos \varphi-i \frac{1}{\alpha} \sin \varphi}{\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}\left(1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi\right)} d \varphi-\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{1-\alpha \cos \varphi-\alpha i \sin \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi} d \varphi\right\}= \\
& =i \beta \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left\{\frac{\alpha^{2}-\alpha \cos \varphi-i \alpha \sin \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi}-\frac{1-\alpha \cos \varphi-\alpha i \sin \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi}\right\} d \varphi= \\
& =i \beta \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\alpha^{2}-1}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi} d \varphi=i \beta\left(\alpha^{2}-1\right) \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{d \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi}= \\
& =\frac{-\alpha}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{d \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi} \cdot
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus,

$$
\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{L} \frac{d z}{(z-\alpha)\left(z-\frac{1}{\alpha}\right)}=\frac{-\alpha}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{d \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi}
$$

from which it follows that:

$$
\frac{-\alpha}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{d \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi}=\frac{\alpha}{\alpha^{2}-1} \Leftrightarrow \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{d \varphi}{1+\alpha^{2}-2 \alpha \cos \varphi}=\frac{2 \pi}{1-\alpha^{2}} .
$$

original.problem:
### 3.34. Compute the integral

$$
\int_{L} \frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)} d z
$$

where $L-$ is a rectangle bounded by the following lines: $x=2, x=-1, y=2, y=-1$.
original.solution:
Solution. The special points of the integrand function, which in this example has the form

$$
f(z)=\frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}
$$

are the points $z=0$ and $z=\frac{\pi}{2}$. The point $z=0$ is a removable singularity of the integrand function, since at this point

$$
\lim _{z \rightarrow 0} f(z)=\lim _{z \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}=\lim _{z \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin z}{z} \lim _{z \rightarrow 0}\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=1 \cdot\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=-\frac{\pi}{2}
$$

Therefore, at this point

$$
\operatorname{res}\left(\frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}, 0\right)=0
$$

The point $z=\frac{\pi}{2}$ is a simple pole of the integrand function. Therefore, according to the formula for calculating the residue at a simple pole, we have:

$$
\operatorname{res}\left(\frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\lim _{z \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}}\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \cdot \frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}=\lim _{z \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\sin z}{z}=\frac{\sin \frac{\pi}{2}}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=\frac{1}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=\frac{2}{\pi}
$$

Now, by the main theorem of residues, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{L} \frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)} d z=2 \pi i\left(\operatorname{res}\left(\frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}, 0\right)+\operatorname{res}\left(\frac{\sin z}{z\left(z-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)= \\
& 3.35 \text { Find } \quad=2 \pi i i\left(0+\frac{2}{\pi}\right)=4 i .
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\int_{L} \sin \frac{i}{z} d z
$$

where $L-$ is a circle of radius $r>0$, i.e., $|z|=r$.

Solution. In the region of the complex plane bounded by the specified circle, the integrand function $f(z)=\sin \frac{i}{z}$ has a single singular point $z=0$, which is an essential singularity of this function. Indeed, the Laurent series expansion of this function in the annulus $0<|z|<r$ is

$$
\sin \frac{i}{z}=\sum_{n=0}^{x} \frac{(-1)^{2 n+1}}{(2 n+1)!}\left(\frac{i}{z}\right)^{2 n+1}=\frac{i}{z}-\frac{1}{3!}\left(\frac{i}{z}\right)^{3}+\ldots
$$

From the given Laurent series expansion of the integrand function, it follows that the coefficient $c_{-1}=i$. Therefore, $\operatorname{res}\left(\sin \frac{i}{z}, 0\right)=c_{-1}=i$. According to the main theorem of residue theory, we have:

$$
\int_{L} \sin \frac{i}{z} d z=2 \pi i \operatorname{res}\left(\sin \frac{i}{z}, 0\right)=2 \pi i \cdot i=2 \pi i^{2}=2 \pi(-1)=-2 \pi
$$

llm_response:
This problem involves computing integrals using residue theory, which requires more than just straightforward calculations. The solution involves proving properties about singularities of the integrand and calculating residues, which is not merely executing a computation. The verification of the results derived from such proofs typically involves complex analysis concepts rather than direct numerical computations.

Thus, the classification for the given problem is:

HARD: The solution requires proving some properties of the function and applying the residue theorem, making it more complex than a straightforward computation.

original.problem:
3.33. Compute

$$
\int \frac{e^{2 z}}{\left(z+\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)^{2}} d z
$$

where $L$ is the circle $|z|=1$.
original.solution:
Solution. A special point of the integrand function $f(z)=\frac{e^{2 z}}{\left(z+\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)^{2}}$ is the point $z=-\frac{\pi i}{2}$, which represents a pole of second order. There are no other special points of the function $f(z)$ within the region bounded by the circle $|z|=1$. Therefore, by the main theorem of residues, we have:

$$
\int_{L} \frac{e^{2 z}}{\left(z+\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)^{2}} d z=2 \pi i \operatorname{res}\left(\frac{e^{2 z}}{\left(z+\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)^{2}},-\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)
$$

By the general formula for computing the residue at a pole of order $n$, and in this case for $n=2$, we have:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{res}\left(\frac{e^{2 z}}{\left(z+\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)^{2}},-\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)=\frac{1}{(2-1)!} \lim _{z \rightarrow-\frac{\pi i}{2}} \frac{d}{d z}\left[\left(z+\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{e^{2 z}}{\left(z+\frac{\pi i}{2}\right)^{2}}\right]= \\
=\lim _{z \rightarrow-\frac{\pi i}{2}} \frac{d}{d z} e^{2 z}=\lim _{z \rightarrow-\frac{\pi i}{2}} e^{2 z}=e^{-\frac{\pi i}{2}}=\cos \frac{\pi}{2}-i \sin \frac{\pi}{2}=-i
\end{gathered}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\int \frac{e^{2 z}}{\left(z+\frac{\pi l}{2}\right)^{2}} d z=2 \pi i \cdot(-i)=2 \pi
$$

original.problem: 4.22. Obtain the general solution of the equation $x y^{3} d x+\left(x^{2} y^{2}-\right.$ $-1) d y=0$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let's make the substitution $y=w^{\beta}$, where the parameter $\beta$ will be determined from the condition of equality of the sums of the degrees of each of the monomials standing in parentheses before $d x$ and $d w$: $x w^{3 \beta} d x+\left(x^{2} w^{3 \beta-1}-w^{\beta-1}\right) \beta d w=0$. We equate the sums of the degrees of the monomials: $1+3 \beta=2+3 \beta-1=\beta-1$, from which

$$
\beta=-1, \quad y=\frac{1}{z}
$$

the original equation takes the form of a homogeneous equation: $w x d x+$ $+\left(w^{2}-x^{2}\right) d w=0$. We make the substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u(x)=\frac{w(x)}{x} \\
& w(x)=x u(x) ; d w=u d x+x d u \\
& u x^{2} d x+\left(u^{2} x^{2}-x^{2}\right)(u d x+x d u)=0 \\
& \left(u x^{2}+u^{3} x^{2}-u x^{2}\right) d x+\left(x^{3} u^{2}-x^{3}\right) d u=0
\end{aligned}
$$

or $u^{3} d x+x\left(u^{2}-1\right) d u=0$. We separate the variables:

$$
\frac{\left(u^{2}-1\right) d u}{u^{3}}=-\frac{d x}{x}
$$

We integrate both sides:

$$
\int \frac{d u}{u}-\int u^{-3} d u=-\int \frac{d x}{x}, \ln |u|+\frac{1}{2 u^{2}}=-\ln |x|+\ln C
$$

we return to the function $w: \ln \left|\frac{w}{x}\right|+\frac{1}{2(w / x)^{2}}=\ln \frac{C}{|x|}$. We return to the function $y(x)=\frac{1}{w(x)}: \ln \left|\frac{1}{y x}\right|+\frac{y^{2} x^{2}}{2}=\ln \frac{C}{|x|}$. Note that in addition to this solution, the original equation has a particular solution $y=0$.

$$

original.problem:
4.39. Integrate the Bernoulli equation

$$
\frac{d y}{d x}+\frac{y}{x}=\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{y^{2}}
$$

using two methods: the Bernoulli method and the method of variation of arbitrary constants, after first reducing it to a linear equation.
original.solution:
The problem is solved. 1st method. First, we will use the Bernoulli method.

1st step. Represent the unknown function $y(x)$ as a product of two new unknown functions $u(x)$ and $v(x)$: $y(x)=u(x) \cdot v(x)$, where $\frac{d y}{d x}=v(x) \frac{d u}{d x}+u(x) \frac{d v}{d x}$.

2nd step. Substitute the expressions for $y(x)$ and its derivative into the original equation:

$$
v(x) \frac{d u}{d x}+u(x) \frac{d v}{d x}+\frac{u(x) v(x)}{x}=\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{(u(x) v(x))^{2}}
$$

and factor out $u(x)$ in the last two terms of the left side:

$$
v(x) \frac{d u}{d x}+u(x)\left[\frac{d v}{d x}+\frac{v(x)}{x}\right]=\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{(u(x) v(x))^{2}}
$$

3rd step. Set the expression in the square brackets to zero: $\frac{d v}{d x}+\frac{v(x)}{x}=0$, and solve the resulting equation by the method of separation of variables: $v(x)=\frac{1}{x}$.

4th step. Substitute the found function into the equation obtained in the 2nd step, to get an equation for the unknown function $u(x)$:

$$
\frac{1}{x} \frac{d u}{d x}=\frac{1}{x^{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\left(u(x) \frac{1}{x}\right)^{2}}
$$

Solve it by the method of separation of variables: $u^{2} d u=x d x$;

$$
\int u^{2} d u=\int x d x ; \quad \frac{u^{3}}{3}=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+C ; u(x)=\sqrt[3]{\frac{3 x^{2}}{2}+3 C}
$$

Denote $3 C=C_{1}$.

5th step. Write down the answer:

$$
y(x)=u(x) v(x)=\frac{1}{x} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{3 x^{2}}{2}+C_{1}}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{2 x}+\frac{C_{1}}{x^{3}}}
$$

2nd method. Now let's solve this equation by reducing it to a linear equation. We have $\alpha=-2$. Introduce the substitution: $u(x)=(y(x))^{1-a}=(y(x))^{1-(-2)}=(y(x))^{3}$. We get a linear first-order ODE with a non-zero right-hand side:

$$
\frac{d u}{d x}+\frac{3}{x} \cdot u=\frac{3}{x^{2}}
$$

Apply the method of variation of arbitrary constants.

1st step. Solve the corresponding homogeneous equation $\frac{d u}{d x}+\frac{3}{x} u=0$ by the method of separation of variables:

$$
\frac{d u}{u}=-3 \cdot \frac{d x}{x} ; \int \frac{d u}{u}=-3 \int \frac{d x}{x} ; \ln |u|=-3 \ln |x|+\ln C ; u(x)=\frac{C}{x^{3}} .
$$

2nd step. Replace the arbitrary constant of integration $C$ with a function $C(x)$ to be determined:

$$
u(x)=\frac{C(x)}{x^{3}}
$$

3rd step. Substitute the new expression for $y(x)$ into the original equation and obtain an equation for $C(x)$:

$$
\frac{d C}{d x} \cdot \frac{1}{x^{3}}=\frac{3}{x^{2}}, \text{ hence } \frac{d C}{d x}=3 x
$$

4th step. Solve the resulting equation by the method of separation of variables: $d C=3 x d x ; C(x)=\frac{3 x^{2}}{2}+C_{1}$.

5th step. Write down the final answer, returning to the sought function: $y(x)=\sqrt[3]{\left(\frac{3 x^{2}}{2}+C_{1}\right) \frac{1}{x^{3}}}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{2 x}+\frac{C_{1}}{x^{3}}}$.

\end{gathered}
\]

From this, when \( 8 a - 2 b = 0 \), \(\frac{d v}{d t} = -2 \left( a x^{2} + 2 b y^{2} \right) \). The Lagrangian function takes the form \( v(x, y) = 2 \left( a x^{2} + 2 b y^{2} \right) = 2 a \left( x^{2} + 8 y^{2} \right) \). For \( a > 0 \), it is differentiable everywhere, and \( v(x, y) > 0 \) when \( x \neq 0, y \neq 0 \), \( v(0,0) = 0 \), and the origin is a point of strict minimum:

Example 2.16. Prove that if $u(x)$ and $v(x)$ have $n$ continuous derivatives on a finite interval, then the following formula holds:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{a}^{b} u v^{(n)} d x & =\left(u v^{(n-1)}-u^{\prime} v^{(n-2)}+\ldots\right. \\
\left.\ldots+(-1)^{(n-1)} u^{(n-1)} v\right) & \left.\right|_{a} ^{b}-\int_{a}^{b} u^{(n)} v d x
\end{aligned}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. We will use the method of mathematical induction.

1) The formula is valid for $n=1$, as it coincides with $(2.3)$.
2) Suppose the formula is valid for $k=n-1$, that is,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{a}^{b} u v^{(n-1)} d x=\left(u v^{(n-2)}-u^{\prime} v^{(n-3)}+\ldots\right. \\
& \left.\quad \ldots+(-1)^{(n-2)} u^{(n-2)} v\right)\left.\right|_{a} ^{b}-(-1)^{(n-1)} \int_{a}^{b} u^{(n-1)} v d x
\end{aligned}
$$

3) Based on the results of points 1 and 2, we will prove the validity of formula (2.4):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{a}^{b} u v^{(n)} d x=\int_{a}^{b} u\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{(n-1)} d x=\left(u\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{(n-2)}-u^{\prime}\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{(n-3)}+\ldots+\right. \\
& \left.\quad+(-1)^{(n-2)} u^{(n-2)}\left(v^{\prime}\right)\right)\left.\right|_{a} ^{b}-(-1)^{(n-1)} \int_{a}^{b} u^{(n-1)}\left(v^{\prime}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

The last integral we will take by parts:

$$
\int_{a}^{b} u^{(n-1)}\left(v^{\prime}\right) d x=\left.u^{(n-1)} v\right|_{a} ^{b}-\int_{a}^{b} u^{n} v d x
$$

Substituting the last expression into the previous one, we obtain formula (2.4).

\end{aligned}
$$

original.problem: Example 2.43. Investigate the absolute and conditional convergence of the improper integral $\int_{0}^{1} \frac{(-1)^{[1 / x]} d x}{x}$, where $[1 / x]$ denotes the integer part of the number $1 / x$, i.e., the greatest integer not exceeding $1 / x$.
original.solution:
Solution. The integral of the modulus of the integrand

$$
\int_{0}^{1}\left|(-1)^{[1 / x]} \frac{d x}{x}\right|=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d x}{x}=\left.\lim _{a \rightarrow+0} \ln x\right|_{a} ^{1}=\infty
$$

diverges.

We will prove the conditional convergence of this integral. First, we make the substitution $\frac{1}{t}=x, d x=-\frac{d t}{t^{2}}$, after which we get:

$$
I=\int_{0}^{1}(-1)^{[1 / x]} \frac{d x}{x}=\int_{1}^{\infty}(-1)^{[x]} \frac{d x}{x}=\lim _{b \rightarrow+\infty} \int_{1}^{b}(-1)^{[x]} \frac{d x}{x}
$$

First, consider the special case $b=n$, where $n$ is a natural number. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\int_{n_{1}}^{n_{2}}(-1)^{[x]} \frac{d x}{x}\right|=\left|\sum_{p=n_{1}}^{n_{2}-1} \int_{p}^{p+1}(-1)^{p} \frac{d x}{x}\right|= \\
& =\left|\sum_{p=n_{1}}^{n_{2}-1}(-1)^{p} \ln \frac{p+1}{p}\right|0$ choose $n_{0}$ such that for $n_{1} \geqslant n_{0}>1$

$$
\ln \frac{n_{1}}{n_{1}-1}x_{1} \geqslant n_{0}+1$ for any real numbers, then we have (choosing $n_{1}$ and $n_{2}$ such that $x_{1} \leqslant n_{1}<n_{2} \leqslant x_{2}$ and $n_{1}-x_{1}<1, x_{2}-n_{2}<1$ )

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}(-1)^{[x]} \frac{d x}{x}\right| \leqslant\left|\int_{x_{1}}^{n_{1}}(-1)^{[x]} \frac{d x}{x}\right|+\left|\int_{n_{1}}^{n_{2}}(-1)^{[x]} \frac{d x}{x}\right|+\left|\int_{n_{2}}^{x_{2}}(-1)^{[x]} \frac{d x}{x}\right| \leqslant \\
\leqslant \ln \frac{n_{1}}{n_{1}-1}+\ln \frac{n_{1}+1}{n_{1}}+\ln \frac{n_{2}+1}{n_{2}}<\varepsilon
\end{gathered}
$$

According to the Cauchy criterion discussed earlier in this chapter, the integral converges.

original.problem: Example 2.45. $I=\mathrm{V} . \mathrm{p} . \int_{1 / e}^{e} \frac{d x}{x \ln x}$. Calculate the improper integral of the second kind in the sense of the principal value.

$$
\begin{gathered}
I=\lim _{a \rightarrow+0}\left(\int_{1 / e}^{1-a} \frac{d(\ln x)}{\ln x}+\int_{1+a}^{e} \frac{d(\ln x)}{\ln x}\right)= \\
=\lim _{a \rightarrow+0}\left(\ln \left|\ln x\left\|_{1 / e}^{1-a}+\ln \mid \ln x\right\|_{1+a}^{e}\right)=\right. \\
=\lim _{a \rightarrow+0}(\ln |\ln (1-a)|-\ln |\ln 1-\ln e|+\ln |\ln e|-\ln |\ln (1+a)|)= \\

=\ln \left|\lim _{a \rightarrow+0}\left(-\frac{1+a}{1-a}\right)\right|=\ln 1=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

Example 2.44. Investigate the conditional and absolute convergence of the improper integral

$$
I=\int_{0}^{2}\left[2 x \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)-\frac{2 \pi}{x} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right] d x
$$
original.solution:
Solution.

$$
\begin{gathered}
I=\lim _{a \rightarrow+0} \int_{a}^{2}\left(2 x \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)-\frac{2 \pi}{x} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right) d x= \\
=\lim _{a \rightarrow+0} \int_{a}^{2}\left(x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right)^{\prime} d x= \\
=\lim _{a \rightarrow+0}\left(2^{2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{2^{2}}\right)-a^{2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{a^{2}}\right)\right)=4 \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)-0=2 \sqrt{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

The integral converges. Now let's investigate the integral of the modulus of the previous integrand.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{2} \left|2 x \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right) - \frac{2 \pi}{x} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right| d x= \\
& =\lim _{a \rightarrow+0} \int_{a}^{2}\left|2 x \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)-\frac{2 \pi}{x} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right| d x
\end{aligned}
$$

If $x \in\left[\sqrt{\frac{2}{2+4 n}}, \sqrt{\frac{2}{1+4 n}}\right]$, then $\frac{\pi}{x^{2}} \in\left[\frac{\pi}{2}+2 \pi n, \pi+2 \pi n\right]$ and therefore the integrand will be positive for these values of $x$. Let's estimate the integral from below.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{2}\left|2 x \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)-\frac{2 \pi}{x} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right| d x=\int_{0}^{2}\left|x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right|^{\prime} d x> \\
> & \sum_{k=0}^{n} \int_{\sqrt{2 /(2+4 k)}}^{\sqrt{2 /(1+4 k)}}\left(x^{2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{x^{2}}\right)\right)^{\prime} d x=\sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{2}{1+4 k},(n=0,1,2, \ldots)
\end{aligned}
$$

We will show that $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{2}{1+4 k}=+\infty$. For this, consider the integral

$$
\int_{0}^{n} \frac{2 d x}{1+4 x}=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \int_{k}^{k+1} \frac{2 d x}{1+4 x}
$$

And we verify that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{2}{1+4 x} \leqslant \frac{2}{1+4 k}, x \in[k, k+1], \int_{k}^{k+1} \frac{2 d x}{1+4 x} \leqslant \frac{2}{1+4 k} \\
\int_{0}^{n} \frac{2 d x}{1+4 x}=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \int_{k}^{k+1} \frac{2 d x}{1+4 x} \leqslant \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \frac{2}{1+4 k}
\end{gathered}
$$

However, the integral on the left tends to infinity as $n \rightarrow \infty$:

$$
\int_{0}^{n} \frac{2 d x}{1+4 x}=\left.\frac{1}{2} \ln (1+4 x)\right|_{0} ^{n}=\frac{1}{2} \ln (1+4 n) \rightarrow+\infty(n \rightarrow+\infty)
$$

The convergence is conditional.

original.problem: Example 3.8. Determine whether the function $f(x, y) = \frac{2 x^{2} y^{2}}{x^{4}+y^{4}}$ has a limit when 1) $x \rightarrow 0, y \rightarrow 0$; 2) $x \rightarrow \infty, y \rightarrow \infty$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) From the definition of a limit, it follows that the result of the limit transition should not depend on the method of its implementation. Let, for example, the point $P(x, y)$ tend to the point $O(0,0)$ along the line $y=k x$. We have

$$
\lim _{\substack{x \rightarrow 0 \\ y \rightarrow 0}} \frac{2 x^{2} y^{2}}{x^{4}+y^{4}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 x^{4} k^{2}}{x^{4}+k^{4} x^{4}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 k^{2}}{1+k^{4}}=\frac{2 k^{2}}{1+k^{4}}
$$

As can be seen, the result varies depending on $k$, and therefore the considered function does not have a limit at the point $P(0,0)$.

2) We will use the same method as in the first case. We obtain

$$
\lim _{\substack{x \rightarrow 0 \\ y \rightarrow 0}} \frac{2 x^{2} y^{2}}{x^{4}+y^{4}}=\frac{2 k^{2}}{1+k^{4}}
$$

that is, the result of the limit transition depends on $k$ or, in other words, on the method of its implementation. This means, as in the first case, that the considered function does not have a limit as $x \rightarrow \infty$ and $y \rightarrow \infty$.

original.problem: Example 3.7. Is the function $z=$ $=f(x, y)=\sqrt{4-x^{2}-y^{2}}$ bounded above (below)?
original.solution:
Solution. The function $f$ is bounded from above and below, as $0 \leqslant f(x, y) \leqslant 2$. Moreover, the function has the maximum and minimum values on $D(f)$: $\max _{(x, y) \in D} f=2, \min _{(x, y) \in D} f=0$

## 3.2 .  LIMIT AND CONTINUITY

The definition of a limit is generalized for the case of functions of several variables as follows.

Let the function $f(P)$ be defined in some neighborhood of the point $P_{0}\left(x_{1}{ }^{0}, x_{2}{ }^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}{ }^{0}\right) \in D(f) \subset E^{n}$, except possibly at the point $P_{0}$. The function $f(P)$ has a limit at the point $P_{0}$, equal to $A$, if for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists a $\delta(\varepsilon)>0$ such that for all points $P\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ in the domain of the function $D(f)$, for which $0<\rho\left(P, P_{0}\right)<\delta$, the inequality $|f(P)-A|<\varepsilon$ holds.

Notation

$$
\lim _{P \rightarrow P_{0}} f(P)=A ; \lim _{\rho\left(P, P_{0}\right) \rightarrow 0} f(P)=A ; \lim _{\substack{x_{1} \rightarrow x_{1}^{0} \\ x_{2} \rightarrow x_{2}^{0} \\ x_{n} \rightarrow x_{n}^{0}}} f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=A
$$

Theorems about limits of functions of one variable are easily generalized and remain valid for functions of several variables. It is important to note that the given definition of a limit assumes the simultaneous approach of the arguments $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ to their limits, that is, respectively, to $x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}$. Therefore, the specified limit is also called an $n$-fold limit. Along with the $n$-fold limit, repeated limits are also considered, obtained as a result of limit transitions for each argument separately. In general, both types of limits of functions of several variables at a point can lead to different results, which must be taken into account when finding the $n$-fold limit of a function of variables.

Example 3.12. Investigate the continuity of the function

$$
f(x, y)= \begin{cases}-\frac{x y^{2}}{y^{2}+y^{4}}, & \text { when } x^{2}+y^{4} \neq 0 \\ 0, & \text { when } x^{2}+y^{4}=0\end{cases}
$$

at the point $O(0,0)$.
original.solution:
Solution. The given function is continuous with respect to each of the variables $x$ and $y$ at the point $O(0,0)$, since

$$
\begin{gathered}
\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0} \Delta_{x} f(0,0)=\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}(f(\Delta x, 0)-f(0,0))= \\
=\left.\lim _{\Delta x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{\Delta x y^{2}}{\Delta x^{2}+y^{4}}\right)\right|_{y=0}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

Similarly for the variable $y$ we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\lim _{\Delta y \rightarrow 0} \Delta_{y} f(0,0)=\lim _{\Delta y \rightarrow 0}(f(\Delta y, 0)-f(0,0))= \\
=\left.\lim _{\Delta y \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{x \Delta y^{2}}{x^{2}+\Delta y^{4}}\right)\right|_{x=0}=0
\end{gathered}
$$

At the same time, for the increments of the independent variables $\delta x=x-0, \delta y=y-0$, the corresponding increment of the function at the point $O(0,0)$ is $\Delta f(0,0)=\frac{\Delta x \Delta y^{2}}{\Delta x^{2}+\Delta y^{4}}$.

The limit of the obtained expression as $\Delta x \rightarrow 0, \Delta y \rightarrow 0$ does not exist, since, for example, if $\Delta x=a \Delta y^{2}$, then

$$
\lim _{\substack{\Delta y \rightarrow 0 \\ \Delta x \rightarrow 0}} \Delta f(0,0)=\lim _{\Delta y \rightarrow 0} \frac{a \Delta y^{4}}{\left(1+a^{2}\right) \Delta y^{4}}=\frac{a}{1+a^{2}}
$$

and when $a=0, \lim _{\substack{\Delta x \rightarrow 0 \\ \Delta y \rightarrow 0}} \Delta f(0,0) \neq 0$. This means, according to the definition of continuity, that the function under consideration is not continuous at the point $O(0,0)$, but is continuous with respect to each of its variables at this point.

## 3.3.  PARTIAL DERIVATIVES AND DIFFERENTIALS OF FUNCTIONS OF SEVERAL VARIABLES

Let the point $P_{0}\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$ belong to the domain of the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$. The partial derivative of the function of several variables $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ with respect to the variable $x_{l}$ at the point $P_{0}\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$ is defined as the limit of the ratio of the partial increment $\Delta_{x_{l}} f\left(P_{0}\right)$ to the increment $\Delta x_{l}$ as the increment $\Delta x_{l}$ approaches zero, if such a limit exists.

The partial derivative is denoted as follows: $f_{x_{l}}^{\prime}\left(P_{0}\right), \frac{\partial f\left(P_{0}\right)}{\partial x_{l}}$. Thus, according to the definition,

$$
\begin{gathered}
f_{x_{l}}^{\prime}\left(P_{0}\right)=\frac{\partial f\left(P_{0}\right)}{\partial x_{l}}=\lim _{\Delta x_{l} \rightarrow 0} \frac{\Delta x_{l} f\left(P_{0}\right)}{\Delta x_{l}}= \\
=\lim _{\Delta x_{l} \rightarrow 0} \frac{f\left(x_{1}^{0}, \ldots, x_{l}^{0}+\Delta x_{l}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)-f\left(x_{1}^{0}, \ldots, x_{l}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)}{\Delta x_{l}}
\end{gathered}
$$

From the definition of the partial derivative of the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ with respect to the variable $x_{k}(k=1,2 \ldots, n)$ at the point $P_{0}\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$, it follows that it is calculated under the condition that the values of all other variables of the function, except $x_{k}$, are fixed and equal to $x_{i}^{0}$, that is, in the same way as the derivative of a function of one variable. Consequently, partial derivatives of functions of several variables possess all the properties of the derivative of a function of one variable. Therefore, all differentiation rules are valid for partial derivatives of functions of several variables. Let's illustrate this with specific examples.

Example 3.11. Investigate the continuity of the function

$$
f(x, y, z)=\left\{\begin{array}{lr}
x^{4}+\frac{2 x y z}{y^{2}+z^{2}}, & y^{2}+z^{2} \neq 0 \\
x^{4}, & y^{2}+z^{2}=0
\end{array}\right.
$$
original.solution:
Solution. If $y^{2}+z^{2} \neq 0$, then the function is continuous due to the fact that $\lim _{P(x, y, z) \rightarrow P\left(x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}\right)} f(x, y, z)=f\left(x_{0}, y_{0}, z_{0}\right)$.

For points where $y^{2}+z^{2}=0$, consider two cases:

1) Point $P_{1}\left(x_{0}, 0,0\right)$, where $x_{0} \neq 0$. If point $P(x, y, z)$ moves towards point $P_{1}$ along the line $x=x_{0} \neq 0, y=0$, then $\lim _{P \rightarrow P_{1}} f(P)=$ $=x_{0}^{4}$. If point $P(x, y, z)$ moves along the line $x=x_{0} \neq 0$, $z=y$, then for $P\left(x_{0}, y, y\right)$ when $y \neq 0 \quad f(P)=x_{0}^{4}+x_{0} \quad$ and $\lim _{P \rightarrow P_{1}} x_{0}^{4}+x_{0} \neq f\left(P_{1}\right)$, since $x_{0} \neq 0$. Thus, the function is discontinuous at point $P_{1}$.
2) Investigate point $P_{2}(0,0,0)$. From the chain of inequalities $(y+z)^{2} \geqslant 0, y^{2}+2 y z+z^{2} \geqslant 0,\left(y^{2}+z^{2}\right) / 2 \geqslant|y z|$, we obtain that $f(x, y, z) \leqslant x^{4}+|x|$ when $y^{2}+z^{2} \neq 0$ and $f(x, y, z)=x^{4}$ when $y^{2}+z^{2}=0$, therefore, as $P(x, y, z) \rightarrow P_{2}(0,0,0)$, we get that $f(P) \rightarrow f\left(P_{2}\right)$, since $x \rightarrow \mathbf{0}$. Hence, $f(P)$ is continuous at point $P_{2}(0,0,0)$.

In addition to the concept of a function of several variables being continuous at a point with respect to the set of variables, as given above, the concept of a function of several variables being continuous at a point with respect to one variable is also introduced. The continuity of a function of several variables with respect to one of its variables means the continuity of the specified function of one variable when the values of all other variables are fixed: A strict definition of this concept can be given based on the definition of the partial increment of a function of several variables with respect to one of the variables at a given point.

The partial increment of a function $(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n})$ with respect to the variable $x_{i}$ at the point $P_{0}\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$ is the difference $\Delta_{x_{i}} f\left(P_{0}\right)=f\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{l-1}^{0}, x_{l}^{0}+\Delta x_{i}, x_{l+1}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)-$ $-f\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{l-1}^{0}, x_{l}^{0}, x_{l+1}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$.

A function $y=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ is called continuous at the point $P_{0}\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$ with respect to the variable $x_{l}$ if its partial increment at the point $P_{0}$ is an infinitesimal function of $\Delta x_{l}$, that is, if the condition $\lim _{\Delta x_{l} \rightarrow 0} \Delta_{x_{l}} f\left(P_{0}\right)=$ $=0$ is satisfied. Continuity of a function of several variables at a given point with respect to the set of variables implies continuity of this function at the same point with respect to each of its variables. However, continuity of the function $y=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ with respect to each of the variables $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ at a given point $P_{0}$ does not, in general, imply continuity of this function at the point $P_{0}$ (i.e., with respect to the set of variables). This is confirmed by the following example.

Example 3.17. Does $f_{x y}^{\prime \prime}(0,0)$ exist if

$$
f(x, y, z)= \begin{cases}\frac{x y^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{4}}, & \text { when } x^{2}+y^{4} \neq 0 \\ 0, & \text { when } x^{2}+y^{4}=0\end{cases}
$$

(see example 3.12).
original.solution:
Solution. The given second-order partial derivative represents the partial derivative with respect to the variable $y$ of the first-order partial derivative with respect to the variable $x$. Therefore, we first need to compute $f_{x}^{\prime}$. We have

$$
f_{x}^{\prime}=\frac{y^{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{4}\right)-x y^{2} 2 x}{\left(x^{2}+y^{4}\right)^{2}}=\frac{x^{2} y^{2}+y^{6}-2 x^{2} y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{4}\right)^{2}}=\frac{y^{6}-x^{2} y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{4}\right)^{2}}
$$

for $x^{2}+y^{4} \neq 0$. When $x^{2}+y^{4}=0$, according to the definition of the partial derivative, we get $(\Delta x \equiv x)$ :

$$
\begin{gathered}
f_{x}^{\prime}(0,0)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{f(x, 0)-f(0,0)}{x}\right)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\left.\frac{y^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{4}}\right|_{y=0}-0\right)= \\
=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}(0-0)=0
\end{gathered}
$$

Now let's find the partial derivative $f_{x y}^{\prime \prime}$ at the point $(0,0)$. According to the definition $(\Delta y \equiv y)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f_{x y}^{\prime \prime}(0,0)=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{f_{x}^{\prime}(0, y)-f_{x}^{\prime}(0,0)}{y}\right)= \\
= & \left.\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{y^{6}-x^{2} y^{2}}{y\left(x^{2}+y^{4}\right)^{2}}\right)\right|_{y=0}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{y^{3}}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

The last limit does not exist, hence $f_{x y}^{\prime \prime}(0,0)$ does not exist either.

It is easy to notice that in the above example 9.16, the mixed partial derivatives $u_{x y}^{\prime \prime}$ and $u_{y x}^{\prime \prime}$ turned out to be equal. Further, conditions will be formulated under which this will be the case. Note that partial derivatives obtained by differentiation with respect to different variables are called mixed partial derivatives. Partial derivatives obtained by differentiation with respect to only one variable are called pure partial derivatives.

One of the most important concepts in the differential calculus of functions of several variables is the concept of differentiability of a function at a point.

A function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ is called differentiable at a point $P\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ if its total increment $\Delta f(P)$ at this point can be represented in the form

$$
\Delta f(P)=A_{1} \Delta x_{1}+A_{2} \Delta x_{2}+\ldots+A_{n} \Delta x_{n}+o(\rho)
$$

where $A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots, A_{n}$ are quantities that do not depend on $\Delta x_{1}, \Delta x_{2}, \ldots$, $\Delta x_{n}$.

The differential $d f$ of the first order of the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ at the point $P\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ is called the principal linear part with respect to the increments of the arguments of the total increment $\Delta f(P)$ of this function at this point

$$
d f=A_{1} \Delta x_{1}+A_{2} \Delta x_{2}+\ldots+A_{n} \Delta x_{n}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A_{i} \Delta x_{i}
$$

If the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ is differentiable at the point $P\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$, then at this point there exist first-order partial derivatives with respect to all arguments, and $\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{i}}=A_{i}$, where $A_{i}$ is defined in (3.3). Thus

$$
d f(P)=f_{x_{1}}^{\prime} \Delta x_{1}+f_{x_{2}}^{\prime} \Delta x_{2}+\ldots+f_{x_{n}}^{\prime} \Delta x_{n}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} f_{x_{2}}^{\prime} \Delta x_{i}
$$

If the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ is differentiable at the point $P\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$, then it is also continuous at this point.

If the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ has continuous first-order partial derivatives with respect to all arguments in some neighborhood of the point $P$, then the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ is differentiable at the point $P$.

## 3.4. DIFFERENTIATION OF COMPOSITE AND IMPLICIT FUNCTIONS

Let the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ be differentiable at the point $P\left(x_{1}^{0}, x_{2}^{0}, \ldots, x_{n}^{0}\right)$, and the functions $x_{i}=\varphi_{i}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{m}\right),(i=1$, $2, \ldots, k)$ be differentiable at the point $M_{0}\left(t_{1}^{0}, t_{2}^{0}, \ldots, t_{m}^{0}\right)$ and such that $x_{i}^{0}=\varphi_{i}\left(t_{1}^{0}, t_{2}^{0}, \ldots, t_{m}^{0}\right)$. Then the composite function $y=$ $=f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}\right), x_{i}=\varphi_{i}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{m}\right), i=1,2, \ldots, k$ is differentiable at the point $M_{0}$ and its partial derivatives are determined by the formula

$$
\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_{j}}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{i}} \frac{\partial x_{i}}{\partial t_{j}}, j=1,2, \ldots, m
$$

where all partial derivatives $\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{i}}$ are computed at the point $P_{0}$, and all partial derivatives $\frac{\partial x_{i}}{\partial t_{j}}$ - at the point $M_{0}$.

From formula (3.12), some important formulas for differentiating composite functions of several variables follow.

1) $u=f(x, y, z, t)$, where $x=x(t), y=y(t), z=z(t)$. In this case, by setting in (3.12) $n=4, m=1, x_{1}=x, x_{2}=y, x_{3}=$ $=z, x_{4}=t$, we obtain the following formula for the total (or material) derivative of the function $f(x, y, z, t)$ :

$$
\frac{d f}{d t}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \frac{d x}{d t}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \frac{d y}{d t}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial z} \frac{d z}{d t}
$$

2) $z=f(u, v)$, where $u=u(x, y), v=v(x, y)$. The formulas for the partial derivatives $f_{x}^{\prime}, f_{y}^{\prime}$ are obtained from (3.12) by setting

$$
\begin{gathered}
x_{1}=u, x_{2}=v, t_{1}=x, t_{2}=y n=2, m=2: \\
\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \\
\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial y}
\end{gathered}
$$

3) $f=f(u, v, w), u=u(x, y, z), v=v(x, y, z), w=w(x, y, z)$. The formulas for the partial derivatives $f_{x}^{\prime}, f_{y}^{\prime} f_{z}^{\prime}$ are obtained from (3.12) similarly to case 2, setting $n=3, m=3$ and adding the corresponding variables $x_{3}=w, t_{3}=z$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial v} \frac{\partial v}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial w} \frac{\partial w}{\partial x} \\
& \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}=\frac{\partial f}{\partial u} \frac{\partial u}{\partial y}

Example 3.44. Investigate the function for local extremum

original.solution:
Solution. We find the derivatives $f_{x_{1}}^{\prime}$ and $f_{x_{2}}^{\prime}$; solving the obtained system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
6 x_{1} x_{2}-3 x_{1}^{2}=0 \\
3 x_{1}^{2}-4 x_{2}^{2}=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

we find two points $P_{0}(6,3)$ and $P_{1}(0,0)$.

To establish the nature of the found stationary points, we will use the sufficient condition for an extremum and investigate the sign definiteness of the quadratic form, which, as is easily noticed, represents the second differential:

$$
\begin{gathered}
d^{2} f=f_{x_{1} x_{1}}^{\prime \prime} d x_{1}^{2}+f_{x_{1} x_{2}}^{\prime \prime} d x_{1} d x_{2}+f_{x_{2} x_{1}}^{\prime \prime} d x_{2} d x_{1}+f_{x_{2} x_{2}}^{\prime \prime} d x_{2}^{2}= \\
=\left(6 x_{2}-6 x_{1}\right) d x_{1}^{2}+6 x_{1} d x_{1} d x_{2}+6 x_{1} d x_{2} d x_{1}-8 x_{2} d x_{2}^{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

We form the matrix $\left(\begin{array}{cc}6 x_{2}-6 x_{1} & 6 x_{1} \\ 6 x_{1} & -8 x_{2}\end{array}\right)$. We compute the values of the corresponding minors according to (3.36):

& \Delta_{1}=\left.\left(6 x_{2}-6 x_{1}\right)\right|_{\substack{x_{1}=6 \\
x_{2}=3}}=-18, \\

6 x_{2}-6 x_{1} & 6 x_{1} \\
6 x_{1} & -8 x_{2}

x_{2}=3}}=648
\end{aligned}
$$

According to (3.37), we obtain that at point $P_{0}$ the function has a maximum $f_{\text {max }}=72$.

Now let's investigate the point $P_{1}(0,0)$. At this point $\Delta_{1}(0,0)=0$, $\Delta_{2}(0,0)=0$ and additional investigation is required. Since at $x_{1}=0$ and $x_{2}=0, f(0,0)=0$; at $x_{1}=0$, and at $x_{1}>0$ and $x_{2}=0, f\left(x_{1}, 0\right)=-x_{1}^{3}<0$, there are both positive and negative values of $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ in the neighborhood of point $P_{1}(0,0)$, meaning $P_{1}(0,0)$ is a saddle point.

original.problem: Example 4.5. Establish the convergence for the reciprocals of squares $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^{2}}$.
original.solution:
Solution. Similarly to Example 4.1, it is not difficult to establish the convergence of the series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n(n+1)}$. The series under investigation can be represented differently as $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^{2}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{(n+1)^{2}}$. However, the terms of the latter series satisfy the inequality

$$

$$

Therefore, by Theorem 4.5, the series of the reciprocals of squares converges.

original.problem: Example 3.49. Investigate the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=x_{2}^{2}-x_{1}^{2}$ for the presence of a local extremum subject to the condition $x_{1}-2 x_{2}+3=0$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let's form the Lagrange function

$$
L(x, y, \lambda)=x_{2}^{2}+x_{1}^{2}+\lambda\left(x_{1}-2 x_{2}+3\right)
$$

We will find the points where the first-order partial derivatives of this function are zero. We have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{\partial L}{\partial x_{1}}=-2 x_{1}+\lambda=0 \\
\frac{\partial L}{\partial x_{2}}=2 x_{2}-2 \lambda=0 \\
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda}=x_{1}-2 x_{2}+3=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

From this, we obtain the point of possible extremum $P_{1}(1,2,-1)$. Next, we find $d^{2} L\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, \lambda\right)=-2 d x_{1}^{2}+2 d x_{2}^{2}+$ $+2 d x_{2} d \lambda-d x_{1} d \lambda$. This quadratic form is indefinite, as the minors of the matrix corresponding to this quadratic form $\left(\begin{array}{cc}-2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2\end{array}\right), \Delta_{1}=-2, \Delta_{2}=\left|\begin{array}{cc}-2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2\end{array}\right|=$ $=-5-$ are negative. Thus, $L(x, y, \lambda)$ does not have an extremum. However, we will prove that the conditional extremum of the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ under the constraint exists.

Indeed, from the constraint, it follows that $d x_{1}=2 d x_{2}$ and $d^{2} L=-6 d x_{2}^{2}$ - is a negative definite quadratic form, and the point $x_{1}=1, x_{2}=2$ is a point of local maximum of the function $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ under the constraint $x_{1}-2 x_{2}+$ $+3=0$.

**HARD**

Solution. We have

$$
