It does not simply involve executing a computation or differentiating a function; instead, it requires an understanding of inequalities and properties related to random variables.

Thus, this problem is classified as:

HARD

original.problem:
103. Show that for any $\lambda>0$ the Boolean transformation

$$
x \rightarrow x-\frac{\lambda}{x} \quad(x \neq 0)
$$

preserves the Lebesgue measure on $\mathbb{R}$, i.e., for any integrable function $f$ on $\mathbb{R}$, the following equality holds:

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x) d x=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f\left(x-\frac{\lambda}{x}\right) d x
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let $\lambda=1$ initially. Then the desired relation follows from the following equalities, valid for any function $f$ integrable on $\mathbb{R}:$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int_{0}^{\infty} f\left(x-\frac{1}{x}\right) d x=\int_{-\infty}^{0} f\left(y-\frac{1}{y}\right) \frac{d y}{y^{2}} \\
\int_{\mathbb{R}} f\left(x-\frac{1}{x}\right) d x=\int_{-\infty}^{0} f\left(y-\frac{1}{y}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{y^{2}}\right) d y=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(z) d z
\end{gathered}
$$

Now let $\lambda$ be any positive number. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}} f\left(x-\frac{\lambda}{x}\right) d x=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f\left(\sqrt{\lambda} x-\frac{\sqrt{\lambda}}{x}\right) \sqrt{\lambda} d x=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(\sqrt{\lambda} x) & \sqrt{\lambda} d x= \\
& =\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

llm_response:
The problem requires showing that a specific transformation preserves Lebesgue measure for any integrable function. The solution involves manipulating integrals and verifying properties rather than performing a straightforward computation or differentiation.

Since the task centers on proving a property regarding the measure-preserving nature of a transformation rather than executing a specific calculation, this qualifies as a proof of a property rather than a direct computation.

Thus, I classify this problem as:

HARD

original.problem:
92. Let $X$ be a random variable with distribution function $F=F(x)$, satisfying the Lipschitz condition:

$$
|F(x)-F(y)| \leqslant L|x-y|, \quad x, y \in \mathbb{R},
$$

for some constant $L>0$. Show that $X$ has a density $f=f(x)$ and for almost all $x \in \mathbb{R}$ (with respect to the Lebesgue measure) the inequality $f(x) \leqslant L$ holds.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $\mathrm{P}_{X}$ denote the distribution of the random variable $X$, which is a probability measure on $(\mathbb{R}, \mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R}))$. We will show that this measure is absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure $\lambda$ defined on Borel sets.

By the regularity of the Lebesgue measure on $\mathbb{R}$ (see problem II.3.32), for any such set $B \in \mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$ with $\lambda(B)=0$ and any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists an open set $B \subset G$ such that $\lambda(G) \leqslant \varepsilon$. Any open set in $\mathbb{R}$ can be represented as a countable union of non-intersecting intervals $\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right), n \geqslant 1$, hence

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{P}_{X}(B) \leqslant \mathrm{P}_{X}\left(\bigcup_{n \geqslant 1}\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right)\right) \leqslant \sum_{n \geqslant 1}\left[F\left(b_{n}\right)\right. & \left.-F\left(a_{n}\right)\right] \leqslant \\
& \leqslant L \sum_{n \geqslant 1}\left[b_{n}-a_{n}\right]=L \lambda(G) \leqslant L \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
\]

By the arbitrariness of $\varepsilon$, we conclude that $\mathrm{P}_{X}(B)=0$. Thus, $\mathrm{P}_{X} \ll \lambda$, and by the Radon-Nikodym theorem, $X$ has a density $f=\frac{d \mathrm{P}_{X}}{d \lambda}$.

Next, using the regularity of the measure $\mathrm{P}_{X}$ and the mentioned representation of open sets on $\mathbb{R}$, we find that for any $B \in \mathbb{R}$, the inequality

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{B} f(x) d \lambda=\inf \left\{\mathrm{P}_{X}(G): G \text { open, } B \subset G\right\} \leqslant \\
& \leqslant \inf \{L \lambda(G): G \text { open, } B \subset G\}=L \int_{B} 1 d \lambda \text {. }
\end{aligned}
\]

From this, it follows that the density $f$ is bounded by the constant $L$.

llm_response:
This problem requires demonstrating that a random variable with a Lipschitz continuous distribution function has a density and that this density is bounded. This involves using properties from measure theory, specifically the Radon-Nikodym theorem, to show absolute continuity with respect to the Lebesgue measure, and to establish an inequality involving the density.

The steps include showing that the probability measure corresponding to the distribution function is absolutely continuous, which is a property that is typically proved through a detailed argument rather than executing a straightforward computation.

Thus, even though there is a computation involved, the primary task here is to prove certain properties of the function and its relationship with measures. 

Therefore, this problem fits into the category of proving some property, which makes it more complex than an outright computation:

**HARD**

99. Let (in the notation and conditions of the previous problem)

$$
A=\sum_{n \geqslant 1} \frac{\mathrm{P}\left(S_{n} \leqslant 0\right)}{n}, \quad B=\sum_{n \geqslant 1} \frac{\mathrm{P}\left(S_{n}>0\right)}{n} .
$$

Show that

$$
\mathrm{P}\left(\tau_{1}<\infty\right)= \begin{cases}1, & \text { if } B=\infty \\ 1-e^{-B}, & \text { if } B<\infty\end{cases}
$$

Prove also that

$$
\mathrm{E} \tau_{1}= \begin{cases}e^{A}, & \text { if } A<\infty \\ \infty, & \text { if } A=\infty\end{cases}
$$
original.solution:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{P}\left(\tau_{1} \leqslant n\right)=\mathrm{P}\left(\max _{1 \leqslant k \leqslant n} S_{k}>0\right)=\mathrm{P}\left(\max _{1 \leqslant k \leqslant n} S_{k} \geqslant 1\right)=\mathrm{P}\left(\min _{1 \leqslant k \leqslant n} S_{k} \leqslant 0\right) \\
& \mathrm{E} s^{\tau_{1}}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} s^{n} \mathrm{P}\left(\tau_{1}=n\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} s^{n} \mathrm{P}\left(\max _{1 \leqslant k \leqslant n} S_{k}>0, \max _{1 \leqslant k \leqslant n-1} S_{k} \leqslant 0\right) \\
& =\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} s^{n} \mathrm{P}\left(S_{n}>0, \max _{1 \leqslant k \leqslant n-1} S_{k} \leqslant 0\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} s^{n} \mathrm{P}\left(S_{n}>0, S_{n-1} \leqslant 0, \ldots, S_{1} \leqslant 0\right) \\
& =\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} s^{n} \mathrm{P}\left(S_{n}>0, S_{n-1} \leqslant 0\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} s^{n} \mathrm{P}\left(S_{n} \leqslant 0\right) \\
& =\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{s^{n}}{n} \mathrm{P}\left(S_{n} \leqslant 0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last quantity clearly increases to $A$ as $s \uparrow 1$.

104. Let $f=f(x)$ be a convex non-decreasing function, $f(-\infty)=0$. Using the fact that any convex function $f$ has a non-decreasing derivative $f^{\prime}$ almost everywhere, show that

$$
f(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}(x-u)^{+} d f^{\prime}(u)
$$

where $x^{+}=x \vee 0$, and the integral with respect to $d f^{\prime}$ is a Lebesgue-Stieltjes integral (the derivative $f^{\prime}$ can be chosen to be right-continuous).
original.solution:
Solution. For $c>0$ we have

$$
\int_{-c}^{\infty}(x-u)^{+} d f^{\prime}(u)=\int_{-c}^{x}(x-u) d f^{\prime}(u)=\int_{-c}^{x} f^{\prime}(u) d u-(x+c) f^{\prime}(-c)
$$

From the non-negativity of the left-hand side of the last equality, it follows that for $x>-c$ the inequalities hold

$$
0 \leqslant(x+c) f^{\prime}(-c) \leqslant \int_{-c}^{x} f^{\prime}(u) d u=f(x)-f(-c) \leqslant f(x)
$$

where we also applied Lebesgue's theorem, which guarantees for a continuous monotonic function $f$ the validity of the equality

$$
\int_{a}^{b} f^{\prime}(u) d u=f(b)-f(a)
$$

From this, it follows that $f^{\prime}(-c)=o(1), c f^{\prime}(-c)=o(1)$ as $c \rightarrow \infty$. Now it is easy to establish the desired relation.

83. Let $h=h(t, x)$ be a function defined on the set $[a, b] \times \mathbb{R}$, where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$ and $a < b$.

(a) Suppose that

1) for each $x \in \mathbb{R}$, the function $h(t, x), t \in [a, b]$, is continuous;
2) for each $t \in [a, b]$, the function $h(t, x), x \in \mathbb{R}$, is $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$-measurable (i.e., Borel measurable).

Show that then the function $h=h(t, x), t \in [a, b], x \in \mathbb{R}$, is $\mathscr{B}([a, b]) \times \mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$-measurable.

(b) Let now $\xi$ be a random variable defined on some probability space. Show that under conditions 1 and 2 and the condition

3) the family of random variables $\{h(t, \xi), t \in [a, b]\}$ is uniformly integrable, the following properties hold:

(i) the expectation $f(t) = \mathrm{E} h(t, \xi)$ is a continuous function of $t \in [a, b]$
(ii) if $H(t, x) = \int_{a}^{t} h(s, x) \, ds$, then the derivative $\frac{d}{d t} \mathrm{E} H(t, \xi)$ exists for all $t \in (a, b)$ and equals $\mathrm{E} h(t, \xi)$, i.e.,

$$
\frac{d}{d t} \mathrm{E} \int_{a}^{t} h(s, \xi) \, ds = \mathrm{E} h(t, \xi)
$$
original.solution:
Solution. (a) The functions

$$
\begin{aligned}
h_{n}(t, x) & = \\
= & \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} h\left(a+(b-a) \frac{i}{n}, x\right) I_{\left[a+(b-a) \frac{i}{n}, a+(b-a) \frac{i+1}{n}\right]}(t)+h(b, x) I_{\{b\}}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

are $\mathscr{B}([a, b]) \times \mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$-measurable and converge to $h(t, x)$ everywhere as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Therefore, the function $h(t, x)$ is also $\mathscr{B}([a, b]) \times \mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$-measurable.

(b) By condition 2, we have

$$
h(s, \xi) \rightarrow h(t, \xi), \quad s \rightarrow t
$$

everywhere for any $t \in[a, b]$. From this, taking into account condition 3 and Theorem 4 (b) from V1.II. 6, property (i) follows. To prove property (b), it is sufficient to check the uniform integrability of the family

$$
\{g(s, t, \xi): s, t \in[a, b], \quad s \neq t\}
$$

where

$$
g(s, t, \xi)=\frac{H(t, \xi)-H(s, \xi)}{t-s}=\frac{1}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t} h(u, \xi) d u
$$

We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& g(s, t, \xi)= \\
& =\frac{1}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t} h(u, \xi) I(|h(u, \xi)|>c) d u+\frac{1}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t} h(u, \xi) I(|h(u, \xi)| \leqslant c) d u
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\left|\frac{1}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t} h(u, \xi) I(|h(u, \xi)| \leqslant c) d u\right| \leqslant c
$$

Therefore,

$$
|g(s, t, \xi)| \leqslant c+\frac{1}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t}|h(u, \xi)| I(|h(u, \xi)|>c) d u
$$

so by Fubini's theorem,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{E}|g(s, t, \xi)| I(|g(s, t, \xi)|>2 c) \leqslant \\
& \leqslant c \mathrm{P}\left(\frac{1}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t}|h(u, \xi)| I(|h(u, \xi)|>c) d u>c\right)+ \\
& \quad+\mathrm{E} \frac{1}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t}|h(u, \xi)| I(|h(u, \xi)|>c) d u \leqslant \\
& \leqslant \frac{2}{t-s} \int_{s}^{t} \mathrm{E}|h(u, \xi)| I(|h(u, \xi)|>c) d u \leqslant \\
& \leqslant 2 \sup _{u \in[a, b]} \mathrm{E}|h(u, \xi)| I(|h(u, \xi)|>c)
\end{aligned}
$$

The last estimate guarantees the uniform integrability of the family

$$
\{g(s, t, \xi): s, t \in[a, b], \quad s \neq t\}
$$

7. Let $\xi$ and $\zeta$ be independent random variables.

(a) Assuming the existence of the expectation $\mathrm{E} \xi$, show that if the random variables $\xi, \zeta$ are identically distributed, then almost surely (a.s.)

$$
\mathrm{E}(\xi \mid \xi+\zeta)=\mathrm{E}(\zeta \mid \xi+\zeta)=\frac{\xi+\zeta}{2}
$$

(b) Assuming the finiteness of $\mathrm{E} \xi^{2}$ and $\mathrm{E} \zeta^{2}$, show that if $\xi \stackrel{d}{=}-\xi$, then almost surely (a.s.)

$$
\mathrm{E}\left((\xi+\zeta)^{2} \mid \xi^{2}+\zeta^{2}\right)=\xi^{2}+\zeta^{2}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. (a) Note that $(\xi, \zeta) \stackrel{d}{=}(\zeta, \xi)$. Therefore, $(\xi, \xi+\zeta) \stackrel{d}{=}$ $\stackrel{d}{=}(\zeta, \xi+\zeta)$ and $\xi \mathbf{1}_{A} \stackrel{d}{=} \zeta \mathbf{1}_{A}$ for any $A \in \sigma(\xi+\zeta)$. Consequently, $\mathrm{E} \xi \mathbf{1}_{A}=\mathrm{E} \zeta \mathbf{1}_{A}$ and

$$
\mathrm{E}(\xi \mid \xi+\zeta)=\mathrm{E}(\zeta \mid \xi+\zeta)=\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\frac{\xi+\zeta}{2} \right\rvert\, \xi+\zeta\right)=\frac{\xi+\zeta}{2} \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

(b) It is easy to verify that from the independence of $\xi, \zeta$ and the equality $\xi \stackrel{d}{=}-\xi$, it follows that $(\xi, \zeta) \stackrel{d}{=}(-\xi, \zeta)$. Thus,

$$
\left(\xi \zeta, \xi^{2}+\zeta^{2}\right) \stackrel{d}{=}\left(-\xi \zeta, \xi^{2}+\zeta^{2}\right)
$$

therefore

$$
\mathrm{E}\left(\xi \zeta \mid \xi^{2}+\zeta^{2}\right)=\mathrm{E}\left(-\xi \zeta \mid \xi^{2}+\zeta^{2}\right)=0 \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

From this, taking into account the linearity property of conditional expectation, the desired equality follows.

$$

F(y)^{n}, & y \leqslant x\end{cases} \\
f_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(x, y) & =n(n-1)[F(y)-F(x)]^{n-2} f(x) f(y) I(y \geqslant x), \\
F_{R_{n}}(x) & =n I(x \geqslant 0) \int_{\mathbb{R}}[F(y)-F(y-x)]^{n-1} f(y) d y, \\
f_{R_{n}}(x) & =n(n-1) I(x \geqslant 0) \int_{\mathbb{R}}[F(y)-F(y-x)]^{n-2} f(y-x) f(y) d y .
\end{aligned}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Using the independence and identical distribution of random variables $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}$, we find that

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(x, y) & =\mathrm{P}\left(m_{n} \leqslant x, M_{n} \leqslant y\right)= \\
& =\mathrm{P}\left(M_{n} \leqslant y\right)-\mathrm{P}\left(xx \\
F(y)^{n}, & y \leqslant x\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the case where $F$ is a smooth function, the density $f_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(x, y)$ is found using the formula

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(x, y)=\left(F_{m_{n}, M_{n}}\right)_{x y}^{\prime \prime}(x, y) & = \\
= & n(n-1)[F(y)-F(x)]^{n-2} f(x) f(y) I(y>x)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the general case, by computing the Lebesgue integral of the function $f_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(x, y)$ over the set $(-\infty, x] \times(-\infty, y]$, we obtain $F_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(x, y)$, i.e., $f_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(x, y)$ is the density of the random vector $\left(m_{n}, M_{n}\right)$. From this, it follows that the density of the vector $\left(M_{n}-m_{n}, M_{n}\right)$ is $f_{M_{n}-m_{n}, M_{n}}(y-x, y)$ and, therefore, the density of the quantity $R_{n}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{R_{n}}(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f_{m_{n}, M_{n}}(y-x, y) d y & = \\
=n(n-1) I(x & \geqslant 0) \int_{\mathbb{R}}[F(y)-F(y-x)]^{n-2} f(y-x) f(y) d y
\end{aligned}
$$

Having the density $f_{R_{n}}(x)$, it is easy to find the distribution function of $R_{n}$ (equal to 0 for $x<0$):

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{R_{n}}(x) & =\int_{-\infty}^{x} f_{R_{n}}(z) d z= \\
& =\int_{0}^{x} d z \int_{\mathbb{R}} n(n-1)[F(y)-F(y-z)]^{n-2} f(y-z) f(y) d y= \\
& =\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(y) d y \int_{0}^{x} n(n-1)[F(y)-F(y-z)]^{n-2} f(y-z) d z= \\
& =\int_{\mathbb{R}} n f(y) d y \int_{0}^{x}(n-1)[F(y)-F(y-z)]^{n-2} f(y-z) d z= \\
& =n \int_{\mathbb{R}}[F(y)-F(y-x)]^{n-1} f(y) d y,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $x \geqslant 0$.

32. For a random variable $\xi$, having a $\mathscr{N}(0,1)$-distribution,

$$
\mathrm{P}(\xi \geqslant x) \sim \frac{\varphi(x)}{x}, \quad x \rightarrow \infty, \quad \text { where } \varphi(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2}} .
$$

Find the corresponding asymptotic for a random variable $\zeta$, having a gamma-distribution with density

$$
f(x)=\frac{I(x>0)}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \cdot x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}, \quad \alpha>0
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The desired asymptotic is

$$
\mathrm{P}(\zeta \geqslant x)=\frac{1}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \int_{x}^{\infty} z^{\alpha-1} e^{-z} d z \sim f(x)=\frac{x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}}{\Gamma(\alpha)}, \quad x \rightarrow \infty
$$

Indeed, by L'Hôpital's rule

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\int_{x}^{\infty} z^{\alpha-1} e^{-z} d z}{x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} & \frac{\left(\int_{x}^{\infty} z^{\alpha-1} e^{-z} d z\right)^{\prime}}{\left(x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}\right)^{\prime}}= \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}}{-x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}\left[1+(\alpha-1) x^{-1}\right]}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

$$

$$
original.solution:
Solution. Due to the continuity of the variables $X_{i}, 1 \leqslant i \leqslant n$, the probability

$$
\mathrm{P}\left(X_{i}=X_{j} \text { for some } 1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n\right)
$$

is equal to zero. Therefore,

$$
\phi_{n}(\lambda)=\mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda S_{n} / M_{n}}=n e^{-\lambda} \mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda S_{n-1} / X_{n}} I\left(M_{n-1} \leqslant X_{n}\right)
$$

Further, by Fubini's theorem,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{n}(\lambda) & =n e^{-\lambda} \int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda S_{n-1} / x} I\left(M_{n-1} \leqslant x\right) f(x) d x= \\
& =n e^{-\lambda} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda X_{1} / x} I\left(X_{1} \leqslant x\right)\right)^{n-1} f(x) d x= \\
& =n e^{-\lambda} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\int_{0}^{x} e^{-\lambda y / x} f(y) d y\right)^{n-1} f(x) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

61. Let the random variable $X$ be distributed according to the binomial law with parameters $n \in \mathbb{N}$ and $p \in [0,1]$, i.e.,

$$
\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant m)=\sum_{k=0}^{m} C_{n}^{k} p^{k} q^{n-k}, \quad 0 \leqslant k \leqslant n, \quad q=1-p,
$$

Prove that $\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant m)$ can be expressed in terms of the incomplete beta function

$$
\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant m)=\frac{1}{\mathrm{~B}(m+1, n-m)} \int_{p}^{1} x^{m}(1-x)^{n-m-1} d x,
$$

where

$$
\mathrm{B}(a, b)=\int_{0}^{1} x^{a-1}(1-x)^{b-1} d x
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Integrating by parts, we find that

$$
\begin{array}{rl}
\int_{p}^{1} x^{m}(1-x)^{n-m-1} & d x=\frac{p^{m} q^{n-m}}{n-m}+\frac{m}{n-m} \int_{p}^{1} x^{m-1}(1-x)^{n-m} d x= \\
= & \frac{p^{m} q^{n-m}}{n-m}+\frac{m p^{m-1} q^{n-m+1}}{(n-m)(n-m+1)}+ \\
& \quad+\frac{m(m-1)}{(n-m)(n-m+1)} \int_{p}^{1} x^{m-1}(1-x)^{n-m+1} d x=\ldots= \\
= & \sum_{i=0}^{m} \frac{C_{n}^{m-i}}{C_{n}^{m}(n-m)} p^{m-i} q^{n-m-i} .
\end{array}
$$

To complete the proof, note that

$$
\mathrm{B}(m+1, n-m)^{-1}=\frac{\Gamma(n+1)}{\Gamma(m+1) \Gamma(n-m)}=\frac{n!}{m!(n-m-1)!}=C_{n}^{m}(n-m)
$$

**HARD**

56. (See [90].) Let $X$ be a bounded random variable with distribution function $F=F(x)$ and smooth density $f=f(x)$.

(a) Suppose $f(x)$ is non-increasing for $x>0$ and non-decreasing for $x \leqslant 0$, in other words, the variable $X$ is unimodal with mode at $x=0$. Prove that $X \stackrel{d}{=} U Z$, where $U$ and $Z$ are independent random variables, and $U$ has a uniform distribution on $[0,1]$, while the distribution function of the variable $Z$ is given by $G(x)=F(x)-x f(x), x \in \mathbb{R}$.

(b) Establish the converse: if $X \stackrel{d}{=} U Z$, where the variables $U$ and $Z$ are independent, and $U$ has a uniform distribution on $[0,1]$, then the variable $X$ is unimodal with mode at zero.

Remark. These statements are a special case of Khintchine's criterion, in which there are no restrictions on the smoothness of the function $F$ and the boundedness of the variable $X$.
original.solution:
Solution. (a) First, note that $G$ is indeed a distribution function. Indeed, $G(\infty)=1, G(-\infty)=0$ (since $f(x)=0$ outside some interval), and for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, the equality

$$
G^{\prime}(x)=f(x)-x f^{\prime}(x)-f(x)=-x f^{\prime}(x) \geqslant 0
$$

holds due to the unimodality (with mode at $x=0$) of the random variable $X$.

By Fubini's theorem, for any real $x$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{P}(U Z \leqslant x)=\int_{0}^{1} \mathrm{P}(u Z & \leqslant x) d u=\int_{0}^{1} G(x / u) d u= \\
= & \int_{0}^{1}\left[F(x / u)-\frac{x}{u} F^{\prime}(x / u)\right] d u=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d u F(x / u)}{d u} d u=F(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e., $X \stackrel{d}{=} U Z$.

(b) If $X \stackrel{d}{=} U Z$, then the distribution function $G$ of the random variable $Z$ must satisfy the integral equation

$$
\int_{0}^{1} G(x / u) d u=x \int_{x}^{\infty} \frac{G(v)}{v^{2}} d v=F(x)
$$

From this, it follows that $G(x)$ coincides (almost everywhere on $\mathbb{R}$ with respect to Lebesgue measure) with $G_{0}(x)=F(x)-x f(x)$, since $G_{0}$ satisfies this equation. Due to the right-continuity of the functions $G_{0}$ and $G$, they must be equal everywhere. Thus, we have obtained that $G(x)=F(x)-x f(x)$ is a distribution function and, therefore, $G^{\prime}(x)=-x f^{\prime}(x) \geqslant 0$. The last inequality is equivalent to the unimodality of the random variable $X$ with mode at zero.

$$
m(t)=F(t)+\int_{0}^{t} m(t-s) d F(s)
$$

where $F(t)$ is the distribution function of a non-degenerate non-negative random variable $\xi$. Show that in the class of functions bounded on finite intervals, the unique solution to the renewal equation is the function defined by the formula

$$
m(t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} F_{n}(t)
$$

original.solution:
Solution. Iterating the equality $(*)$, we get $m(t)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} F_{i}(t)+R(t)$,

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_fdc8637a08cd99f091cag-422.jpg?height=203&width=1092&top_left_y=1400&top_left_x=140)

Now we will show that the series $\sum_{n \geqslant 1} F_{n}(t)$ converges for all $t \geqslant 0$ (in particular, by establishing that $\left.F_{n}(t) \rightarrow 0\right)$. This will fully prove the statement of the problem.

We have $F_{n}(t)=\mathrm{P}\left(S_{n} \leqslant t\right)$ where $S_{n}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \xi_{i}$, and $\xi_{i}$ are independent copies of the random variable $\xi$. Choose $\delta>0$ such that $\mathrm{P}(\xi>\delta)=p>0$. Let also, for simplicity, $t=k \delta$ for some $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$. Then

$\mathrm{P}\left(S_{n} \leqslant k \delta\right) \leqslant \mathrm{P}\left(\right.$ no more than $k$ of the variables $\xi_{i}$ exceed $\left.\delta\right) \leqslant$

$$
\leqslant(k+1) C_{n}^{k} p^{k}(1-p)^{n-k}
$$

for all sufficiently large $n$. The finiteness of the sum $\sum_{n \geqslant k} C_{n}^{k}(1-p)^{n}$
implies the convergence of the series in question.

$$
f(x ; \alpha, \lambda)=\frac{\lambda^{\alpha}}{\Gamma(\alpha)} x^{\alpha-1} e^{-\lambda x} I(x>0)
$$

where $\alpha, \lambda>0$ and

$$
\Gamma(\alpha)=\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x} d x
$$

Show that

$$
\mathrm{E} X=\frac{\alpha}{\lambda}, \quad \mathrm{D} X=\frac{\alpha}{\lambda^{2}}
$$

and generally for all $p>-\alpha$ the equality holds

$$
\mathrm{E} X^{p}=\frac{1}{\lambda^{p}} \frac{\Gamma(\alpha+p)}{\Gamma(\alpha)}
$$

Also establish that the Laplace transform of the variable $X$ is given by the formula

$$
\mathrm{E} e^{-s X}=\frac{\lambda^{\alpha}}{(\lambda+s)^{\alpha}}, \quad s>0
$$
original.solution:
Solution. If $X$ has a gamma distribution with parameters $(\alpha, \lambda)$, then $\lambda X$ has a gamma distribution with parameters $(\alpha, 1)$. For simplicity, we will assume $\lambda=1$ from now on. We will find $\mathrm{E} X^{p}$:

$$
\mathrm{E} X^{p}=\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{p} \frac{x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}}{\Gamma(\alpha)} d x=\frac{\Gamma(\alpha+p)}{\Gamma(\alpha)}
$$

In particular, due to the equality $\Gamma(s+1)=s \Gamma(s), s>0$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{E} X=\frac{\Gamma(\alpha+1)}{\Gamma(\alpha)}=\alpha, \quad \mathrm{E} X^{2}=\frac{\Gamma(\alpha+2)}{\Gamma(\alpha)}=\alpha(\alpha+1) \\
\mathrm{D} X=\alpha(\alpha+1)-\alpha^{2}=\alpha
\end{gathered}
$$

Now let's compute the Laplace transform of the variable $X$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E} e^{-s X}=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-s x} \frac{x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x}}{\Gamma(\alpha)} d x=\frac{(1+s)^{-\alpha}}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{x}{1+s}\right)^{\alpha-1} e^{-(1+s) x} \frac{d x}{1+s} & = \\
& =(1+s)^{-\alpha} .
\end{aligned}
$$

80. (See [36].) Let the conditions of problem II.8.79 be satisfied.

original.solution:
Solution. (a) According to problem II.11.17, the Laplace transform of a non-negative quantity with a density uniquely determines this density. Therefore, we only need to find non-negative functions $f_{\alpha}=f_{\alpha}(y)$ and $g_{\alpha}=g_{\alpha}(z)$, for which for all $\lambda>0$ the following equalities hold:

$$
\left(\frac{\sqrt{2 \lambda}}{\operatorname{sh} \sqrt{2 \lambda}}\right)^{\alpha}=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\lambda y} f_{\alpha}(y) d y, \quad\left(\frac{1}{\operatorname{ch} \sqrt{2 \lambda}}\right)^{\alpha}=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\lambda z} g_{\alpha}(z) d z
$$

By the Lévy formula for $u>0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\operatorname{ch} u)^{-\alpha}=\frac{2^{\alpha} e^{-\alpha u}}{\left(1+e^{-2 u}\right)^{\alpha}}= & 2^{\alpha} \sum_{n \geqslant 0} C_{-\alpha}^{n} e^{-(2 n+\alpha) u}= \\
& =2^{\alpha} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\frac{u^{2} z}{2}} \sum_{n \geqslant 0} C_{-\alpha}^{n} \frac{2 n+\alpha}{\sqrt{2 \pi z^{3}}} e^{-\frac{(2 n+\alpha)^{2}}{2 z}} d z
\end{aligned}
$$

where the penultimate equality follows from the binomial formula for fractional powers $a$:

$$
(1+x)^{a}=\sum_{n \geqslant 0} C_{a}^{n} x^{n} \quad \text { for }|x|<1, \quad C_{a}^{n}=\frac{a(a-1) \ldots(a-n+1)}{n!}, \quad C_{a}^{0}=1
$$

Substituting $u=\sqrt{2 \lambda}$, we find that

$$
g_{\alpha}(z)=2^{\alpha} \sum_{n \geqslant 0} C_{-\alpha}^{n} \frac{2 n+\alpha}{\sqrt{2 \pi z^{3}}} e^{-\frac{(2 n+\alpha)^{2}}{2 z}}
$$

Similarly, we obtain

$$
(u / \operatorname{sh} u)^{\alpha}=2^{\alpha} \int_{0}^{\infty} u^{\alpha} e^{-\frac{u^{2} y}{2}} h_{\alpha}(y) d y
$$

where

$$
h_{\alpha}(y)=\sum_{n \geqslant 0} C_{-\alpha}^{n}(-1)^{n} \frac{2 n+\alpha}{\sqrt{2 \pi y^{3}}} e^{-\frac{(2 n+\alpha)^{2}}{2 y}}, \quad y>0
$$

To compute $f_{\alpha}$, we can do the following. First, write $\alpha=2 n-2 a, n \in \mathbb{N},-10
$$

we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\infty}\left(u^{2} / 2\right)^{-a} e^{-\frac{u^{2} y}{2}} h_{\alpha}^{(n)}(y) d y=\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{h_{\alpha}^{(n)}(y) d y}{\Gamma(a)} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\frac{u^{2}(x+y)}{2}} x^{a-1} d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{h_{\alpha}^{(n)}(y) d y}{\Gamma(a)} \int_{y}^{\infty} e^{-\frac{u^{2} z}{2}}(z-y)^{a-1} d z=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\frac{u^{2} z}{2}} d z \int_{0}^{z}(z-y)^{a-1} \frac{h_{\alpha}^{(n)}(y) d y}{\Gamma(a)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, as before, setting $u=\sqrt{2 \lambda}$, we find

$$
f_{\alpha}(z)=\frac{2^{3 \alpha / 2}}{\Gamma(a)} \int_{0}^{z}(z-y)^{a-1} h_{\alpha}^{(n)}(y) d y
$$

(b) The distribution function $F(y)=\mathrm{P}\left(Y_{2} \leqslant y\right)$ satisfies the equality

$$

$$

In other words,

$$
\frac{2}{(\operatorname{sh} \sqrt{2 \lambda})^{2}}=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\lambda y} F(y) d y
$$

Again applying the same reasoning as in part (a), we conclude that

$$
F(y)=4 h_{2}(y)=\frac{8 \sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{\pi y^{3}}} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} k^{2} e^{-\frac{2 k^{2}}{y}}, \quad y>0
$$

where we also take into account that $(-1)^{n} C_{-2}^{n}=n+1, n \geqslant 0$.

Remark. Using the identity for the Jacobi theta function (see problem II.12.2), the distribution function of the quantity $Y_{2}$ can also be represented as

$$
F(y)=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}\left(1-n^{2} \pi^{2} y\right) e^{-\frac{\pi^{2} k^{2} y}{2}}

Indeed, since $\sqrt{t} \theta(t)=\theta\left(t^{-1}\right), t>0$, where $\theta(t)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-n^{2} \pi t}$, we get

or, equivalently,

$$

from which the desired representation follows (if we take $y=\pi t / 2$).

original.problem: 4. Prove that the space $L^{\infty}$ is complete.

$$
\xi=\varlimsup_{n} \xi_{n} \cdot I\left(\varlimsup_{n} \xi_{n}<\infty\right)
$$

The $\xi$ defined in this way is a random variable, and for it, $\lim _{n}\left\|\xi-\xi_{n}\right\|_{\infty}=$ $=0$. The last equality can be derived, for example, from the fact that the measure of all such $\omega \in \Omega$ for which $\left|\xi_{n}(\omega)-\xi_{m}(\omega)\right| \leqslant\left\|\xi_{n}-\xi_{m}\right\|_{\infty}$ for all $n, m \geqslant 1$ is equal to one.

34. The statement of Egorov's theorem makes it natural to introduce the following concept. A sequence of measurable functions $\left\{f_{n}\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ on a space $(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mu)$ with finite measure $\mu$ is said to converge almost uniformly to a function $f$ if for every $\varepsilon>0$ there exists a set $A_{\varepsilon} \in \mathscr{F}$ with $\mu\left(A_{\varepsilon}\right)<\varepsilon$ such that $f_{n}(\omega) \rightarrow f(\omega)$ uniformly for all $\omega \in \bar{A}_{\varepsilon}$ (notation: $f_{n} \rightrightarrows f$).

Show that from the almost uniform convergence $f_{n} \rightrightarrows f$ it follows that the convergence in measure $f_{n} \xrightarrow{\mu} f$ and the convergence almost everywhere $f_{n} \xrightarrow{\mu \text {-a.e. }} f$ also hold.
original.solution:
Solution. Due to the finiteness of $\mu$, from the $\mu$-a.s. convergence follows the convergence in measure. Therefore, it is sufficient to prove that

$$
f_{n} \rightrightarrows f \Rightarrow f_{n} \xrightarrow{\mu-\text{a.s.}} f
$$

Thus, assume that $f_{n} \rightrightarrows f$. By definition, on the set $\bigcup_{\varepsilon>0} \bar{A}_{\varepsilon}$, the convergence $f_{n}(\omega) \rightarrow f(\omega)$ holds. It remains to note that

$$
\mu\left(\Omega \backslash \bigcup_{\varepsilon>0} \bar{A}_{\varepsilon}\right)=\mu\left(\bigcap_{\varepsilon>0} A_{\varepsilon}\right) \leqslant \lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \mu\left(A_{\varepsilon}\right)=0
$$

original.problem: 43. ([64]) Show that in the space $C[0,1]$ of continuous functions on the interval $[0,1]$, there does not exist a metric $\rho$ such that the convergence $\rho\left(f_{n}, f\right) \rightarrow 0$ is equivalent to the pointwise convergence of $f_{n}$ to $f$. (Compare with problem II.10.16.)
original.solution:
Solution. We will need a certain set of functions $\{f_{nm}\}_{m, n \geqslant 1}$ continuous on $[0,1]$, for the construction of which it will be necessary to introduce several auxiliary constructions.

We call

$$
\left\{\left[x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right): x_{0}=a, x_{n}=\frac{x_{n-1}+b}{2}, n \geqslant 1\right\}
$$

a normal partition of the half-interval $[a, b), am\end{cases}
$$

The functions $f_{nm}$ defined in this way converge pointwise to $0$ as $m \rightarrow \infty$.

Suppose that the metric $\rho$ specified in the condition exists. Then necessarily $\rho(f_{nm}, 0) \rightarrow 0$ as $m \rightarrow \infty$. Therefore, there exist indices $\{m_n^*\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ such that $\rho(f_{nm}, 0) < \frac{1}{n}$ for all $m > m_n^*$. Thus, for any sequence $(m_n)$ such that $m_n > m_n^*$, the pointwise convergence of $f_{n m_n}$ to zero holds.

Let $I_1$ be some half-interval from $P_1$. Choose some $m_1$ such that $m_1 > l(I_1) + m_1^*$. Then $f_{1 m_1} = 1$ on the closure of $I_2^c$ for some half-interval $I_2 \in P_2, I_2 \subseteq I_1$. Now choose $m_2$ such that $m_2 > l(I_2) + m_2^*$. Then $f_{2 m_2} = 1$ on $I_3^c$ for some $I_3 \in P_3, I_3 \subseteq I_2$. Continuing this procedure indefinitely, we obtain a nested sequence of non-empty intervals ($I_n^c$) and a sequence of functions $(f_{n m_n})$ such that $m_n > m_n^*$ and $f_{n m_n} = 1$ on $I_{n+1}^c (n \geqslant 1)$. But this will mean that

$$
f_{n m_n}(x) \rightarrow 1 \neq 0, \quad x \in \bigcap_{n \geqslant 1} I_n^c (\neq \varnothing)
$$

i.e., the functions $f_{n m_n}$ do not converge pointwise to zero. The contradiction obtained proves the non-existence of the metric $\rho$.

**HARD**

37. Let the function $f=f(x), x \in \mathbb{R}$, be such that $\int_{0}^{\infty}|f(x)|^{p} d x < \infty$. Prove that the following continuity property in $L^{p}$ holds:

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}|f(x+h)-f(x)|^{p} d x \rightarrow 0, \quad h \rightarrow 0
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Fix an arbitrary $\varepsilon>0$, for which we will choose $a>0$ such that

$$
\int_{|x|>a}|f(x)|^{p} d x<\varepsilon, \quad \int_{|x|>a}|g(x)|^{p} d x<\varepsilon
$$

where $g(x)$ is a continuous function on $\mathbb{R}$, and $c_{p}$ is a constant depending only on $p$. For any $b>0$, we have

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|f(x)-f_{b}(x)\right|^{p} d x<\varepsilon
$$

where $f_{b}(x)$ is a function that approximates $f(x)$ on $[-b, b]$. For any $h \in \mathbb{R}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}}|f(x+h)-f(x)|^{p} d x \leqslant \int_{|x|>2 a}|f(x+h)-f(x)|^{p} d x+\int_{-2 a}^{2 a}|f(x+h)-f(x)|^{p} d x \leqslant \\
& \leqslant 2 c_{p} \varepsilon+4 c_{p} b \cdot \frac{\varepsilon}{b}+\int_{-2 a}^{2 a}|g(x+h)-g(x)|^{p} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

The continuous function $g=g(x)$ on $[-3 a, 3 a]$ is uniformly continuous on this interval, so for sufficiently small $h$ we have

$$
\int_{-2 a}^{2 a}|g(x+h)-g(x)|^{p} d x \leqslant \varepsilon
$$

Thus, for sufficiently small $h$ we have

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}|f(x+h)-f(x)|^{p} d x \leqslant\left(6 c_{p}+1\right) \varepsilon
$$

By the arbitrariness of $\varepsilon>0$, the desired relation follows.

The problem presented requires proving a specific continuity property in \( L^{p} \) space for a function \( f \) under a bounded integral condition. The solution involves demonstrating that a limit holds true as \( h \) approaches 0, which requires applying concepts related to norms, continuity, and properties of integrals.

Since the problem asks to prove a mathematical property (specifically, the continuity property in \( L^{p} \)), this indicates it falls into a category where the solution involves more than mere computation; it requires logical reasoning and proof techniques.

Thus, I classify this problem as:

HARD: The solution requires proving a property of function \( f(x) \) in the \( L^{p} \) space, involving limits and continuity, not just executing a computation.

17. Let $f=f(x)$ be a Borel function defined on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$ such that

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} e^{-\lambda x} f(x) d x=0 \quad \text { for all } \lambda \in \mathbb{N} \text {. }
$$

Show that $f=0$ a.e. with respect to Lebesgue measure.
original.solution:
Solution. Let's make a change of variables

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} e^{-\lambda x} f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{1} z^{\lambda-1} g(z) d z, \quad g(z)=f(-\ln z) .
$$

The function $g(z)$ is orthogonal on the interval $[0,1]$ to all polynomials. Polynomials form a dense set in the space $C[0,1]$, which in turn forms a dense set in

$$
L^{2}([0,1], \mathscr{B}([0,1]), \mu)
$$

where $\mu$ is the Lebesgue measure. From this, we conclude that $g=0$, and therefore, $f=0$ almost everywhere with respect to the Lebesgue measure.

1. Let $X$ be a random variable such that $\mathrm{E} e^{s X}<\infty, s \in \mathbb{R}$ and

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathrm{E} e^{(s+i t) X}\right| d t<\infty, \quad s, t \in \mathbb{R}
$$

The latter for $s=0$ guarantees the existence of a density $f=f(x)$ for $X$. Under these conditions, suggest some method for obtaining upper bounds for $f$ on $\mathbb{R}$.
original.solution:
Solution. The finiteness of $\mathrm{E} e^{s X}$ is equivalent to the fact that the function $e^{s x} f(x)$ defines the density of some finite measure on $\mathbb{R}$, corresponding to the characteristic function $\mathrm{E} e^{(s+i t) X}$. Therefore, by the inversion formula,

$$
e^{s x} f(x)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i x t} \mathrm{E} e^{(s+i t) X} d t
$$

Consequently,

$$
f(x) \leqslant \inf _{s} \frac{e^{-s x}}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\mathrm{E} e^{(s+i t) X}\right| d t
$$

Remark. Using the proposed upper bound for $f=f(x)$, in the work [89] (see also [27]), a very accurate estimate of the density $f=f(x)$ of the random harmonic series $X=\sum \pm \frac{1}{n}$ (the signs + and - are chosen with equal probability and independently for different $n$) was obtained, of the form

$$
\lim _{|x| \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\ln f(x)}{e^{|x|}}=-\frac{e^{2 \gamma} \pi}{4}
$$

where $\gamma=\lim \left[1+\frac{1}{2}+\ldots+\frac{1}{n}-\ln n\right]$ is the Euler constant. From this, it can be deduced that when the signs are randomly placed before the terms of the harmonic series, it is practically impossible to obtain a large number.

6. Let $X=\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right)$ and $\mathrm{E}\|X\|^{n}<\infty$, where $\|X\|=\sqrt{\sum X_{i}^{2}}$. Show that

$$
\varphi(t)=\mathrm{E} e^{i(t, X)}=\sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{i^{k} \mathrm{E}(t, X)^{k}}{k!}+o(1) \cdot\|t\|^{n}, \quad\|t\| \rightarrow 0
$$

where $t \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$.
original.solution:
Solution. By expanding $\cos x$ and $\sin x$ into a sum of powers of $x$ with the remainder term in the form of Taylor, one can obtain various upper bounds for the modulus of the difference

$$
\left|e^{i x}-\sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{i^{k} x^{k}}{k!}\right|
$$

valid for any real $x$. For example, estimate it by $3|x|^{n+1}, 3|x|^{n}$, and thus $3|x|^{n} \cdot|x| \wedge 1$. But then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\varphi(t)-\sum_{k=0}^{n} \frac{i^{k} \mathrm{E}(t, X)^{k}}{k!}\right| \leqslant 3 \mathrm{E}\left[|(t, X)|^{n} \cdot|(t, X)|\right. & \wedge 1] \leqslant \\
& \leqslant 3\|t\|^{n} \mathrm{E}\left[\|X\|^{n} \cdot|(t, X)| \wedge 1\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

It remains to note that $\mathrm{E}\left[\|X\|^{n} \cdot|(t, X)| \wedge 1\right] \rightarrow 0$ as $\|t\| \rightarrow 0$ by the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem.

35. Prove Lusin's theorem.

Any $\overline{\mathscr{B}}[a, b]$-measurable function $f=f(x)$ on $[a, b]$ can be made continuous by removing suitable open intervals from $[a, b]$ with arbitrarily small total length.

From this, deduce that for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists a continuous function $f_{\varepsilon}=f_{\varepsilon}(x)$ such that

$$
\lambda\left(x \in[a, b]: f(x) \neq f_{\varepsilon}(x)\right)<\varepsilon
$$

where $\lambda$ is the Lebesgue measure. Moreover, it can be guaranteed that

$$
\sup _{x \in[a, b]}\left|f_{\varepsilon}(x)\right| \leqslant \sup _{x \in[a, b]}|f(x)| \text {. }
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Consider step functions

$$
f_{n}(x)=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} k 2^{-n} I\left([k-1] 2^{-n} \leqslant f(x) < k 2^{-n}\right)
$$

where $I$ is the indicator function. Due to problem II.3.32, we can find closed sets

$$
F_{n k} \subseteq\left\{x: f_{n}(x)=k 2^{-n}\right\}
$$

and $K_{n} \geqslant 1$, such that $\lambda\left(\bigcup_{k=-K_{n}}^{K_{n}} F_{n k}\right)>b-a-\varepsilon 2^{-n}$. Since $F_{n k}$ do not intersect over $k$ and the function $f_{n}$ is constant on each $F_{n k}$, it is continuous on $F_{n}=\bigcup_{k=-K_{n}}^{K_{n}} F_{n k}$, which is also closed. Therefore, $f_{n}$ is continuous on the intersection $F=\bigcap_{n} F_{n}$, which is also closed.

Furthermore, $f_{n} \rightarrow f$ uniformly on $F$, so the function $f$ must be continuous on $F$. The complement of $F$ is open and, therefore, can be represented as a union of non-intersecting intervals $\bigcup_{n}\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right)$. Their total length is

$$
b-a-\lambda(F) \leqslant \sum_{n \geqslant 1} \varepsilon 2^{-n}=\varepsilon
$$

The second statement follows directly from the first. Specifically, for any $\varepsilon>0$, the function $f=f(x)$ is continuous on the set $[a, b] \backslash \bigcup_{n}\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right)$, where $\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right) \subset[a, b]$ are non-intersecting intervals, and $\sum_{n}\left[b_{n}-a_{n}\right]<\varepsilon$. Thus, $f_{\varepsilon}$ can be defined by the formula

$$
f_{\varepsilon}(x)= \begin{cases}f(x), & x \notin \bigcup_{n}\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right) \\ f\left(a_{n}\right)+\frac{f\left(b_{n}\right)-f\left(a_{n}\right)}{b_{n}-a_{n}}\left(x-a_{n}\right), & x \in\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right)\end{cases}
$$

If $|f(x)| \leqslant c$ on $[a, b]$, then the same statement holds for $f_{\varepsilon}$.

Remark. With minor modifications, the proof of the theorem remains valid for measurable functions $f=f(x)$ defined on some bounded open domain in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$.

Remark. Following the ideas of Borel and Han, using Lusin's theorem, one can give another, equivalent definition of a measurable function on $(a, b)$ and construct the Lebesgue integral. Specifically, a function $f=f(x)$ is called measurable on $(a, b)$ if it can be made continuous by removing suitable open intervals from $(a, b)$ of arbitrarily small total length.

We then define the Lebesgue integral $\int_{F} f(x) d x$ first over a closed set $F$ for functions $f$ that are continuous on $F$. In the general case, the integral is defined by the limit transition $\lim _{n} \int_{F_{n}} f(x) d x$, where the total length of the complement of $F_{n}(\subset(a, b))$ tends to zero.

for all $\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n}\right),\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, where $t=\left(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{n}\right)$.

15. Let $\xi$ be an integer-valued random variable and $\varphi_{\xi}(t)$ its characteristic function. Show that

$$
\mathrm{P}(\xi=n)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} e^{-i n t} \varphi_{\xi}(t) d t, \quad k \in \mathbb{Z}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. By Fubini's theorem

$$
\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} e^{-i n t} \varphi_{\xi}(t) d t=\mathrm{E} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} e^{i(\xi-n) t} d t=2 \pi \mathrm{P}(\xi=n)
$$

55. As proven in B1.I.5.5, the Bernstein polynomials

$$
B_{n}(x, f)=\sum_{k=0}^{n} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right) C_{n}^{k} x^{k}(1-x)^{n-k}
$$

provide a uniform approximation of a continuous function $f=f(x)$ on the interval $[0,1]$. If we consider not an interval but the half-line $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, then the Szász-Mirakyan series

$$
S_{n}(x, f)=e^{-n x} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right) \frac{(n x)^{k}}{k!}
$$

possess a similar property. Specifically, if the function $f=f(x)$ is continuous and bounded on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, then

$$
S_{n}(x, f) \rightarrow f(x), \quad n \rightarrow \infty
$$

uniformly on any finite interval $[a, b] \subset \mathbb{R}_{+}$. Establish this result.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots$ be independent Poisson random variables with parameter $x \geqslant 0$. Then $Z_{n}=X_{1}+\ldots+X_{n}(n \geqslant 1)$ is a Poisson random variable with parameter $n x$. Consequently,

$$
S_{n}(x, f)=e^{-n x} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} f\left(\frac{k}{n}\right) \frac{(n x)^{k}}{k!}=\mathrm{E} f\left(\frac{Z_{n}}{n}\right)
$$

On any finite interval $[a, b]$, a continuous function $f=f(x)$ is uniformly continuous, so for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists $\delta=\delta(\varepsilon)>0$ such that $\delta(\varepsilon) \rightarrow 0$ as $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0+$ and

$$
|f(x)-f(y)| \leqslant \delta(\varepsilon), \quad|x-y| \leqslant \varepsilon
$$

For simplicity, assuming that the function $f$ is bounded by one, for $a \leqslant x \leqslant b$ we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mid S_{n}(x, f) & \left.-f(x)|\leqslant| \mathrm{E} f\left(\frac{Z_{n}}{n}\right)-f(x) \right\rvert\, \leqslant \\
& \leqslant \mathrm{E}\left|f\left(\frac{Z_{n}}{n}\right)-f(x)\right| I\left(\left|\frac{Z_{n}}{n}-x\right| \leqslant \varepsilon\right)+2 \mathrm{P}\left(\left|\frac{Z_{n}}{n}-x\right|>\varepsilon\right) \leqslant \\
& \leqslant \delta(\varepsilon)+2 \mathrm{P}\left(\left|\frac{Z_{n}}{n}-x\right|>\varepsilon\right) \leqslant \delta(\varepsilon)+\frac{2 \mathrm{E}\left|Z_{n}-n x\right|^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2} n^{2}}= \\
& =\delta(\varepsilon)+\frac{2 \mathrm{D} Z_{n}}{\varepsilon^{2} n^{2}}=\delta(\varepsilon)+\frac{2 x}{\varepsilon^{2} n} \leqslant \delta(\varepsilon)+\frac{2|a|+2|b|}{\varepsilon^{2} n}
\end{aligned}
$$

From this, it is easy to deduce the uniform convergence of $S_{n}(x, f)$ to $f(x)$ on $[a, b]$ (for any interval $[a, b]$).

Remark. In general, one cannot guarantee the uniform convergence of $S_{n}(x, f)$ to $f(x)$ on the entire half-line $\mathbb{R}_{+}$ (if $f(x)$ does not have a limit as $x \rightarrow \infty$). Let us verify this with the following example. Take any even periodic function $f=f(x)$ on $\mathbb{R}$ with period one. For example, let $f(x)=\cos (2 \pi x)$.

Let $Y_{n}$ be a Poisson random variable with parameter $n^{2}(n \geqslant 1)$. Then, as proven above (taking into account the periodicity of $f$),

$$
\left|S_{n}(n, f)-f(n)\right|=\left|\mathrm{E} f\left(\frac{Y_{n}}{n}\right)-f(n)\right|=\left|\mathrm{E} f\left(\frac{Y_{n}-n^{2}}{n}\right)-1\right|
$$

According to the central limit theorem (see Theorem 3 from V1.III.3),

$$
\frac{Y_{n}-n^{2}}{n}=\frac{Y_{n}-E Y_{n}}{\sqrt{D Y_{n}}} \xrightarrow{d} \xi \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1),
$$

so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|S_{n}(n, f)-f(n)\right|=1-\mathrm{E} f\left(\frac{Y_{n}-n^{2}}{n}\right) & \rightarrow \\
\rightarrow 1-\mathrm{E} f(\xi) & =1-\mathrm{E} \cos (2 \pi \xi)=1-e^{-2 \pi^{2}}>0
\end{aligned}
$$

## § 11. Hilbert Space of Random Variables with Finite Second Moment

original.problem:
7. Let $\mu$ and $\nu$ be two probability measures on ( $\mathbb{R}^{n}, \mathscr{B}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ ), such that

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} e^{i(t, x)} d \mu=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} e^{i(t, x)} d \nu
$$

for all $t \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$. Prove that $\mu=\nu$.
original.solution:
Solution. Measures $\mu$ and $\nu$ on $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$ are defined by their values on "rectangles" of the form $\left(a_{1}, b_{1}\right] \times \ldots \times\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right]$. Therefore, it is sufficient to prove the equality $\mu=\nu$ only on these sets.

Notice now that the measure of any "rectangle" $\left(a_{1}, b_{1}\right] \times \ldots \times\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right]$ can be obtained as the limit of integrals of bounded continuous functions of the form

$$
f_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\prod_{j=1}^{n} \varphi_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{j}, a_{i}, b_{j}\right)
$$

as $\varepsilon \downarrow 0$, where $\varphi_{\varepsilon}(x, a, b)$ is zero for $x < a$ and $x > b + \varepsilon$, one for $x \in [a + \varepsilon, b]$, and linear on the remaining intervals.

We will use the following fundamental result (which follows from the Stone-Weierstrass theorem): any continuous function $f=f(x)$ on the interval $[-\pi K, \pi K]$ can be uniformly approximated on this interval by linear combinations of trigonometric exponentials of the form $e^{i k x / \kappa}, k=1,2, \ldots$ Thus, for each $1 \leqslant j \leqslant n$, the inequality

$$
\sup _{\left|x_{j}\right| \leqslant \pi K}\left|\varphi_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{j}, a_{j}, b_{j}\right)-L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right)\right| \leqslant \varepsilon
$$

holds, where $L_{j}\left(x_{i}, \varepsilon\right)$ is the specified linear combination of exponentials. Considering the expansion

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \prod_{j=1}^{n} \varphi_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{j}, a_{j}, b_{j}\right)-L_{1}\left(x_{1}, \varepsilon\right) \prod_{j=2}^{n} \varphi_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{j}, a_{j}, b_{j}\right)+ \\
& +L_{1}\left(x_{1}, \varepsilon\right) \prod_{j=2}^{n} \varphi_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{j}, a_{j}, b_{j}\right)-\ldots-\prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and noting that the function $\varphi_{\varepsilon}$ is bounded by one and, therefore, $L_{j}$ is bounded by $1+\varepsilon$, we obtain that on $[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}$ the inequality

$$
\left|f_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)-\prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right)\right| \leqslant n(1+\varepsilon)^{n} \varepsilon
$$

holds. By the problem's condition,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right) d \mu=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right) d \nu
$$

The function $\prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right)$ is bounded on $[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}$ (by $(1+\varepsilon)^{n}$) and is periodic on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ in each $x_{j}$ (with period $2 \pi K$), hence it is bounded on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$.

Thus, combining the obtained estimates, we conclude that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} f_{\varepsilon} d \mu-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} f_{\varepsilon} d \nu\right| \leqslant\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} f_{\varepsilon} d \mu-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right) d \mu\right|+ \\
& +\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} f_{\varepsilon} d \nu-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right) d \nu\right| \leqslant \\
& \leqslant 2 n(1+\varepsilon)^{n} \varepsilon+\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}}\left|f_{\varepsilon}-\prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right)\right| d \mu+ \\
& +\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}}\left|f_{\varepsilon}-\prod_{j=1}^{n} L_{j}\left(x_{j}, \varepsilon\right)\right| d \nu \leqslant \\
& \leqslant 2 n(1+\varepsilon)^{n} \varepsilon+2(1+\varepsilon)^{n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}} d \mu+2(1+\varepsilon)^{n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}} d \nu .
\end{aligned}
$$

By choosing a sufficiently large $K$, we can ensure that

$$
\mu\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}\right)+\nu\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash[-\pi K, \pi K]^{n}\right) \leqslant \varepsilon
$$

and, therefore,

$$
\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} f_{\varepsilon} d \mu-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} f_{\varepsilon} d \nu\right| \leqslant(2 n+4)(1+\varepsilon)^{n} \varepsilon .
$$

Taking the limit as $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$, we obtain the equality $\mu(\Pi)=\nu(\Pi)$ for any fixed "rectangle" $\Pi=\left(a_{1}, b_{1}\right] \times \ldots \times\left(a_{n}, b_{n}\right]$, from which it follows that $\mu=\nu$.

19. (Hinchin's Criterion.) Show that the characteristic function $\varphi=\varphi(t)$ of any absolutely continuous distribution with density $f=f(x)$ can be represented in the form

$$
\varphi(t)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} \phi(t+s) \overline{\phi(s)} d s, \quad t \in \mathbb{R}
$$

for some complex-valued function $\phi$ satisfying the condition $\int_{\mathbb{R}}|\phi(s)|^{2} d s=1$. Assume for simplicity that

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}} \sqrt{f(x)} d x<\infty, \quad \int_{\mathbb{R}} d t\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{i t x} \sqrt{f(x)} d x\right|<\infty
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let

$$
\phi(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{i t x} \sqrt{f(x)} d x
$$

By the inversion formula (for finite measures with density $g(x)=\sqrt{f(x)}, x \in \mathbb{R})$, and the Fubini's theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{i t x} d t \int_{\mathbb{R}} \phi(t+s) \overline{\phi(s)} d s= & \\
=2 \pi \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} \overline{e^{-i s x} \phi(s)} d s & \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i(t+s) x} \phi(t+s) d t= \\
& =2 \pi \sqrt{f(x) /(2 \pi)} \cdot \sqrt{f(x) /(2 \pi)}=f(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

from which the statement of the problem follows.

original.solution:
Solution. If $\varphi(t)=\sqrt{1-t^{2}} \cdot I(|t| \leqslant 1)=\mathrm{E} e^{i t \xi}$ is the characteristic function for some random variable $\xi$, then $\xi$ has a second moment $\mathrm{E} \xi^{2}=-\varphi^{\prime \prime}(0)$. This implies that the function $\varphi(t)$ is differentiable for any $t \in \mathbb{R}$. However, this is not the case (for example, at $t=1$), so the given function is not a characteristic function.

The function $\varphi(t)=\frac{\sin t}{t}$ is the characteristic function of a random variable that has a uniform distribution on $[-1,1]$.

27. Let $X$ and $Y$ be independent random variables with characteristic functions $\varphi=\varphi(t)$ and $\psi=\psi(t)$ and distribution functions $F=F(x)$ and $G=G(x)$. For functions $f=f(t)$ and $g=g(t)$ with values in $\mathbb{C}$, denote by $M(f, g)$ the limit (as $T \rightarrow \infty$) of the integrals

$$
\frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T} f(t) \overline{g(t)} d t
$$

when it exists. Show that

$$
\begin{gathered}
M\left(\varphi, e^{i t x}\right)=\lim _{T} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T} e^{-i t x} \varphi(t) d t=F(x)-F(x-), \quad x \in \mathbb{R} \\
M(\varphi, \psi)=\sum_{-\infty<x<\infty}[F(x)-F(x-)][G(x)-G(x-)]
\end{gathered}
$$

In particular,

$$
M(\varphi, \varphi)=\sum_{-\infty<x<\infty}[F(x)-F(x-)]^{2}
$$

and the distribution function $F=F(x)$ is continuous if and only if $M(\varphi, \varphi)=0$.
original.solution:
Solution. By Fubini's theorem

$$
M\left(\varphi, e^{i t x}\right)=\frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T} e^{-i t x} \varphi(t) d t=\mathrm{E} \frac{1}{2 T} \int_{-T}^{T} e^{i t(X-x)} d t=\mathrm{E} \frac{\sin T(X-x)}{T(X-x)}
$$

The last expression, by the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem, tends to

$$
\mathrm{P}(X-x=0)=F(x)-F(x-)
$$

as $T \rightarrow \infty$. Further, since $\varphi(t) \overline{\psi(t)}=\mathrm{E} e^{i t(X-Y)}$, by the proven result (see also problem II.8.57), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
M(\varphi, \psi)=M(\varphi \bar{\psi}, 1)=\mathrm{P} & (X-Y=0)= \\

16. Show that in the space

$$
L^{2}=L^{2}([-\pi, \pi], \mathscr{B}([-\pi, \pi]))
$$

with the Lebesgue measure, the system of functions $\left\{\frac{e^{i \lambda n}}{\sqrt{2 \pi}}, n \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$ forms an orthonormal basis.
original.solution:
Solution. The proof can be carried out according to the following scheme:

(a) for $\varepsilon>0$, find some $c>0$ such that

$$
\|\varphi-f\|_{L^{2}}<\varepsilon, \quad f(x)=\varphi(x) I(|\varphi(x)| \leqslant c)
$$

(b) by the Lusin's theorem (see problem II.10.35), find a continuous function $f_{\varepsilon}(x)$ such that $|f_{\varepsilon}(x)| \leqslant c$ and

$$
\mu\left\{x \in[-\pi, \pi]: f_{\varepsilon}(x) \neq f(x)\right\}<\varepsilon
$$

then $\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}} \leqslant 2 c \sqrt{\varepsilon}$

(c) find a continuous function $g_{\varepsilon}(x)$ such that $g_{\varepsilon}(-\pi)=g_{\varepsilon}(\pi)$ and $\left\|g_{\varepsilon}-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}} \leqslant \varepsilon ;$

(d) by the Weierstrass theorem, find a function

$$
h_{\varepsilon}(x)=\sum_{k=-n}^{n} a_{k} e^{i k x}
$$

such that

$$
\sup _{x \in[-\pi, \pi]}\left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-h_{\varepsilon}(x)\right| \leqslant \varepsilon
$$

and, therefore, $\left\|g_{\varepsilon}-h_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{2}} \leqslant \varepsilon$.

From (a)-(d), it follows that finite sums of the form $\sum_{k=-n}^{n} a_{k} e^{i k x}$ form a dense set in $L^{2}$, i.e., the system $\left\{\frac{e^{i \lambda n}}{\sqrt{2 \pi}}, n \in \mathbb{Z}\right\}$ forms an (orthonormal) basis.

for each $t \in \mathbb{R}$.

\mathrm{E} e^{-\frac{(X-t)^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}}}=\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t y} e^{-\frac{\sigma^{2} y^{2}}{2}} \varphi(y) d y

39. Let $X$ be a random variable with characteristic function $\varphi=\varphi(t)$ such that $\int_{\mathbb{R}}|\varphi(t)| d t<\infty$. Using the fact that $\psi(t)=(1-|t|)^{+}$ is the characteristic function of a distribution with density

$$
g(x)=\frac{1-\cos x}{\pi x^{2}}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R}
$$

prove that $X$ has a bounded continuous density given by the formula

$$
f(x)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t x} \varphi(t) d t, \quad x \in \mathbb{R}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let $Y$ be a random variable independent of $X$ and having density $g(x)$. Then the density $f_{\sigma}=f_{\sigma}(x)$ of the variable $X+\sigma Y (\sigma>0)$ is

$$
f_{\sigma}(x)=\mathrm{E} \frac{1}{\sigma} g\left(\frac{x-X}{\sigma}\right), \quad x \in \mathbb{R}
$$

Obviously, $X+\sigma Y \xrightarrow{d} X, \sigma \rightarrow 0$, and thus,

$$
\int_{a}^{b} \mathrm{E} \frac{1}{\sigma} g\left(\frac{x-X}{\sigma}\right) d x \rightarrow \mathrm{P}(a<X \leqslant b)
$$

for all continuity points $a<b$ of the distribution function of $X$. By direct calculation (using Fubini's theorem), we obtain that for each $x \in \mathbb{R}$ the equality holds

$$
\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t x} \varphi_{\sigma}(t) d t=\mathrm{E} \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\sigma|t| \leqslant 1} e^{i t(X-x)}(1-\sigma|t|) d t=\mathrm{E} \frac{1}{\sigma} g\left(\frac{x-X}{\sigma}\right)
$$

where $\varphi_{\sigma}(t)=(1-\sigma|t|)^{+} \varphi(t)$ is the characteristic function of the variable $X+\sigma Y$. Note now that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$ the condition

$$
\int_{\sigma|t| \leqslant 1} e^{-i t x}(1-\sigma|t|) \varphi(t) d t \rightarrow \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t x} \varphi(t) d t
$$

holds, and

$$
\left|\int_{\sigma|t| \leqslant 1} e^{-i t x}(1-\sigma|t|) \varphi(t) d t\right| \leqslant \int_{\mathbb{R}}|\varphi(t)| d t<\infty
$$

Finally, applying Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem, we conclude that

$$
\int_{a}^{b} \mathrm{E} \frac{1}{\sigma} g\left(\frac{x-X}{\sigma}\right) d x \rightarrow \int_{a}^{b} \frac{d x}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t x} \varphi(t) d t=\mathrm{P}(a<X \leqslant b) \geqslant 0
$$

($a$ and $b$ are defined above). From this, it follows that the random variable $X$ has the density $f(x)=(2 \pi)^{-1} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t x} \varphi(t) d t$. This function is bounded and continuous (thereby it must be non-negative due to condition $(*)$).

36. A function $\phi=\phi(\lambda), \lambda>0$, is called completely monotonic if there exist derivatives $\phi^{(n)}(\lambda)$ of all orders $n \geqslant 0$ for each $\lambda>0$ and $(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(\lambda) \geqslant 0$. Prove the following Bernstein criterion.

A function $\phi=\phi(\lambda)$ on $(0, \infty)$ is the Laplace transform of some probability measure $\mu$ on $\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}, \mathscr{B}^{\left.\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)\right)}\right.$), i.e., $\phi(\lambda)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} e^{-\lambda x} d \mu$, if and only if this function is completely monotonic and $\phi(0+)=1$.

To establish sufficiency, following the work [82] (see also [99], p. 3), the proof should be conducted as follows.
(a) Assuming that $\phi(\infty)=0$, represent $\phi(\lambda)$ in the form (for each $n \geqslant 1$)

$$
\phi(\lambda)=\int_{\lambda}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(u)}{(n-1)!}(u-\lambda)^{n-1} d u
$$

(b) Prove that the function

$$
f_{n}(x)=\frac{(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(n / x)}{n!}(n / x)^{n+1}
$$

is a density on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, and that

$$
\phi(\lambda)=\int_{0}^{n / \lambda}\left(1-\frac{\lambda x}{n}\right)^{n-1} f_{n}(x) d x
$$

(c) Derive from part (b) by a limiting argument that $\phi(\lambda)=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\lambda x} d \mu$
for some probability measure $\mu$ on $\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}, \mathscr{B}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)\right.$).

(d) Consider the case $\phi(\infty)>0$.
original.solution:
Solution. To prove necessity, it is necessary to note that if $\phi(\lambda)=\mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda x}, \lambda>0$, then for all $n \geqslant 0$ (and $\lambda>0$) the relation holds

$$
(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(\lambda)=\mathrm{E} X^{n} e^{-\lambda X} \geqslant 0
$$

The existence of all derivatives can easily be derived from the Lebesgue theorem on dominated convergence (see problem II.6.49). Moreover, again applying the Lebesgue theorem, we find that $\mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda t} \rightarrow 1=\phi(0+), \lambda \downarrow 0$.

Let's prove sufficiency

(a) By the Taylor formula for $n=1,2, \ldots$ for all $a>0$ we have

$$
\phi(\lambda)=\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \frac{(-1)^{i} \phi^{(i)}(a)}{i!}(a-\lambda)^{i}+\int_{\lambda}^{a} \frac{(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(u)}{(n-1)!}(u-\lambda)^{n-1} d u
$$

If now $a>\lambda$, then all the terms (and the integrand) are non-negative. Therefore,

$$
\int_{\lambda}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(u)}{(n-1)!}(u-\lambda)^{n-1} d u \leqslant \phi(\lambda)
$$

By setting $n=1,2, \ldots$ sequentially and taking the limit as $a \rightarrow \infty$ in formula $(*)$, we obtain that the limits exist

$$
l_{n}=\lim _{a} \frac{(-1)^{n-1} \phi^{(n-1)}(a)}{(n-1)!}(a-\lambda)^{n-1}=\lim _{a} \frac{(-1)^{n-1} \phi^{(n-1)}(a)}{(n-1)!} a^{n-1},
$$

since the limits of the corresponding integrals exist

$$
\lim _{a} \int_{\lambda}^{a} \frac{(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(u)}{(n-1)!}(u-\lambda)^{n-1} d u=\int_{\lambda}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(u)}{(n-1)!}(u-\lambda)^{n-1} d u
$$

The limits $l_{n}$ are necessarily equal to zero, since $\phi(\infty)=0$ and

$$
\phi(\lambda)=\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} l_{i+1}+\int_{\lambda}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n} \phi^{(n)}(u)}{(n-1)!}(u-\lambda)^{n-1} d u
$$

(b) The statement follows from part (a) (if we make the substitution $u=n / x$) taking into account that $f_{n}(x) \geqslant 0$ and $\phi(0+)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} f_{n}(x) d x=1$.

(c) Helly's theorem states that

regardless of the distribution functions $F_{n}, n \geqslant 1$, there exists a subsequence $\left(n_{k}\right) \subseteq(n)$ such that $F_{n_{k}}(x) \rightarrow F(x)$ for some generalized distribution function $F, 0 \leqslant F(-\infty) \leqslant \leqslant F(\infty) \leqslant 1$, and all points $x \in \mathbb{R}$, at which $F$ is continuous.

Let $F_{n}=F_{n}(x)$ be the distribution functions corresponding to the densities $f_{n}(n \geqslant 1)$, and $\left(n_{k}\right)$ be the subsequence appearing in Helly's theorem. Note that

$$
\lim _{n}\left(1-\frac{\lambda x}{n}\right)^{n-1} I(\lambda x \leqslant n)=e^{-\lambda x}
$$

uniformly for $x \geqslant 0$. From this, it can be derived that

$$
\phi(\lambda)=\int_{0}^{n_{k} / \lambda}\left(1-\frac{\lambda x}{n_{k}}\right)^{n_{k}-1} d F_{n_{k}}(x) \rightarrow \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\lambda x} d F(x)
$$

so $\phi(\lambda)$ is the Laplace transform of a finite measure $\mu$ induced by the function $F$. This measure must be a probability measure, since $\mu\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)=\phi(0+)=1$.

(d) It is not difficult to see that

$$
\psi(\lambda)=\frac{\phi(\lambda)-\phi(\infty)}{1-\phi(\infty)}, \quad \lambda>0
$$

is a completely monotonic function, $\psi(0+)=1$ and $\psi(\infty)=0$. Therefore, by what has been proved, $\psi(\lambda)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} e^{-\lambda x} d \mu$ for some probability measure $\mu$. Then $\phi(\lambda)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} e^{-\lambda x} d \nu$, where the probability measure $\nu$ is given by the formula

$$
\nu=\phi(\infty) \delta_{\{0\}}+(1-\phi(\infty)) \mu
$$

llm_response:
This problem involves proving a mathematical criterion related to completely monotonic functions and their properties as Laplace transforms of probability measures. The proofs require establishing various properties of derivatives, integrals, and invoking specific theorems like Helly's theorem in probability theory. Consequently, the problem involves proving that a certain function is indeed a Laplace transform based on its characteristics, which cannot be directly executed as a computation.

35. In this problem, following the book [40], it is proposed to establish that

$$
\varlimsup_{t \rightarrow \infty}|\varphi(t)|=1
$$

for the characteristic function $\varphi(t)$ of an arbitrary discrete random variable $\xi$.

To prove this, one should first consider the Fejér kernel

$$
F_{n}(t)=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \sum_{|j| \leqslant k} e^{i j t}, \quad n \geqslant 1, \quad t \in \mathbb{R}
$$

and verify that $F_{n}(t) \geqslant 0$ for all $t$, and then show that if $\xi$ takes values $0, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots$ with probabilities $p_{0}, p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots$, then

$$
\overline{\lim }_{t \rightarrow \infty}|\varphi(t)| \geqslant \lim _{T} \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} \varphi(t) \overline{K_{N}(t, n)} d t \geqslant p_{0}+\frac{n-1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{N} p_{k}
$$

where $K_{N}(t, n)=\prod_{k=1}^{N} F_{n}\left(x_{k} t\right), n, N \geqslant 1$, and, by taking the limit as $n, N \rightarrow \infty$, establish that the equality ( $(*)$) holds.

Remark. Another way to prove the given statement is based on considering the elementary properties of almost periodic functions of the form $\sum_{k \geqslant 1} p_{k} e^{i x_{k} t}$ (see [37, p. 44]).
original.solution:
Solution. The Fejér kernel admits representations of the form

$$
F_{n}(t)=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \frac{\sin (k+1 / 2) t}{\sin t / 2}=\frac{1}{n}\left[\frac{\sin n t / 2}{\sin t / 2}\right]^{2}
$$

since for all $t \in \mathbb{R}$ the equalities hold

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{|j| \leqslant k} e^{i j t}=1+2 \sum_{j=1}^{k} \cos j t=\frac{\sin (k+1 / 2) t}{\sin t / 2} \\
\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \sin (k t+t / 2)=\frac{(\sin n t / 2)^{2}}{\sin t / 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Of course, $F_{n}(t) \geqslant 0, t \in \mathbb{R}$.

We have

$$
K_{N}(t, n)=\prod_{k=1}^{N} F_{n}\left(x_{k} t\right)=1+\frac{n-1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{N} e^{-i x_{k} t}+R_{N}(t, n)
$$

where the remainder $R_{N}(t, n)$ is a weighted sum of exponentials of the form $e^{i a t}$ with positive weights.

Further, since $\varphi(t)=\sum_{k \geqslant 1} p_{k} e^{i x_{k} t}$, where $p_{k} \geqslant 0(k \geqslant 1)$ and $\sum_{k \geqslant 1} p_{k}=$ $=10$, the following relations hold

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{T} \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} \varphi(t) K_{N}(t, n) d t=\lim _{T} \frac{1}{T} \int_{M}^{T} \varphi(t) K_{N}(t, n) d t \leqslant \\
& \leqslant \sup _{t>M}|\varphi(t)| \lim _{T} \frac{1}{T} \int_{M}^{T} K_{N}(t, n) d t= \\
&=\sup _{t>M}|\varphi(t)| \lim _{T} \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} K_{N}(t, n) d t=\sup _{t>M}|\varphi(t)|
\end{aligned}
$$

By taking the limit as $M \rightarrow \infty$, we obtain the upper bound of the limit specified in the condition.

40. Let $X$ be a random variable with density $f=f(x)$ and characteristic function $\varphi=\varphi(t)$. Suppose that either of the following conditions is satisfied:
(a) $\int_{\mathbb{R}}|\varphi(t)|^{2} d t<\infty \quad$ or
(b) $\int_{\mathbb{R}} f^{2}(x) d x<\infty$.

Using the inversion formula from problem II.12.39, prove that the Plancherel formula holds:

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}} f^{2}(x) d x=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|\varphi(t)|^{2} d t \quad(<\infty)
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let condition (a) be satisfied. Note that $\psi(t)=$ $=|\varphi(t)|^{2}, t \in \mathbb{R}$, is the characteristic function of the variable $X-Y$, where $Y$ is an independent copy of the variable $X$. In turn, the density of the variable $X-Y$ is

$$
g(z)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x-z) f(x) d x
$$

where the considered integral is finite for almost all (Lebesgue measure) $z \in \mathbb{R}$. Since $\psi(t)$ is an absolutely integrable function, by the inversion formula we obtain

$$
g(z)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t z} \psi(t) d t
$$

for $z \in \mathbb{R}$ almost everywhere with respect to Lebesgue measure, from which, in particular, it follows that almost everywhere

$$
|g(z)| \leqslant \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|\psi(t)| d t0$. Indeed, as $z \rightarrow 0$ we have

$$
\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}} f_{c}(x)[f(x+z)-f(x)] d x\right| \leqslant c \int_{\mathbb{R}}|f(x+z)-f(x)| d x \rightarrow 0 .
$$

Furthermore, $g_{c}(z) \leqslant g(z)$ and

$$
g_{c}(0) \uparrow g(0), \quad c \uparrow \infty
$$

therefore, if for some $z_{n} \rightarrow 0$ the values $g\left(z_{n}\right)$ are uniformly bounded by some $M>0$, then $g(0)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f^{2}(x) d x \leqslant M$.

Thus, we can initially assume that condition (b) is satisfied. If this is the case, then $g$ is a bounded continuous function, since in this case by the Cauchy-Bunyakovsky inequality (see also problem II.10.37)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{z} g^{2}(z) \leqslant \int_{\mathbb{R}} f^{2}(x-z) d x \int_{\mathbb{R}} f^{2}(x) d x=g(0)^{2}<\infty \\
& \quad|g(u)-g(v)|^{2} \leqslant g(0) \int_{\mathbb{R}}|f(x-u)-f(x-v)|^{2} d x \rightarrow 0, \quad u \rightarrow v
\end{aligned}
$$

Now consider the variable $X-Y+\sigma Z$, where $Z \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$ is independent of $X, Y$. Its characteristic function and density are respectively

$$
\varphi_{\sigma}(t)=e^{-\frac{\sigma^{2} t^{2}}{2}}|\varphi(t)|^{2}, \quad h(z)=\mathrm{E} g(z-\sigma Z)
$$

where $t, z \in \mathbb{R}$. Therefore, $\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\varphi_{\sigma}(t)\right| d t<\infty$ and $h(z)$ is continuous in $z$, so by the inversion formula we have

$$
h(z)=\operatorname{E} g(z-\sigma Z)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t z} \varphi_{\sigma}(t) d t
$$

everywhere and, in particular, at $z=0$. Now passing to the limit as $\sigma \rightarrow 0$ and applying the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem (the function $g$ is bounded and continuous), we obtain the desired equality.

Remark. In deriving the Plancherel formula, in particular, it was established that if the function

$$
g(z)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x-z) f(x) d x, \quad z \in \mathbb{R}
$$

(the convolution of the density $f(x)$ with $f(-x)$), is uniformly bounded for $z \in$ $\in\left\{z_{1}, z_{2}, \ldots\right\}, z_{n} \rightarrow 0$, then $g(z)$ is a bounded continuous function on $\mathbb{R}$. It is interesting to note that there exist such densities $f(x)$ for which the function $g(z)$ is discontinuous at every point. For example,

$$
f(x)=\sum_{n \geqslant 1} 2^{-n} h\left(x-q_{n}\right), \quad \text { where } \quad h(x)= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}, & x \in(0,1] \\ 0, & x \notin(0,1]\end{cases}
$$

$\left\{q_{1}, q_{2}, \ldots\right\}=\mathbb{Q}$. The function $f(x)$ is indeed a density, since $\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x) d x=1$ and $f(x) \geqslant 0$, and, therefore, $f(x)<\infty$ almost everywhere with respect to
Lebesgue measure. Moreover, the convolution $g(z)$ is also finite almost everywhere with respect to Lebesgue measure (this follows from Fubini's theorem). However, it is clear that $g(z)=\infty$ for $z \in \mathbb{Q}$. Therefore, $g$ is discontinuous at any point.

45. Let $\varphi=\varphi(t)$ be a characteristic function. Prove that

(a) $\varphi$ corresponds to a distribution with a bounded density $f=f(x)$, if

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}|\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)| d t<\infty$ and there exists a singular distribution for which $\int_{\mathbb{R}}|\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)|^{p} d t<\infty$ (see the proof of Theorem 13.4.2 in the book [74]). For $1 \leqslant p \leqslant 2$, the condition $\int_{\mathbb{R}}|\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)|^{p} d t<\infty$ implies the existence of a density in $L^{q}, q=p /(p-1)$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $X$ be a random variable with characteristic function $\varphi$ and $\xi$ be a random variable independent of $X$, $\mathrm{P}(\xi=1)=\mathrm{P}(\xi=-1)=1 / 2$. Then

$$
\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)=\mathrm{E} \cos t X=\mathrm{E} \frac{e^{-i t X}+e^{i t X}}{2}=\mathrm{E} e^{i t \xi X}
$$

is the characteristic function for $\xi X$. By problem II.4.1, if the variable $\xi X$ has a density $g=g(x)$, then $X$ also has such a density $f=f(x)$, such that

$$
g(x)=\frac{f(x)+f(-x)}{2}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R}
$$

Moreover, $g \in L^{p}(1 \leqslant p \leqslant \infty)$ if and only if $f \in L^{p}$. Thus, part (a) follows from the inversion formula.

To verify part (b), we need to show that $l(h)=\mathrm{E} h(\xi X)$ is a linear bounded functional in the Hilbert space $L^{2}$ (with the Lebesgue measure on $\mathbb{R}$). Any such functional is necessarily represented in the form

$$
l(h)=(f, h)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x) h(x) d x
$$

for some function $f \in L^{2}$, so $f \vee 0(=f$ almost everywhere) will be the desired density.

We can take $f=\sum_{n \geqslant 1} l_{n} e_{n}$, where $l_{n}=l\left(e_{n}\right)$ and $\left(e_{n}\right)$ is any complete orthonormal system in $L^{2}$. In this case, $f$ will be a well-defined element of the space $L^{2}$, since

$$
\sum_{n \geqslant 1} l_{n}^{2}=\lim _{m} l\left(\sum_{n \leqslant m} \frac{l_{n} e_{n}}{\sqrt{\sum_{n \leqslant m} l_{n}^{2}}}\right)^{2} \leqslant \sup _{(h, h)=1} l(h)^{2}<\infty
$$

It is sufficient to check the boundedness of $l(h)$ for all $h$ that are finite linear combinations of the elements $e_{n}, n \geqslant 1$. If we take $e_{n}$ to be only bounded continuous functions (such a system exists), then their linear combination will also be continuous and bounded.

Thus, we need to show that $\sup |l(h)|<\infty$, where the supremum is taken over all such continuous bounded functions $h$ such that $(h, h)=1$. Let $Z \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$ be independent of $\xi X$. Then

$$
\mathrm{E} h(\xi X+\sigma Z) \rightarrow \mathrm{E} h(\xi X)=l(h), \quad \sigma \rightarrow 0
$$

Let $f_{\sigma}=f_{\sigma}(x)(\sigma \neq 0)$ be the density of the variable $\xi X+\sigma Z$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
{[\mathrm{E} h(\xi X+\sigma Z)]^{2}=\left(h, f_{\sigma}\right)^{2} \leqslant\left(f_{\sigma}, f_{\sigma}\right)=} & \int_{\mathbb{R}} f_{\sigma}^{2}(x) d x= \\
& =\int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-\sigma^{2} t^{2} / 2}|\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)|^{2} d t<\infty,
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last equality we applied the Plancherel equality (see problem II.12.40).

Therefore,

$$
\sup |l(h)|^{2} \leqslant \lim _{\sigma \rightarrow 0} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-\sigma^{2} t^{2} / 2}|\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)|^{2} d t=\int_{\mathbb{R}}|\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)|^{2} d t<\infty \text {. }
$$

This completes the proof of the boundedness of the functional $l(h)$.

43. Show that if $\varphi(t)$ is the characteristic function of a random variable $\xi$, then the Laplace transform of the magnitude $|\xi|$ is given by the formula

$$
\mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda|\xi|}=\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\lambda \varphi(t)}{\lambda^{2}+t^{2}} d t, \quad \lambda>0
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Consider the quantity $\eta$, independent of $\xi$ and having a Cauchy distribution with density $\frac{1}{\pi\left(1+x^{2}\right)}$ and characteristic function $e^{-|t|}$. By Fubini's theorem, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{E} e^{-\lambda|\xi|}=\mathrm{E} e^{i \lambda \xi \eta}=\mathrm{E} \varphi(\lambda \eta)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\lambda}{\pi\left(\lambda^{2}+t^{2}\right)} \varphi(t) d t, \quad \lambda>0
$$

50. Moments $\mathrm{E} X^{n}$ and absolute moments $\mathrm{E}|X|^{n}$ of a random variable $X$ can be expressed for integers $n \geqslant 1$ through the $n$-th order derivatives of the characteristic function $\varphi(t)=\mathrm{E} e^{i t X}, t \in \mathbb{R}$. For fractional $\alpha>0$, to obtain the corresponding results for $\mathrm{E} X^{\alpha}$ and $\mathrm{E}|X|^{\alpha}$, one has to resort to the concept of fractional derivatives, defined as follows.

Let $n$ be a non-negative integer and $0<a<1$. The fractional derivative $\frac{d^{n+a} f(t)}{d t^{n+a}}$ of a function $f=f(t), t \in \mathbb{R}$, is defined as

$$
\frac{a}{\Gamma(1-a)} \int_{-\infty}^{t} \frac{f^{(n)}(t)-f^{(n)}(s)}{(t-s)^{1+a}} d s
$$

(assuming the integral is well-defined).

In particular, if $\varphi=\varphi(t)$ is the characteristic function of a random variable $X$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d^{n+a} \varphi(0)}{d t^{n+a}}=\frac{a}{\Gamma(1-a)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{\varphi^{(n)}(0)-\varphi^{(n)}(-s)}{s^{1+a}} d s= \\
& =\frac{i^{n} a}{\Gamma(1-a)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}}\left[\mathrm{E} X^{n}(1-\cos s X)+i \mathrm{E} X^{n} \sin s X\right] \frac{d s}{s^{1+a}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Show that for even $n$, the absolute moments $\mathrm{E}|X|^{n+a}$ are finite if and only if

(1) $\mathrm{E} X^{n}<\infty$;

(2) $\frac{d^{n+a} \operatorname{Re} \varphi(0)}{d t^{n+a}}$ exists.

In this case,

$$
\mathrm{E}|X|^{n+a}=\frac{(-1)^{n / 2}}{\cos \frac{a \pi}{2}} \frac{d^{n+a} \operatorname{Re} \varphi(0)}{d t^{n+a}}
$$

Remark. A more detailed discussion of issues related to finding $\mathrm{E}|X|^{n+a}$ for any $n \geqslant 0$ and $0<a<1$ can be found in the book $[81]$.
original.solution:
Solution. If condition 1 is satisfied, then $\varphi^{(n)}(t)$ exist for all $t \in \mathbb{R}$. If, in addition, condition 2 holds, then

$$
\left.\frac{d^{n+a} \operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)}{d t^{n+a}}\right|_{t=0}=\frac{(-1)^{n / 2} a}{\Gamma(1-a)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \mathrm{E} X^{n}(1-\cos s X) \frac{d s}{s^{1+a}}
$$

Now let us use the following formula:

$$
C_{b} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{1-\cos s x}{s^{1+b}} d s=|x|^{b}
$$

which is valid for all $0<b<2$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}$ when

$$
C_{b}=\frac{2 \Gamma(1+b)}{\pi} \sin \frac{\pi b}{2}
$$

Moreover, by Fubini's theorem,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d^{n+a} \operatorname{Re} \varphi(0)}{d t^{n+a}}=\frac{(-1)^{n / 2} a}{\Gamma(1-a)} \mathrm{E} X^{n} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}}(1-\cos s X) \frac{d s}{s^{1+a}}= \\
& \quad=(-1)^{n / 2} \frac{\pi}{2}\left[\Gamma(1-a) \frac{\Gamma(1+a)}{a} \sin \frac{\pi a}{2}\right]^{-1} \cdot \mathrm{E}|X|^{n+a}= \\
& \quad=(-1)^{n / 2} \frac{\pi}{2}\left[\frac{\pi}{\sin \pi a} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi a}{2}\right]^{-1} \cdot \mathrm{E}|X|^{n+a}=(-1)^{n / 2} \cos \frac{\pi a}{2} \cdot \mathrm{E}|X|^{n+a} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, the converse statement can be established.

55. Let $\xi$ and $\eta$ be independent random variables, and $\eta \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$. Let also $f=f(x)$ be a bounded Borel function with compact support. Show that for any $\sigma>0$ the following equality holds:

$$
\mathrm{E} f(\xi+\sigma \eta)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-\frac{\sigma^{2} t^{2}}{2}} \varphi(t) \widehat{f}(-t) d t
$$

where $\varphi(t)=\mathrm{E} e^{i t \xi}$ and $\hat{f}(t)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{i t x} f(x) d x$.

Formulate an analogous result for vector-valued variables $\xi$ and $\eta$.
original.solution:
Solution. The characteristic function of the quantity $\zeta=\xi+\sigma \eta$ is absolutely integrable on $\mathbb{R}$ and equals $e^{-\frac{\sigma^{2} t^{2}}{2}} \varphi(t)$. This means that the density of the quantity $\zeta$ is

$$
\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i t x-\frac{\sigma^{2} t^{2}}{2}} \varphi(t) d t
$$

Using now Fubini's theorem for the bounded measures $|f(x)| d x$ and $e^{-\frac{\sigma^{2} t^{2}}{2}} d t$, we obtain the desired formula $(*)$.

For independent random vectors $\xi$ and $\eta \sim \mathscr{N}(0, I)$, taking values in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ (where $I$ is the identity matrix of size $n \times n$), the formula $(*)$ is rewritten as

$$
\mathrm{E} f(\xi+\sigma \eta)=\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{n}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} e^{-\frac{\sigma^{2}(t, t)}{2}} \varphi(t) \hat{f}(-t) d t
$$

where $\varphi(t)=\mathrm{E} e^{i(t, \xi)}$ and $\hat{f}(t)=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} e^{i(t, x)} f(x) d x$.

48. (a) Show that the series

$$
\sum_{n \geqslant 1} a_{n} \sin n t
$$

converges uniformly on $\mathbb{R}$ when $n a_{n} \rightarrow 0$ and $a_{n} \geqslant a_{n+1} \geqslant 0$ for all $n$.

(b) Verify by example that the smoothness on $\mathbb{R}$ of the characteristic function $\varphi(t)$ of a random variable $\xi$ does not, in general, imply that $\mathrm{E}|\xi|<\infty$.
original.solution:
Solution. (a) Due to the periodicity of the function $f(x)=\sin n x$, it is sufficient to prove uniform convergence for $t \in(0, \pi]$. We will need auxiliary relations of the form

$$
s_{n}=\sum_{l=1}^{n} \sin l t=\frac{\sin \frac{(n+1) t}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{n t}{2}}{\sin \frac{t}{2}}
$$

$$
\left|s_{n}\right| \leqslant \frac{\frac{(n+1) t}{2} \cdot \frac{n t}{2}}{\frac{2}{\pi} \cdot \frac{t}{2}}=(n+1) n \cdot \frac{\pi t}{4}, \quad n t \leqslant 1, \quad \text { and } \quad\left|s_{n}\right| \leqslant \frac{\pi}{t}, \quad n t>1
$$

Using these estimates, we find that uniformly in $t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\sum_{l=m}^{n} a_{l} \sin l t\right|=\left|\sum_{l=m}^{n} a_{l}\left(s_{l}-s_{l-1}\right)\right| \leqslant \\
& \leqslant m a_{m}+n a_{n}+\left|\sum_{l=m}^{n-1}\left(a_{l}-a_{l+1}\right) s_{l}\right| \leqslant \\
& \leqslant m a_{m}+n a_{n}+\frac{\pi t}{4} \sum_{m \leqslant l \leqslant t^{-1}}\left(a_{l}-a_{l+1}\right)(l+1) l+\frac{\pi}{t} \sum_{t^{-1}<l \leqslant n}\left(a_{l}-a_{l+1}\right) \leqslant \\
& \leqslant 2 m a_{m}+n a_{n}+\pi \frac{l\left(m \leqslant t^{-1}\right)}{t^{-1}} \sum_{1 \leqslant l \leqslant t^{-1}}(l+1) a_{l}+\pi a_{\left[t^{-1}\right] \vee m} \cdot t^{-1} \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where $m, n \rightarrow \infty, 1 \leqslant m<n$, and $[x]$ is the integer part of $x \geqslant 0$.

(b) Let $\xi$ be a symmetric random variable with values in $\mathbb{Z}$, such that

$$
\mathrm{P}(|\xi|=n)=p_{n}, \quad \mathrm{E}|\xi|=\sum n p_{n}=\infty
$$

where $n \geqslant 1, n^{2} p_{n} \rightarrow 0$ and $n p_{n}$ decreases with $n$. We will show that under these constraints, the characteristic function of this variable

$$
\varphi(t)=\mathrm{P}(\xi=0)+\sum p_{n} \cos n t
$$

is smooth (despite the equality $\mathrm{E}|\xi|=\infty$). Indeed, since the series $\sum p_{n}(\cos n t)^{\prime}=-\sum n p_{n} \sin n t$ converges uniformly on $\mathbb{R}$ (see part (a)), it can be integrated term by term, and thus the derivative $\varphi^{\prime}(t)$ exists, is continuous, and coincides with $-\sum n p_{n} \sin n t$.

llm_response:
The problem consists of two parts: 

(a) Proving the uniform convergence of a series involving sine functions under certain conditions on the coefficients, which requires establishing a mathematical property rather than just performing straightforward calculations. 

(b) Providing a counterexample to show that smoothness of a characteristic function does not guarantee finiteness of the expected value, which also necessitates proving a property.

Both parts of the problem require establishing properties of series and functions rather than simply performing computations. This aligns with the classification for problems that require more than routine calculation or differentiation.

Therefore, the classification for this problem is:

HARD
