47. Let $f=f(x)$ be the density of some probability distribution, $\varphi=\varphi(t)$ its characteristic function. Using problem II.12.46(a), verify that for all $\sigma>0$ the function

$$
f_{\sigma}(x)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\sigma|t| \leqslant 1} e^{-i t x} \varphi(t)(1-\sigma|t|) d t
$$

is a density, and that

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|f(x)-f_{\sigma}(x)\right| d x \rightarrow 0, \quad \sigma \rightarrow 0
$$
original.solution:
Solution. According to problem II.12.46(a), we have

$$
\varphi(t)(1-\sigma|t|)^{+}=\mathrm{E} e^{i t(X+\sigma Y)}
$$

where the quantities $X, Y$ are independent, $X$ has density $f(x)$, and the density of the quantity $Y$ is

$$
g(x)=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left[\frac{\sin (x / 2)}{x / 2}\right]^{2}
$$

Therefore, due to the inversion formula, $f_{\sigma}(x)$ is the density of the quantity $X+\sigma Y$ and

$$
f_{\sigma}(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x-\sigma z) g(z) d z
$$

Consequently,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|f(x)-f_{\sigma}(x)\right| d x \leqslant \int_{\mathbb{R}} h(\sigma z) g(z) d z=\mathrm{E} h(\sigma Y),
$$

where

$$
h(u)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}|f(x)-f(x-u)| d x, \quad u \in \mathbb{R}
$$

By problem II.10.37, we have $h(\sigma Y) \rightarrow 0$ as $\sigma \rightarrow 0$ everywhere. Since $|h(\sigma Y)| \leqslant 2$, by the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem, $\mathrm{E} h(\sigma Y) \rightarrow 0$, from which the desired statement follows.

18. Let $X=X_{t}(\omega),(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times[0,1],-\mathscr{F} \times \mathscr{B}[0,1]$-measurable function, and $\int_{0}^{1}\left|X_{t}\right| d t<\infty$ a.s. Suppose that $\left\{X_{t}\right\}_{0 \leqslant t \leqslant 1}$ is a
Gaussian system. Prove that the random variable $\int_{0}^{1} X_{t} d t$ is also
Gaussian.
original.solution:
Solution. First, we can consider that

$$
\mathrm{E}\left[\int_{0}^{1} X_{t} d t\right]^{2} \leqslant \mathrm{E} \int_{0}^{1} X_{t}^{2} d t=\int_{0}^{1} \mathrm{E} X_{t}^{2} d t<\infty
$$

Alternatively, we can first consider

$$
\frac{X_{t}}{\sqrt{1+\varepsilon \mathrm{E} X_{t}^{2}}}
$$

and then take the limit as $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$, using the fact that the limit of a sequence of almost surely Gaussian random variables is always a Gaussian random variable.

Notice that if $Y=Y_{t}(\omega)-$ is an independent $\mathscr{F} \times \mathscr{B}[0,1]$-measurable copy of the random variable $X$, for which the relations $\int_{0}^{1}\left|Y_{t}\right| d t<\infty$ almost surely and $\int_{0}^{1} Y_{t} d t \stackrel{d}{=} \int_{0}^{1} X_{t} d t$ hold, then by problem II.6.20, the random variables $\int_{0}^{1} X_{t} d t$ and $\int_{0}^{1} Y_{t} d t$ are independent. Furthermore, the following are also independent:

$$
\int_{0}^{1}\left[X_{t}-Y_{t}\right] d t=\int_{0}^{1} X_{t} d t-\int_{0}^{1} Y_{t} d t \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{0}^{1}\left[X_{t}+Y_{t}\right] d t=\int_{0}^{1} X_{t} d t+\int_{0}^{1} Y_{t} d t .
$$

Therefore, by Bernstein's theorem (see problem II.13.17), $\int_{0}^{1} X_{t} d t$ is a Gaussian random variable.

A suitable copy $Y$ can be easily constructed on an extension of the original probability space $(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathrm{P})$. Specifically, it is sufficient to set

$$
Y_{t}\left(\omega, \omega^{\prime}\right)=X_{t}\left(\omega^{\prime}\right), \quad X_{t}\left(\omega, \omega^{\prime}\right)=X_{t}(\omega), \quad\left(\omega, \omega^{\prime}\right) \in \Omega \times \Omega^{\prime}
$$

where $\left(\Omega^{\prime}, \mathscr{F}^{\prime}, \mathrm{P}^{\prime}\right)$ is a copy of the space $(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathrm{P})$.

x^{-p} & =\frac{1}{\Gamma(p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} e^{-\lambda x} \lambda^{p-1} d \lambda, & & p>0
\end{aligned}
$$

$$

show that the probability densities

then $\mathrm{E} e^{\lambda X}0)$, $x \in \mathbb{R}, Y$ is an independent copy of the variable $X, \mathrm{P}(Z= \pm 1)=1 / 2$, and $F_{n}(t), n \geqslant 1,$ are binomial distribution functions with parameters $(1 / 2, n)$, where $F_{0}(x)=I(x \geqslant 0), x \in \mathbb{R}$.

52. Let $X$ be a non-negative random variable.

(a) The double Laplace transform or Stieltjes transform of the variable $X$ is the function $\bar{\psi}(\lambda)=$ $=\mathrm{E}(X+\lambda)^{-1}, \lambda>0$. Prove that for $0<\lambda<\infty$, $\bar{\psi}(\lambda)$ is a completely monotone function. Show that for any $0<p<1$ the following equality holds:

$$
\mathrm{E} X^{p}=\frac{p}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \bar{\psi}(\lambda) \lambda^{p-1} d \lambda
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The required relations follow from the equalities

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{-p} & =\frac{1}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{\lambda^{-p}}{x+\lambda} d \lambda \\
x^{p} & =\frac{p}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \ln (1+x / \lambda) \lambda^{p-1} d \lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

valid for all $x \geqslant 0$. We will derive the first equality from the formulas used in solving the previous problem. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $x=1$ (otherwise, make the substitution $v=\lambda / x, x>0$ in the integrand). We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
1 & =\frac{p}{\Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{1-e^{-\lambda}}{\lambda^{p+1}} d \lambda= \\
& =\frac{p}{\Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}}\left(1-e^{-\lambda}\right)\left[\frac{1}{\Gamma(p+1)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} e^{-u \lambda} u^{p} d u\right] d \lambda= \\
& =\frac{p}{\Gamma(p+1) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} u^{p} d u \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}}\left[e^{-u \lambda}-e^{-\lambda(u+1)}\right] d \lambda= \\
& =\frac{1}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{u^{p-1}}{u+1} d u=\frac{1}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{v^{-p}}{1+v} d v
\end{aligned}
$$

Now let's prove the second equality:

$$
\begin{aligned}
1 & =\int_{0}^{1} p u^{p-1} d u=\int_{0}^{1}\left[\frac{p}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{\lambda^{p-1}}{u+\lambda} d \lambda\right] d u= \\
& =\frac{p}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \lambda^{p-1} d \lambda \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{u+\lambda} d u= \\
& =\frac{p}{\Gamma(p) \Gamma(1-p)} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \lambda^{p-1} \ln \frac{\lambda+1}{\lambda} d \lambda .
\end{aligned}
$$

19. Let $K=K(s, t)$ be a continuous real covariance function on $[a, b]^{2} \subset \mathbb{R}^{2}$. Verify the continuity and self-adjointness in $L^{2}[a, b]$ of the operator

$$
A f(s)=\int_{a}^{b} K(s, t) f(t) d t
$$

By applying the Hilbert-Schmidt theorem and considering the compactness of the operator $A$, prove Mercer's theorem: the equation

$$
\int_{a}^{b} K(s, t) \phi(t) d t=\lambda \phi(s), \quad a \leqslant s \leqslant b
$$

for an infinite number of values $\lambda=\lambda_{n} \geqslant 0, n \geqslant 1$, has corresponding real solutions $\phi_{n}=\phi_{n}(s), n \geqslant 1$, forming a complete orthonormal system in $L^{2}=L^{2}[a, b]$, such that $\phi_{n}$ is continuous when $\lambda_{n}>0$, and

$$
K(s, t)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \lambda_{n} \phi_{n}(s) \phi_{n}(t)
$$

where the series converges absolutely and uniformly on $[a, b] \times[a, b]$.

From this, derive that a centered Gaussian process $X=$ $=\left(X_{t}, t \in[a, b]\right)$ with covariance function $K(s, t)$ can be constructively defined as:

$$
X_{t}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \xi_{n} \sqrt{\lambda_{n}} \phi_{n}(t)
$$

where $\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots$ are independent $\mathscr{N}(0,1)$-variables, and the convergence of this series holds almost surely and in $L^{2}$.
original.solution:
Solution. Since for $f, g \in L^{2}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{a}^{b}|A f(s)-A g(s)|^{2} d s \leqslant\left.\int_{a}^{b} \int_{a}^{b} \int_{a}|K(s, t) \| f(t)-g(t)| d t\right|^{2} d s \leqslant \\
& \leqslant(b-a)^{2}\|K\|_{\infty}^{2} \int_{a}^{b}|f(t)-g(t)|^{2} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

the operator $A$ is continuous. Moreover, by Fubini's theorem

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (A f, g)=\int_{a}^{b} A f(s) \overline{g(s)} d s=\int_{[a, b]^{2}} K(s, t) f(t) \overline{g(s)} d s d t= \\
& =\int_{a}^{b} f(t) \overline{A g(t)} d t=(f, A g)
\end{aligned}
$$

so $A$ is a self-adjoint operator.

Therefore, by the Hilbert-Schmidt theorem (considering the compactness of the operator $A$) in $L^{2}$ there exists a complete orthonormal system of complex-valued functions $\phi_{n}$, satisfying equation (*) for some $\lambda=\lambda_{n} \in \mathbb{R},\left|\lambda_{1}\right| \geqslant\left|\lambda_{2}\right| \geqslant \ldots \rightarrow 0, n \rightarrow \infty$, and such that

$$
A f=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \lambda_{n}\left(f, \phi_{n}\right) \phi_{n}
$$

in $L^{2}$. Moreover, due to the non-negative definiteness of $K(s, t)$ we have

$$
\lambda_{n}=\left(A \phi_{n}, \phi_{n}\right)=\int_{[a, b]^{2}} K(s, t) \phi_{n}(t) \overline{\phi_{n}(s)} d s d t \geqslant 0
$$

Furthermore,

$$
\left\|A \phi_{n}(s)\right\| \leqslant\|K\|_{\infty} \int_{a}^{b}\left|\phi_{n}(t)\right| d t
$$

thus, by the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem, the functions $\phi_{n}(s)$ are continuous in $s$ when $\lambda_{n}>0$. We will now show that $\phi_{n}$ can be chosen to be real.

If $\phi_{n}$ is a solution to equation (*) for $\lambda=\lambda_{n}$, then so are $\operatorname{Re} \phi_{n}$ and $\operatorname{Im} \phi_{n}$. Define $\mu_{1}, \mu_{2}, \ldots$ by the conditions

$$
\mu_{n}>\mu_{n+1}, \quad \lambda_{n} \in\left\{\mu_{1}, \mu_{2}, \ldots\right\} \quad \text { for all } n .
$$

Consider the system of functions

$$
A_{i}=\left\{\operatorname{Re} \phi_{n}: \lambda_{n}=\mu_{i}\right\} \cup\left\{\operatorname{Im} \phi_{n}: \lambda_{n}=\mu_{i}\right\}
$$

Solutions to equation (*) corresponding to different $\lambda$ are orthogonal. Therefore, $\left(f_{i}, f_{j}\right)=0$ for $f_{i} \in A_{i}, f_{j} \in A_{j}$ when $i \neq j$. Let $n_{i}=\left|A_{i}\right|$. Applying the Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization method to the functions in $A_{i}$, we obtain a system of orthonormal functions $f_{1 i}, \ldots, f_{n_{i}}$, generating $A_{i}$ and being a linear combination of functions from $A_{i}$. Thus, the set

$$
\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}\left\{f_{1 i}, \ldots, f_{n_{i} i}\right\}
$$

is a complete orthonormal system of real solutions to equation (*) in $L^{2}$, which can be taken as $\left\{\varphi_{n}\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$.

For each $n$ the function

$$
K_{n}(s, t)=K(s, t)-\sum_{i=1}^{n} \lambda_{i} \phi_{i}(s) \phi_{i}(t)
$$

is continuous in $(s, t)$. Denote by $A_{n}$ the integral operator corresponding to $K_{n}$. For any function $f \in L^{2}$ we have

$$
\int_{[a, b]^{2}} K_{n}(s, t) f(s) \overline{f(t)} d s d t=\left(A_{n} f, f\right)=\sum_{i=n+1}^{\infty} \lambda_{i}\left|\left(f, \phi_{i}\right)\right|^{2}
$$

From this it follows that $K_{n}(s, s) \geqslant 0$ for all $s$. Indeed, otherwise (due to the continuity of $K_{n}$) there would be a neighborhood $U=\left(s_{0}-\delta, s_{0}+\delta\right)^{2}$,
where $K_{n}$ takes negative values. Then ( $\left.A_{n} f, f\right)<0$ for $f \equiv 1$ in $U$ and $f \equiv 0$ outside $U$, which is impossible.

Thus, we have $K_{n}(s, s) \geqslant 0$ for all $s$ and $n$, and therefore,

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \lambda_{n}\left|\phi_{n}(s)\right|^{2} \leqslant K(s, s)
$$

Considering the Cauchy-Bunyakovsky inequality, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\sum_{i=m}^{n} \lambda_{i} \phi_{i}(s) \phi_{i}(t)\right|^{2} \leqslant \sum_{i=m}^{n} \lambda_{i}\left|\phi_{i}(s)\right|^{2} \sum_{i=m}^{n} & \lambda_{i}\left|\phi_{i}(t)\right|^{2} \leqslant \\
= & \|K\|_{\infty} \sum_{i=m}^{n} \lambda_{i}\left|\phi_{i}(t)\right|^{2}, \quad m \leqslant n
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, for each fixed $t$ the series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \lambda_{n} \phi_{n}(s) \phi_{n}(t)$ converges uniformly in $s$ to some function $R(s, t)$. Due to the continuity of $\phi_{n}$ for $\lambda_{n} \neq 0$, the function $R(s, t)$ will be continuous in $t$, and for any continuous function $f$ the equality

$$
\int_{a}^{b} R(s, t) f(t) d t=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \lambda_{n}\left(f, \phi_{n}\right) \phi_{n}(s) .
$$

holds. Therefore,

$$
\int_{a}^{b}[K(s, t)-R(s, t)] f(t) d t=0
$$

Setting $f(t)=K(s, t)-R(s, t)$, we get $K(s, t)=R(s, t)$ for all $t$ at each fixed $s$ and, in particular,

$$
K(s, s)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \lambda_{n}\left|\phi_{n}(s)\right|^{2}
$$

It remains to use Dini's theorem (the proof of which is left as an exercise).

If the series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} f_{n}(x)$ of continuous non-negative functions $f_{n}:[a, b] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}$ converges to a continuous function $f$, then this convergence is uniform in $x$.

Applying the Cauchy-Bunyakovsky inequality, as done above, and considering Dini's theorem, we obtain the absolute and uniform convergence of the series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \lambda_{n} \phi_{n}(s) \phi_{n}(t)$ in $(s, t)$. Mercer's theorem is proved.

Let's move on to the second part of the problem. By the relation ( $* *$ ) we have

$$
\mathrm{E}\left|\sum_{i=m}^{n} \sqrt{\lambda_{i}} \phi_{i}(t) \xi_{i}\right|^{2}=\sum_{i=m}^{n} \lambda_{i}\left|\phi_{i}(t)\right|^{2} \rightarrow 0, \quad m, n \rightarrow \infty
$$

Thus, the sequence of partial sums of the series $X_{t}$ is fundamental in $L^{2}$, so it converges in $L^{2}$. Moreover, by the Kolmogorov-Hinchin theorem

20. (See [87], [106].) Let $\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$. Then

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{E} \xi_{n: n} \leqslant \sqrt{2 \ln n}, \quad n \geqslant 1, \\
\frac{\lim _{n}}{}\left[\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}\right] \leqslant 0 \quad \text { a.s., }
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\xi_{n: n}=\max \left\{\xi_{1}, \ldots, \xi_{n}\right\}$.

If in addition $\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots$ are independent, then

$$
\lim _{n}\left[\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}\right]=0 \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

Refine the last result by showing that

$$
\varlimsup_{n} \frac{\sqrt{2 \ln n}\left[\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}\right]}{\ln \ln n}=\frac{1}{2}, \quad \frac{\lim }{n} \frac{\sqrt{2 \ln n}\left[\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}\right]}{\ln \ln n}=-\frac{1}{2}
$$

Remark. Similar equalities with $\varlimsup$ and $\varliminf$ for maxima of the form

$$
\max _{0 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n} \frac{\xi_{i+1}+\ldots+\xi_{j}}{\sqrt{i-i}}
$$

were obtained in the paper [72].
original.solution:
Solution. By Jensen's inequality for all $s>0$ we have

$$
\mathrm{E} \xi_{n: n} \leqslant \frac{1}{s} \ln \mathrm{E} e^{s \xi \xi_{n n}} \leqslant \frac{1}{s} \ln \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathrm{E} e^{s \xi_{i}}=\frac{1}{s} \ln n e^{\frac{s^{2}}{2}}=\frac{\ln n}{s}+\frac{s}{2}
$$

Minimizing over $s>0$, we find that $\mathrm{E} \xi_{n: n} \leqslant \sqrt{2 \ln n}$ when $s=\sqrt{2 \ln n}$.

For any $\varepsilon>0$ we have

$$
\sum \mathrm{P}\left(\left|\xi_{n}\right| \geqslant \sqrt{2 \ln n}+\varepsilon\right) \leqslant \sum \mathrm{P}\left(e^{\frac{\left(\left|\xi_{1}\right|-\varepsilon\right)^{2}}{2}} \geqslant n\right) \leqslant \mathrm{E} e^{\frac{\left(\left|\xi_{1}\right|-\varepsilon\right)^{2}}{2}}0$ with probability one, only a finite number of events $\left\{\left|\xi_{n}\right|-\sqrt{2 \ln n} \geqslant \varepsilon\right\}$ occur. Therefore,

$$
\varlimsup_{n}\left[\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}\right] \leqslant 0 \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

Now consider independent random variables $\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots \sim$ $\sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$. Let $\varphi=\varphi(x)$ be the density of $\xi_{1}$. For all $\varepsilon>0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{n: n} \leqslant \sqrt{2 \ln n}-\varepsilon\right)=\sum \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1} \leqslant \sqrt{2 \ln n}-\varepsilon\right)^{n}= \\
& =\sum\left[1-\mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1}>\sqrt{2 \ln n}-\varepsilon\right)\right]^{n} \leqslant \sum \exp \left[-n \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1}>\sqrt{2 \ln n}-\varepsilon\right)\right] \leqslant \\
& \leqslant \sum \exp [-h(\sqrt{2 \ln n}, \varepsilon)]0
$$

and the penultimate estimate follows from the inequality

$$
\mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1}>x\right) \geqslant \frac{x \varphi(x)}{1+x^{2}}, \quad x>0
$$

Again applying the Borel-Cantelli lemma, we get

$$
\frac{\lim }{n}\left[\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}\right] \geqslant 0 \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

From this, taking into account that $\overline{\lim }_{n}\left[\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}\right] \leqslant 0$ a.s. (see above), the required relation follows.

Let us now denote for brevity

$$
L_{n}=\frac{\ln \ln n}{\sqrt{2 \ln n}}
$$

for $n \geqslant 3$ and $L_{n}=1$ for $n=1,2$. Then, taking into account the estimate

$$
\mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1}>x\right) \leqslant \frac{\varphi(x)}{x}, \quad x>0
$$

for each $a>1 / 2$ we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{n} \geqslant \sqrt{2 \ln n}+a L_{n}\right) \leqslant \sum \frac{\varphi\left(\sqrt{2 \ln n}+a L_{n}\right)}{\sqrt{2 \ln n}} \leqslant \\
& \leqslant \sum \frac{1}{n(\ln n)^{a+1 / 2}}0$. In other words, due to the second Borel-Cantelli lemma for $a\sqrt{2 \ln n}-a L_{n}\right)\right]^{n} \rightarrow 1
$$

since

$$
\mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1}>\sqrt{2 \ln n}-a L_{n}\right) \sim \frac{\varphi\left(\sqrt{2 \ln n}-a L_{n}\right)}{\sqrt{2 \ln n}-a L_{n}}=o\left(\frac{1}{n}\right)
$$

Therefore, we can find a sequence of indices $n_{k} \uparrow \infty$ and numbers $a_{k} \uparrow 1 / 2$, for which

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{n_{k}: n_{k}}>\sqrt{2 \ln n_{k}}-a_{k} L_{n_{k}}\right)1 / 2$. If $k=k(n)$ is such that $2^{k}1 / 2$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\ln \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{2^{k \cdot 2} \cdot 2^{k}} \leqslant \sqrt{2 k \ln 2}-a L_{2^{k}}\right) & =2^{k} \ln \left\{1-\mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1}>\sqrt{2 k \ln 2}-a L_{2^{k}}\right)\right\} \sim \\
& \sim-\frac{2^{k} \varphi\left(\sqrt{2 k \ln 2}-a L_{2^{k}}\right)}{\sqrt{2 k \ln 2}-a L_{2^{k}}} \sim-k^{a-1 / 2+o(1)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus

$$
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{2^{k} 2^{k}} \leqslant \sqrt{2 k \ln 2}-a L_{2^{k}}\right)<\infty
$$

This proves that

$$
\frac{\lim }{n} \frac{\xi_{n: n}-\sqrt{2 \ln n}}{L_{n}}=\frac{\lim }{k} \frac{\xi_{2^{k}: 2^{k}}-\sqrt{2 k \ln 2}}{L_{2^{k}}} \geqslant-\frac{1}{2}
$$

(a) Show that $\mathrm{E}|X|^{p}<\infty$ for a given $p, 0<p<2$, if and only if

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{1-\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)}{|t|^{1+p}} d t<\infty
$$

and in this case

$$
\mathrm{E}|X|^{p}=C_{p} \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{1-\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)}{|t|^{1+p}} d t,
$$

where

$$
C_{p}=\left[\int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{1-\cos t}{|t|^{1+p}} d t\right]^{-1}=\frac{\Gamma(1+p)}{\pi} \sin \frac{p \pi}{2} .
$$

(b) Establish that if $\mathrm{E}|X|<\infty$, then

$$
\mathrm{E}|X|=-(\mathrm{R}) \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\operatorname{Re} \varphi^{\prime}(t)}{\pi t} d t
$$

where $(\mathrm{R}) \int_{\mathbb{R}}$ is the improper Riemann integral.
original.solution:
Solution. (a) The statement follows from Fubini's theorem and the equality

$$
|x|^{p}=C_{p} \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{1-\cos x t}{|t|^{1+p}} d t, \quad 0<p<2,
$$

valid for the specified $C_{p}$.

(b) First, note that the derivative $[\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)]^{\prime}=\operatorname{Re} \varphi^{\prime}(t)=$ $=\mathrm{E} X \sin t X$ exists by the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem and the fact that $\mathrm{E}|X|<\infty$. Setting $p=1$ in part (a) and noting that Riemann and Lebesgue integrals coincide (when both are defined), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E}|X| & =\int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{1-\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)}{\pi t^{2}} d t=\lim _{a, b, \varepsilon}\left[(\mathrm{R}) \int_{a}^{-\varepsilon}+(\mathrm{R}) \int_{\varepsilon}^{b}\right] \frac{1-\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)}{\pi t^{2}} d t= \\
& =\lim _{a, b, \varepsilon}\left[-\frac{1-\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)}{\pi t}\left[\left.\right|_{a} ^{-\varepsilon}+\left.\right|_{\varepsilon} ^{b}\right]-\left[(\mathrm{R}) \int_{a}^{-\varepsilon}+(\mathrm{R}) \int_{\varepsilon}^{b}\right] \frac{\operatorname{Re} \varphi^{\prime}(t)}{\pi t} d t\right]= \\
& =-\lim _{a, b, \varepsilon}\left[(\mathrm{R}) \int_{a}^{-\varepsilon}+(\mathrm{R}) \int_{\varepsilon}^{b}\right] \frac{\operatorname{Re} \varphi^{\prime}(t)}{\pi t} d t=-(\mathrm{R}) \int_{\mathbb{R}} \frac{\operatorname{Re} \varphi^{\prime}(t)}{\pi t} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

where $a \rightarrow-\infty, b \rightarrow \infty, \varepsilon \rightarrow 0$. Here we also used the fact (see problem II.12.31) that $1-\operatorname{Re} \varphi(t)=o(t)$ as $\mathbf{E}|X| \leqslant \infty$ and $t \rightarrow 0(\Re \varphi(t)$ is the characteristic function of the random variable $\xi X$, where the random variable $\xi$ is independent of $X$ and $\mathrm{P}(\xi= \pm 1)=1 / 2)$.

33. Let $\xi \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$ and

$$
\eta_{\alpha}= \begin{cases}\xi, & \text { if }|\xi| \leqslant \alpha \\ -\xi, & \text { if }|\xi|>\alpha\end{cases}
$$

Show that $\eta_{\alpha} \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$ and for such $\alpha$ that

$$
\int_{0}^{\alpha} x^{2} \varphi(x) d x=\frac{1}{4}, \quad \varphi(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}
$$

the variables $\xi$ and $\eta_{\alpha}$ are uncorrelated but dependent Gaussian variables (cf. Theorem 1(a) from V1.II.13).
original.solution:
Solution. By the definition of $\eta_{\alpha}$, taking into account the equality $\xi \stackrel{d}{=}-\xi$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{P}\left(\eta_{\alpha} \leqslant x\right) & =\mathrm{P}(\xi \leqslant x,|\xi| \leqslant \alpha)+\mathrm{P}(-\xi \leqslant x,|\xi|>\alpha)= \\
& =\mathrm{P}(\xi \leqslant x,|\xi| \leqslant \alpha)+\mathrm{P}(\xi \leqslant x,|\xi|>\alpha)=\mathrm{P}(\xi \leqslant x)
\end{aligned}
$$

so that $\eta_{\alpha} \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$. Moreover,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{cov}\left(\xi, \eta_{\alpha}\right)=\mathrm{E} \xi \eta_{\alpha}=\mathrm{E} \xi^{2} I(|\xi| \leqslant \alpha)-\mathrm{E} \xi^{2} I(|\xi| & >\alpha)= \\
& =2 \mathrm{E} \xi^{2} I(|\xi| \leqslant \alpha)-1=0
\end{aligned}
$$

if

$$
\mathrm{E} \xi^{2} I(|\xi| \leqslant \alpha)=2 \int_{0}^{\alpha} x^{2} \varphi(x) d x=\frac{1}{2}
$$

original.problem: 1. Let $\left(a_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 1}$ be a numerical sequence such that for all $t \in[c, d], c<d$, there exists $\lim _{n} e^{i t a_{n}}$. Show that then there exists a finite limit $\lim _{n} a_{n}=a$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $\left|a_{n_{k}}\right| \rightarrow \infty$ for some $\left(n_{k}\right) \subset(n)$. Then there exists a subsequence $\left(m_{l}\right) \subset\left(n_{k}\right)$ such that $\left|b_{l}\right| \rightarrow \infty$, where $b_{l}=a_{m_{l+1}}-a_{m_{l}}$. According to the condition,

$$
f_{l}(t)=\exp \left(i t b_{l}\right)=\frac{\exp \left(i t a_{m_{l+1}}\right)}{\exp \left(i t a_{m_{l}}\right)} \rightarrow 1, \quad t \in[c, d],
$$

thus,

$$
\int_{c}^{d} f_{l}(t) d t=\frac{e^{i d b_{l}}-e^{i c b_{l}}}{i b_{l}} \rightarrow \int_{c}^{d} d t=d-c>0 .
$$

However, as $\left|b_{l}\right| \rightarrow \infty$, we have

$$
\frac{e^{i d b_{l}}-e^{i c b_{l}}}{i b_{l}} \rightarrow 0
$$

We have reached a contradiction. Therefore, $\overline{\lim }_{n}\left|a_{n}\right|<\infty$. If $a$ and $b$ are limit points of the sequence $\left(a_{n}\right)$, then

$$
e^{i t a}=\lim _{n} e^{i t a_{n}}=e^{i t b}, \quad t \in[c, d],
$$

and necessarily $a=b$. From this, the existence of the limit $\lim _{n} a_{n}$ follows.

Remark. The statement of the problem remains valid if we require that the sequence $e^{i t a_{n}}$ converges on some set $B$ of finite positive Lebesgue measure. The proof remains the same if we note that, by problem II.12.33(a), we have

$$
\int_{B} f_{l}(t) d t \rightarrow 0
$$

and that there always exist points $s, t \in B(t \neq 0)$ with an irrational ratio $s / t$, ensuring the validity of the implication

$$
\left(e^{i s a}=e^{i s b} \text { and } e^{i t a}=e^{i t b}\right) \Rightarrow a=b
$$

23. Establish that the process $\left(B_{t}\right)_{0 \leqslant t \leqslant 1}$, given by the formula

$$
B_{t}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2 \sqrt{2} \xi_{n}}{(2 n-1) \pi} \sin \frac{(2 n-1) \pi t}{2}
$$

with independent random variables $\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$, is a Brownian motion (the given series converges, for example, in $L^{2}$ ).
original.solution:
Solution. This representation can be derived from Mercer's Theorem II.13.19. However, we will obtain it here by modifying the construction described in the remark to Problem II.13.21. Specifically, we have

$$
B_{t}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(e_{n}, J_{t}\right) \zeta_{n}
$$

where $J_{t}=J_{t}(x)(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 1)$ is an odd function defined for $x \geqslant 0$ by the formula

$$
J_{t}=\frac{I_{[(1-t) / 2,(1+t) / 2]}}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

and $e_{1}, e_{2}, e_{3}, e_{4}, \ldots$ are respectively $1 / \sqrt{2}, \sin \pi x, \cos \pi x$, $\sin 2 \pi x, \ldots$ and

$\zeta_{1}, \zeta_{2}, \zeta_{3}, \ldots$ are $\eta_{1},(-1)^{0} \xi_{1}, \eta_{2}, \eta_{3}, \eta_{4},(-1)^{1} \xi_{2}, \eta_{5}, \eta_{6}, \eta_{7},(-1)^{2} \xi_{3}, \ldots ;$ here $\left(\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}, \ldots\right)$ is an independent copy of the set $\left(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots\right)$. With this definition, $\left(J_{s}, J_{t}\right)=s \wedge t$ for all $0 \leqslant s, t \leqslant 1,\left(e_{n}, J_{t}\right)=0$ if $e_{n}$ is not $\sin (2 k-1) \pi x$ for some $k \in \mathbb{N}$, and otherwise

$$
\left(e_{n}, J_{t}\right)=\frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{(2 k-1) \pi} \sin \frac{(2 k-1) \pi t}{2}
$$

64. (See [45].) Let $(\xi, \eta)$ be a two-dimensional Gaussian vector with $\mathrm{E} \xi = \mathrm{E} \eta = 0, \mathrm{D} \xi = \mathrm{D} \eta = 1$ and correlation coefficient $\rho$. Establish the equality

$$
\mathrm{P}(\xi > a, \eta > b) - \mathrm{P}(\xi > a) \mathrm{P}(\eta > b) = \int_{0}^{\rho} \phi(a, b, r) d r
$$

where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}, \phi(a, b, r)$ is the density of the bivariate distribution

$$
\mathscr{N}\left(\binom{0}{0},\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & r \\
r & 1
\end{array}\right)\right)
$$

Using Hoeffding's formula

$\operatorname{cov}(f(\xi), f(\eta)) = \int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}[\mathrm{P}(\xi > a, \eta > b) - \mathrm{P}(\xi > a) \mathrm{P}(\eta > b)] f^{\prime}(a) g^{\prime}(b) d a d b$

and the given equality, establish that

$$
\operatorname{cov}(f(\xi), g(\eta)) = \int_{0}^{\rho} \mathrm{E} f^{\prime}\left(\xi_{r}\right) g^{\prime}\left(\eta_{r}\right) d r
$$

for such smooth functions $f$ and $g$ that $\mathrm{E}|f(\xi) g(\eta)| < \infty$, when $\left(\xi_{r}, \eta_{r}\right)$ is a Gaussian vector with density $\phi(a, b, r)$.
original.solution:
Solution. We will assume that $\rho \geqslant 0$, otherwise we replace $\eta$ with $-\eta$ and use the relation

$$
\operatorname{cov}(I(\xi>a), I(\eta>b))=-\operatorname{cov}(I(\xi>a), I(-\eta>-b))
$$

We will compute $\mathrm{P}(\xi>a, \eta>b)$ using Hermite polynomials. We have

$$
\begin{gathered}
I(\xi>a)=\sum_{n} \mathrm{H}_{n}(\xi) \frac{\mathrm{EH}_{n}(\xi) I(\xi>a)}{n!} \\
\mathrm{EH}_{n}(\xi) I(\xi>a)=(-1)^{n} \int_{a}^{\infty} \varphi^{(n)}(x) d x=(-1)^{n} \Psi^{(n)}(a)
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\Psi(x)=\mathrm{P}(\xi>x), \varphi(x)=-\Psi^{\prime}(x)$, and the summation here and below is over all $n \geqslant 0$. Thus, by problem II.13.62(b), we have

$$
\mathrm{E}[I(\xi>a) \mid \eta]=\sum_{n} \frac{\Psi^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(-1)^{n} \rho^{n} \mathrm{H}_{n}(\eta)
$$

therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{P}(\xi>a, \eta>b)=\mathrm{E} I(\xi>a) I(\eta>b)= \\
& =\mathrm{E} \sum_{n} \frac{\Psi^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(-1)^{n} \rho^{n} \mathrm{H}_{n}(\eta) \sum_{k} \frac{\Psi^{(k)}(b)}{k!}(-1)^{k} \mathrm{H}_{k}(\eta)= \\
& =\sum_{n} \frac{\Psi^{(n)}(a) \Psi^{(n)}(b)}{n!} \rho^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the density of $(\xi, \eta)$ is

$$
\phi(a, b, \rho)=\sum_{n} \frac{\Psi^{(n+1)}(a) \Psi^{(n+1)}(b)}{n!} \rho^{n}
$$

which means,

$$
\mathrm{P}(\xi>a, \eta>b)=\Psi(a) \Psi(b)+\int_{0}^{\rho} \phi(a, b, r) d r
$$

This is the desired equality.

To prove the given inequality, we should use Hoeffding's formula

$$
\begin{array}{r}
\operatorname{cov}(f(\xi), g(\eta))=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}[\mathrm{P}(\xi>a, \eta>b)-\mathrm{P}(\xi>a) \mathrm{P}(\eta>b)] f^{\prime}(a) g^{\prime}(b) d a d b= \\
=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}} d a d b \int_{0}^{\rho} f^{\prime}(a) g^{\prime}(b) \phi(a, b, r) d r=\int_{0}^{\rho} \mathrm{E} f^{\prime}\left(\xi_{r}\right) g^{\prime}\left(\eta_{r}\right) d r . \quad \square
\end{array}
$$

68. Let's call a function $f: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ almost differentiable if for some measurable function $g: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, the following equality holds:

$$
f(b)-f(a)=\int_{0}^{1}(b-a)^{\top} g(a+x(b-a)) d x, \quad a, b \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

In this case, we will write $\nabla f=\left(f_{x_{1}}^{\prime}, \ldots, f_{x_{d}}^{\prime}\right)=g$ for $d>1$ and $f^{\prime}=g$ for $d=1$.

Let $\xi \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$. Prove Stein's lemma [103]:

$$
\mathrm{E}\left|f^{\prime}(\xi)\right|<\infty \Rightarrow \mathrm{E}|\xi f(\xi)|<\infty, \quad \mathrm{E} \xi f(\xi)=\mathrm{E} f^{\prime}(\xi)
$$

for any almost differentiable function $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$.

Let $\eta$ be an arbitrary random vector whose components, together with $\xi$, form a Gaussian system. Generalizing the previous statement, show that

$$
\mathrm{E} \sum_{i=1}^{d}\left|f_{x_{i}}^{\prime}(\eta)\right|<\infty \Rightarrow \mathrm{E}|\xi f(\eta)|<\infty, \quad \mathrm{E} \xi f(\eta)=[\mathrm{E} \nabla f(\eta)]^{\top} \mathrm{E} \xi \eta
$$

for any almost differentiable function $f: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$.
original.solution:
Solution. Let $\varphi=\varphi(x)$ be the density of the random variable $\xi$. Then

$$
\varphi(x)=\int_{x}^{\infty} z \varphi(z) d z=-\int_{-\infty}^{x} z \varphi(z) d z
$$

By Fubini's theorem

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E} f^{\prime}(\xi) & =\int_{\mathbb{R}} f^{\prime}(x) \varphi(x) d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} f^{\prime}(x) d x \int_{x}^{\infty} z \varphi(z) d z-\int_{-\infty}^{0} f^{\prime}(x) d x \int_{-\infty}^{x} z \varphi(z) d z= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} z \varphi(z) d z \int_{0}^{z} f^{\prime}(x) d x-\int_{-\infty}^{0} z \varphi(z) d z \int_{z}^{0} f^{\prime}(x) d x= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} z \varphi(z)[f(z)-f(0)] d z+\int_{-\infty}^{0} z \varphi(z)[f(z)-f(0)] d z= \\
& =\int_{\mathbb{R}} z f(z) \varphi(z) d z=\mathrm{E} \xi f(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\mathrm{E}|\xi f(\xi)|<\infty$, where we also consider that

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty}\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right| d x \int_{x}^{\infty} z \varphi(z) d z+\int_{-\infty}^{0}\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right| d x \int_{-\infty}^{x}|z| \varphi(z) d z=\mathrm{E}\left|f^{\prime}(\xi)\right|<\infty
$$

The second part of the problem is a consequence of the first part, as well as the fact that, by problem II. 13.9, the random variables $\xi$ and $\eta-\xi \cdot \mathrm{E} \xi \eta$ are independent. Indeed, in this case

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{E}\left([\nabla f(\eta)]^{\top} \mid \eta-\xi \cdot \mathrm{E} \xi \eta=z\right) \mathrm{E} \xi \eta= \\
&=[\mathrm{E} \nabla f(z+\xi \cdot \mathrm{E} \xi \eta)]^{\top} \mathrm{E} \xi \eta=\mathrm{E} \xi f(z+\xi \cdot \mathrm{E} \xi \eta)
\end{aligned}
$$

which means,

$$
[\mathrm{E} \nabla f(\eta)]^{\top} \mathrm{E} \xi \eta=\left.\mathrm{E}[\mathrm{E} \xi f(z+\xi \cdot \mathrm{E} \xi \eta)]\right|_{z=\eta-\xi \cdot \mathrm{E} \xi \eta}=\mathrm{E} \xi f(\eta)
$$

75. (See [49].) Let $\left\{X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots\right\}$ be a uniformly integrable family of random variables. Show that (as $n \rightarrow \infty$)

$$
X_{n} \xrightarrow{d} \mathscr{N}(0,1) \Leftrightarrow \mathrm{E}\left[X_{n} e^{i t X_{n}}-i t e^{i t X_{n}}\right] \rightarrow 0 \text { for all } t \in \mathbb{R} .
$$
original.solution:
Solution. The family of random variables $\left\{X_{n}\right\}_{n \geqslant 1}$ is tight, since

$$
\sup _{n} \mathrm{P}\left(\varepsilon\left|X_{n}\right|>1\right) \leqslant \sup _{n} \varepsilon \mathrm{E}\left|X_{n}\right| I\left(\varepsilon\left|X_{n}\right|>1\right) \rightarrow 0, \quad \varepsilon \downarrow 0 .
$$

Therefore, by Prokhorov's theorem, it is relatively compact, i.e., from any sequence $\left(n^{\prime}\right) \subset(n)$ one can extract a subsequence $\left(n^{\prime \prime}\right) \subset\left(n^{\prime}\right)$, for which $X_{n^{\prime \prime}}$ converge in distribution to some random variable $X$ as $n^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow \infty$.

Thus, it suffices to check that any such $X$ is distributed according to the law $\mathscr{N}(0,1)$. We have

$$
\varphi^{\prime}(t)+t \varphi(t)=0, \quad \varphi(0)=1
$$

where $\varphi$ is the characteristic function of the random variable $X$. Indeed, due to the uniform integrability of $X_{n}$, we have

$$
\lim _{n} \mathrm{E}\left[i X_{n} e^{i t X_{n}}+t e^{i t X_{n}}\right]=0=\mathrm{E}\left[i X e^{i t X}+t e^{i t X}\right]=\varphi^{\prime}(t)+t \varphi(t) .
$$

The only solution to the given differential equation is $\varphi(t)=$ $=e^{-t^{2} / 2}$, i.e., $X \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$.

The converse statement is proved similarly.

2. (See [13], [39].) Assuming that $\int_{\mathbb{R}} x p(x) d x=0$ and $\int_{\mathbb{R}} x^{2} p(x) d x = \sigma^{2} > 0$, provide a formal derivation of another widely used expansion - the Edgeworth expansion:

$$
\sigma p(\sigma x)=\varphi(x)+\varphi(x) \sum_{n \geqslant 1} \frac{1}{\sigma^{n}} \sum_{n} \mathrm{H}_{n+2 k}(x) \prod_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{k_{j}!}\left[\frac{s_{j+2} / s_{2}}{(j+2)!}\right]^{k_{j}}
$$

where $\sum_{n}$ is the sum over all integers $k, k_{1}, \ldots, k_{n} \geqslant 0$ with

$$
k_{1}+2 k_{2}+\ldots+n k_{n}=n, \quad k_{1}+\ldots+k_{n}=k
$$

and $\left(s_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 2}$ are the semi-invariants of the distribution $p=p(x)$.

Remark. For the derivation of the last expansion, the formula of the form

$$
\frac{d^{n} \exp f(x)}{d x^{n}}=n!\exp f(x) \sum_{n} \prod_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{k_{j}!}\left[\frac{f^{(j)}(x)}{j!}\right]^{k_{j}}, \quad n \geqslant 1
$$

is useful, which holds for all infinitely differentiable functions $f=f(x)$ (for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$).
original.solution:
Solution. 1. (a) According to problem II.13.62(c), the system $\left(\mathrm{H}_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 1}$ is orthogonal and dense everywhere in the Hilbert space of measurable functions with the scalar product $(f, g)=\mathrm{E} f(\xi) g(\xi)$, where $\xi \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$. Thus, the specified expansion in terms of $\left(\mathrm{H}_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 1}$ (with convergence in this space) will hold if

$$
\mathrm{E}\left[\frac{p(\xi)}{\varphi(\xi)}\right]^{2}=\sqrt{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|p(x)|^{2} e^{x^{2} / 2} d x<\infty
$$

In this case,

$$
a_{n}=\frac{1}{\mathrm{E}\left|\mathrm{H}_{n}(\xi)\right|^{2}} \mathrm{E} \frac{p(\xi) \mathrm{H}_{n}(\xi)}{\varphi(\xi)}=\frac{1}{n!} \int_{\mathbb{R}} p(x) \mathrm{H}_{n}(x) d x, \quad n \geqslant 1
$$

(b) Since by definition

$$
\mathrm{He}_{n}(x)=2^{n / 2} \mathrm{H}_{n}(\sqrt{2} x)
$$

(see also $\$ 3$ in the appendix), the system $\left(\mathrm{He}_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 1}$ is orthogonal and dense everywhere in the Hilbert space of measurable functions with the scalar product $(f, g)=\mathrm{E} f(\xi / \sqrt{2}) g(\xi / \sqrt{2})$, where $\xi \sim \mathscr{N}(0,1)$. Therefore, the expansion in terms of $\left(\mathrm{He}_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 1}$ will hold if

$$
\mathrm{E}\left[\frac{p(\xi / \sqrt{2})}{\varphi(\xi / \sqrt{2})}\right]^{2}=2 \sqrt{\pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}}|p(x)|^{2} d x<\infty
$$

In this case,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{n}=\frac{1}{\mathrm{E}\left|\mathrm{He}_{n}(\xi / \sqrt{2})\right|^{2}} \mathrm{E} \frac{p(\xi / \sqrt{2}) \mathrm{He}_{n}(\xi / \sqrt{2})}{\varphi(\xi / \sqrt{2})}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2^{n-1 / 2} n!} \int_{\mathbb{R}} p(x) \mathrm{He}_{n}(x) e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2}} d x, \quad n \geqslant 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

70. (See [103].) Let the function $f: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow(0, \infty)$ be smooth up to the second order, and for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, the following equality holds:

$$
\nabla^{2} h(x)=\nabla^{\top} \nabla h(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{d} h_{x_{i} x_{i}}^{\prime \prime}(x) \leqslant 0, \quad h=\sqrt{f}
$$

Also,

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\nabla \ln f(\xi)\|^{2}<\infty, \quad \mathrm{E} \frac{1}{f(\xi)} \sum_{i=1}^{d} f_{x_{i} x_{i}}^{\prime \prime}(\xi)<\infty
$$

where $\xi$ is a Gaussian vector in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ with the identity covariance matrix, and

$$
\nabla=\left(\nabla_{1}, \ldots, \nabla_{d}\right), \quad \nabla_{i}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}
$$

Prove that, regardless of $\mathrm{E} \xi$, the following inequality holds:

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2} \leqslant \mathrm{E}\|\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=d
$$

Also derive that for $d \geqslant 3$, the following equalities hold:

$$
\mathrm{E}\left\|\xi+\frac{A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}-\mathrm{E} \xi\right\|^{2}=d-\mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A^{2} \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}}, \quad B=[(\operatorname{tr} A) I-2 A]^{-1} A^{2}
$$

for any symmetric matrix $A$ such that the matrix $(\operatorname{tr} A) I-2 A$ is positive definite.
original.solution:
Solution. We have

$\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=$

$$
=\mathrm{E}\|\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}+2 \mathrm{E}(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} \nabla \ln f(\xi)+\mathrm{E}\|\nabla \ln f(\xi)\|^{2}
$$

and by problem II.13.68 we obtain

$$
\mathrm{E}(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} \nabla \ln f(\xi)=\mathrm{E} \nabla^{2} \ln f(\xi)
$$

Moreover,

$$
\nabla^{2} \ln f=\nabla^{\top} \frac{\nabla f}{f}=\frac{\nabla^{2} f}{f}-\frac{\|\nabla f\|^{2}}{f^{2}}
$$

thus,

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=d+2 \mathrm{E} \frac{\nabla^{2} f(\xi)}{f(\xi)}-\mathrm{E} \frac{\|\nabla f(\xi)\|^{2}}{f(\xi)^{2}}
$$

Noting now that

$$
\nabla^{2} \sqrt{f}=\nabla^{\top} \nabla \sqrt{f}=\frac{1}{2} \nabla^{\top} \frac{\nabla f}{\sqrt{f}}=\frac{\nabla^{2} f}{2 \sqrt{f}}-\frac{\|\nabla f\|^{2}}{4 f^{3 / 2}}
$$

we finally obtain

$$
\mathrm{E}\|\xi+\nabla \ln f(\xi)-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}=d+4 \mathrm{E} \frac{\nabla^{2} \sqrt{f}(\xi)}{\sqrt{f}(\xi)} \leqslant d
$$

Let's move on to the second part of the problem. By problem II.13.69, all the expectations mentioned below exist (for $d \geqslant 3$). We have

$$
\mathrm{E}\left\|\xi+\frac{A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}-\mathrm{E} \xi\right\|^{2}=\mathrm{E}\|\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi\|^{2}+2 \mathrm{E} \frac{(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}+\mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A^{2} \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}} .
$$

By Stein's lemma (see problem II.13.68)

$$
\mathrm{E} \frac{(\xi-\mathrm{E} \xi)^{\top} A \xi}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}=\mathrm{E} \frac{\operatorname{tr} A}{\xi^{\top} B \xi}-2 \mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A B \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}}=-\mathrm{E} \frac{\xi^{\top} A^{2} \xi}{\left(\xi^{\top} B \xi\right)^{2}}
$$

From this, the desired equality follows.

llm_response:
This problem involves proving a specific inequality and deriving additional equalities related to properties of a smooth function \( f \) and its derivatives, with the context of expectations in multivariate statistics. It requires understanding the implications of properties of derivatives and applying tools like Stein's lemma. This does not reduce to merely executing a computation; rather, it needs a careful proof to establish the relationships.

Thus, I classify this problem as:

HARD

The justification is that proving the inequality and deriving the equalities requires handling the properties of the function and its derivatives systematically, which goes beyond straightforward computation.

original.problem: 40. Prove that $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} \frac{x^{n}}{n!}=0$ for any value of $x$. ${ }^{*}$
original.solution:
Solution. No matter what the value of $x$ is, there will always be two consecutive positive integers $k$ and $k+1$ such that $|x|$ is between them, i.e., $k<|x|<k+1$.

From this, we obtain the obvious inequality:

$$
\left|\frac{x^{n}}{n!}\right|=\left|\frac{x^{k}}{k!} \cdot \frac{x}{k+1} \cdot \frac{x}{k+2} \cdot \frac{x}{k+3} \cdots \cdot \frac{x}{n}\right|<\left|\frac{x^{k}}{k!}\right| \cdot\left|\frac{x}{k+1}\right|^{n-k}
$$

The first factor $M_{1}=\left|\frac{x^{k}}{k!}\right|$ does not depend on $n$ and for any given value of $x$ is a constant; the second factor $M_{2}=\left|\frac{x}{k+1}\right|^{n-k}$ as $n \rightarrow+\infty$ will be an infinitely small quantity, since $\left|\frac{x}{k+1}\right|<1$. (See the solution to problem 28.)[^4]

Therefore, $M_{1} \cdot M_{2}$, as the product of a constant and an infinitely small quantity, is an infinitely small quantity.

Consequently, the function $\frac{x^{n}}{n!}$ will also be an infinitely small quantity, i.e., $\lim _{n \rightarrow+\infty} \frac{x^{n}}{n!}=0$ for any value of $x$.

Find the following limits:

llm_response:
This problem involves proving a limit statement which is a common analysis exercise. The proof requires demonstrating that the expression \(\frac{x^{n}}{n!}\) approaches zero as \(n\) approaches infinity for any value of \(x\). 

The solution provided shows several logical steps and inequalities to arrive at the conclusion, which goes beyond simple computation. The nature of the problem is primarily about establishing the truth of a mathematical statement rather than performing straightforward calculations.

This problem fits into the category of needing to show general properties and requires a proving approach, making it inherently a proof-oriented task rather than a simple computation.

Therefore, I classify this as:

**HARD**

original.problem:
29. Prove that:
1) $\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 x+3}{3 x}=\frac{2}{3}$
2) $\lim _{x \rightarrow 3}(2 x+1)=7$
original.solution:
Solution. 1) Let's form the difference $\frac{2 x+3}{3 x}-\frac{2}{3}=\frac{1}{x}$. As $x \rightarrow \infty$, this difference is an infinitesimal quantity, being the reciprocal of an infinitely large quantity. If the variable $\frac{2 x+3}{3 x}$ differs from the constant $\frac{2}{3}$ by an infinitesimal quantity, then the constant is the limit of the variable. Therefore, $\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 x+3}{3 x}=\frac{2}{3}$.

2) Let $x=3+\alpha$ and form the difference: $(2 x+1)-7=$ $=[2(3+\alpha)+1]-7=2 \alpha$. As $x \rightarrow 3$, the variable $\alpha \rightarrow 0$ and the difference between the function $2 x+1$ and the number 7, i.e., $2 \alpha$, will be infinitesimal. From this, it follows that $\lim (2 x+1)=7$.

$$
x \rightarrow 3
$$

llm_response:
The problem consists of proving two limits. The first requires proving a limit at infinity and the second requires proving the limit as \( x \) approaches a particular value.

1) Proving that \( \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{2 x+3}{3 x}=\frac{2}{3} \) requires understanding the concept of limits and justifying that the simplification leads to the limit correctly. 

2) Proving that \( \lim _{x \rightarrow 3}(2 x+1)=7 \) also requires understanding of limits, specifically applying the formal definition.

Both of these involve justifications and reasoning about the behavior of functions rather than direct computation. However, they don't require proving properties in a way that might not translate into a computation, making them more straightforward to verify.

Thus, while they're more involved than a simple derivative, they still employ calculus concepts that will be verifiable through formal proof checking.

Classification: HARD

original.problem:
114. Prove that as $x \rightarrow 0$:
1) $\sin a x \approx a x$; 2) $\tan a x \approx a x$; 3) $\arcsin a x \approx a x$;
2) $\arctan a x \approx a x$
3) $\sqrt{1+x}-1 \approx \frac{1}{2} x$
original.solution:
Solution. To prove the equivalence of two infinitesimals, we need to find the limit of their ratio. If this limit turns out to be equal to one, then the infinitesimals are equivalent.

1) \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin a x}{a x}=\lim _{a x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin a x}{a x}=1\).
2) \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\operatorname{tg} a x}{a x}=\lim \frac{\sin a x}{a x \cos a x}=\lim _{a x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin a x}{a x} \cdot \lim \frac{1}{\cos a x}=1 \cdot 1=1\).
3) Let \(\operatorname{arcšin} a x=\alpha\), then we get:

\[
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\arcsin a x}{a x}=\lim _{a \rightarrow 0} \frac{a}{\sin \alpha}=1
\]

4) Let \(\operatorname{arctg} a x=z\), then we find:

\[
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\operatorname{arctg} \alpha x}{\operatorname{ax}}=\lim _{z \rightarrow 0} \frac{z}{\operatorname{tg} z}=\lim \frac{z}{\sin z} \lim \cos z=1
\]

5) \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+x}-1}{\frac{x}{2}}=2 \lim \frac{1+x-1}{x(\sqrt{1+x}+1)}=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2}=1\).

llm_response:
This problem involves proving approximations of trigonometric and square root functions as \( x \) approaches \( 0 \). The solution requires calculating limits to show that the ratios of the functions in question converge to \( 1 \), establishing their equivalence as \( x \) approaches \( 0 \). 

This characterizes the problem as one that involves proving properties of functions rather than simply executing computations or verifying identities. Hence it requires a significant level of rigor.

Therefore, the classification for this problem is:

HARD: The solution requires proving properties of functions through limits, which involves understanding behavior at infinity and determining equivalence.

original.problem:
120. For each of the following functions, find the points of discontinuity if they exist, find the jump of the function at each point of discontinuity, and plot the graph:
1) $f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}-\frac{1}{2} x^{2} \text { for } x \leqslant 2 \\ x \text { for } x>2\end{array}\right.$
2) $\varphi(x)= \begin{cases}2 \sqrt{x} & \text { for } 0 \leqslant x \leqslant 1 \\ 4-2 x & \text { for } 1<x<2.5 \\ 2 x-7 & \text { for } 2.5 \leqslant x<+\infty \text {; }\end{cases}$
3) $F(x)= \begin{cases}2 x+5 & \text { for }-\infty<x<-1 \\ \frac{1}{x} & \text { for }-1 \leqslant x<+\infty .\end{cases}$
original.solution:
Solution. 1) The function $f(x)$ is defined on the entire number line. However, this does not imply that it is continuous on the entire number line, as this function is non-elementary; it is defined by two different formulas for different intervals of the argument $x$ and may have a discontinuity at the point $x=2$, where its analytical expression changes.

Investigating the point $x=2$, we find the one-sided limits of the function as the argument approaches this point from the left and right:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 2-0} f(x)=\lim \left(-\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\right)=-2
$$

since to the left of the point $x=2$ the function $f(x)=-\frac{1}{2} x^{2}$;

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 2+0} f(x)=\lim x=2
$$

since to the right of the point $x=2$ the function $f(x)=x$.

The left and right limits of the function are finite but not equal to each other. Therefore, due to the failure of the 2nd condition

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-054.jpg?height=344&width=349&top_left_y=1145&top_left_x=104)

Fig. 25 continuity, the function has a discontinuity (finite) at the point $x=2$.

At this point of discontinuity, the function has a finite jump:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 2+0} f(x)-\lim _{x \rightarrow 2-0} f(x)=2-(-2)=4
$$

In all other points on the number line, the function $f(x)$ is continuous, as both formulas by which it is defined represent elementary continuous functions.

The graph of this function is shown in Fig. 25.

2) The non-elementary function $\varphi(x)$ is defined for all values $x \geqslant 0$. It may have discontinuities at the points $x=1$ and $x=2.5$, where its analytical expression changes. In all other points of its domain, the function $\varphi(x)$ is continuous, as each of the formulas by which it is defined represents an elementary function that is continuous in its interval of argument $x$.

Investigate the points $x=1$ and $x=2.5$:
a) $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1-0} \varphi(x)=\lim 2 \sqrt{x}=2 ; \lim _{x \rightarrow 1+0} \varphi(x)=\lim (4-2 x)=2$.

According to the condition, the value of the function $\varphi(x)$ at the point $x=1$ is determined by the first formula

$$
\varphi(1)=2 \sqrt{1}=2
$$

Therefore, at the point $x=1$, all conditions of continuity are satisfied: the function is defined in the neighborhood of the point $x=1$ and

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 1-0} \varphi(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1+0} \varphi(x)=\varphi(1)
$$

Therefore, the function $\varphi(x)$ is continuous at the point $x=1$.

b) $\lim _{x \rightarrow 2.5-0} \varphi(x)=\lim (4-2 x)=-1 ; \lim _{x \rightarrow 2.5+0} \varphi(x)=\lim (2 x-7)=-2$.

Here, the left and right limits of the function are finite but not the same, i.e., the 2nd condition of continuity is not satisfied. Therefore, the function has a discontinuity (finite) at the point $x=2.5$, Fig. 26.

The finite jump of the function at the point of discontinuity is:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 2.5+0} \varphi(x)-\lim _{x \rightarrow 2.5-0} \varphi(x)=-2-(-1)=-1
$$

3) The non-elementary function $F(x)$ is defined on the entire number line except at the point $x=0$. This means that the function is discontinuous at the point $x=0$. Investigate this point:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow-0} F(x)=\lim \frac{1}{x}=-\infty
$$

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow+0} F(x)=\lim \frac{1}{x}=+\infty
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-055.jpg?height=330&width=397&top_left_y=978&top_left_x=790)

Fig. 26

Therefore, the function $F(x)$ has an infinite discontinuity at the point $x=0$.

Further, investigate the point $x=-1$. Since the function $F(x)$ is non-elementary, it may have a discontinuity at this point, where its analytical expression changes:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow-1-0} F(x)=\lim (2 x+5)=3, \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow-1+0} F(x)=\lim \frac{1}{x}=-1
$$

The one-sided limits of the function found are finite but different. Therefore, the function has a finite discontinuity at the point $x=-1$; its finite jump at this point is

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow-1+0} F(x)-\lim _{x \rightarrow-1-0} F(x)=-4
$$

In all other points on the number line, the function $F(x)$ is continuous; its graph is shown in Fig. 27.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-056.jpg?height=341&width=348&top_left_y=244&top_left_x=105)

Fig. 27

llm_response:
This problem involves analyzing the points of discontinuity and the jumps of several piecewise-defined functions. The solution consists of detailed reasoning about the behavior of each function at specified points and proves the existence of discontinuities using limits. Although it requires some computations, it fundamentally involves verifying properties of the functions regarding continuity and discontinuity rather than just executing straightforward derivative computations.

Here's the classification:

**HARD**: The problems involve proving properties of the discontinuities and jumps of the functions using limits, making it more about proving than just computing or classifying.

original.problem: 4. Show that the elementary functions: 1) $y=2 x^{2}-1$; 2) $v=\operatorname{cosec} x$ are continuous throughout their domain of definition.
original.solution:
Solution. We will find the domain of the function and then, based on the definition of continuity, ensure that the function will be continuous in the same domain.

1) The domain of the function \( y \) is the entire number line. Next, we will give the argument \( x \) an arbitrary increment \( \Delta x \) and, substituting into the given expression of the function instead of \( x \) the incremented value \( x + \Delta x \), we will find the incremented value of the function:

\[
y + \Delta y = 2(x + \Delta x)^2 - 1
\]

Subtracting this incremented value of the function from its initial value, we will find the increment of the function:

\[
\Delta y = 2(x + \Delta x)^2 - 1 - (2x^2 - 1) = 4x \Delta x + 2 \Delta x^2
\]

Now let \( \Delta x \rightarrow 0 \). Then \( \lim \Delta y = 0 \) for any value of \( x \). \( \Delta x \rightarrow 0 \)

Therefore, according to the definition of continuity, the function \( y \) will be continuous for any value of \( x \), i.e., throughout its entire domain.

2) The trigonometric function \( \operatorname{cosec} x \) is defined on the entire number line, except for the points \( x = k \pi, k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots \)

Repeating the above reasoning, we will find the increment of the function \( \Delta v \) and then its limit as \( \Delta x \rightarrow 0 \):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta v & = \operatorname{cosec}(x + \Delta x) - \operatorname{cosec} x = \frac{1}{\sin (x + \Delta x)} - \frac{1}{\sin x} = \\
& = \frac{\sin x - \sin (x + \Delta x)}{\sin (x + \Delta x) \sin x} = \frac{2 \cos \left(x + \frac{\Delta x}{2}\right) \sin \left(-\frac{\Delta x}{2}\right)}{\sin (x + \Delta x) \sin x} \\
\lim \Delta v & = \lim \frac{2 \cos \left(x + \frac{\Delta x}{2}\right)}{\sin (x + \Delta x) \sin x} \cdot \lim \sin \left(-\frac{\Delta x}{2}\right) = \frac{2 \cos x}{\sin^2 x} \cdot 0
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\Delta x \rightarrow 0
\]

for all values of \( x \), except \( x = k \pi, k = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots \)

Therefore, the domain of continuity and the domain of definition of the elementary function \( \operatorname{cosec} x \) completely coincide.

llm_response:
This problem involves proving the continuity of two functions across their respective domains. In the case of the polynomial \( y = 2x^2 - 1 \), the proof demonstrates that the function is continuous for all real \( x \). For the cosecant function \( v = \operatorname{cosec} x \), the proof establishes continuity except at points where it is not defined.

The problem requires a demonstration of properties (continuity) rather than merely executing calculations. Although it does involve computation, the main task requires proving a property of the functions and their domains.

Thus, this fits the classification:

**HARD: The solution requires proving some properties of the functions, not just executing computations.**

original.problem:
264. The speed of a body in rectilinear motion is proportional to the square root of the distance traveled (as, for example, 
in free fall). Prove that this motion occurs under the action of a constant force.
original.solution:
Solution. According to Newton's law, the force $F$ causing the motion is proportional to the acceleration

$$
F=k \frac{d^{2} s}{d t^{2}}
$$

According to the condition $\frac{d s}{d t}=\lambda \sqrt{s}$. Differentiating this equality, we find

$$
\frac{d^{2} s}{d t^{2}}=\frac{\lambda}{2 \sqrt{s}} \cdot \frac{d s}{d t}=\frac{\lambda}{2 \sqrt{s}} \cdot \lambda \sqrt{s}=\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2}
$$

Therefore, the acting force $F=\frac{k \lambda^{2}}{2}$ (const).

llm_response:
The problem involves proving that rectilinear motion with speed proportional to the square root of the distance traveled occurs under the action of a constant force. The solution includes a derivation based on Newton's law and involves applying calculus to differentiate and manipulate equations. 

Since this requires demonstrating a property of the motion (i.e., connecting the speed and the resulting force to prove it is constant), it qualifies as a proof problem rather than simply executing a computation.

Thus, the classification for this problem is: 

HARD

This is because it's not merely about performing a calculation, but rather proving a relationship between functions and their properties in the context of motion under a force.

original.problem:
416. Find the equation of the evolute of the curve and plot the curve and its evolute:
1) $x^{2}=2(1-y)$
2) $x=a \cos t, y=b \sin t$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) From the given parabola equation, we find the derivatives: \( y' = -x, y'' = -1 \) and using formulas (2), we find the coordinates of any point on its evolute:

\[
\begin{aligned}
& X = x - \frac{1 + (y')^2}{y''} y' = x - \frac{1 + x^2}{-1}(-x); \\
& Y = y + \frac{1 + (y')^2}{y''} = 1 - \frac{x^2}{2} + \frac{1 + x^2}{-1}; \\
\end{aligned}
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
X = -x^3 \\
Y = -\frac{3}{2} x^2
\end{array}
\right.
\]

These are the parametric equations of the evolute. By eliminating the parameter \( x \) from them, we obtain \( 27 X^2 = -8 Y^3 \) - the equation of a semi-cubic parabola. The given parabola and its found evolute are shown in Fig. 84.

2) From the equations of the ellipse, we find the derivatives \( \dot{x} = -a \sin t \), \( \ddot{x} = -a \cos t \), \( \dot{y} = b \cos t \), \( \ddot{y} = -b \sin t \) and using formulas (2), we obtain, after simplifications, the parametric equations of the evolute of the ellipse

\[
X = -\frac{c^2}{a} \cos^3 t, \quad Y = -\frac{c^2}{b} \sin^3 t, \quad \text{where } c^2 = a^2 - b^2
\]

The ellipse and its evolute are shown in Fig. 85.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-153.jpg?height=281&width=287&top_left_y=378&top_left_x=240)

Fig. 84

Fig. 85

original.problem:
458. Find the integrals:
1) $\int \frac{2 x d x}{x^{4}+3}$
2) $\int \frac{\sin x d x}{\sqrt{1+2 \cos x}}$
3) $\int \frac{x d x}{\sqrt[3]{x^{2}+a}}$;
4) $\int \frac{\sqrt{1+\ln x}}{x} d x$
5) $\int \frac{d y}{\sqrt{e^{y}+1}}$
6) $\int \frac{d t}{\sqrt{\left(1-t^{2}\right)^{3}}}$.
original.solution:
Solution. 1) Let $x^{2}=t$; differentiate $2 x d x=d t$, substitute into the integrand, find the new integral, and return to the original variable $x$:

$$
\int \frac{2 x d x}{x^{4}+3}=\int \frac{d t}{t^{2}+3}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \operatorname{arctg} \frac{t}{\sqrt{3}}+C=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \operatorname{arctg} \frac{x^{2}}{\sqrt{3}}+C
$$

2) Let $1+2 \cos x=t$. Then $-2 \sin x d x=d t$ and

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int \frac{\sin x d x}{\sqrt{1+2 \cos x}}=-\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{d t}{\sqrt{t}}=-\frac{1}{2} \int t^{-\frac{1}{2}} d t=-\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 t^{\frac{1}{2}}+C= \\
=C-\sqrt{t}=C-\sqrt{1+2 \cos x}
\end{gathered}
$$

3) Taking the substitution $x^{2}+a=z$, we have $2 x d x=d z$ and

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int \frac{x d x}{\sqrt[3]{x^{2}+a}}=\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{d z}{\sqrt[3]{z}}=\frac{1}{2} \int z^{-\frac{1}{3}} d z=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{3}{2} z^{\frac{2}{3}}+C= \\
=\frac{3}{4} \sqrt[3]{\left(x^{2}+a\right)^{2}}+C
\end{gathered}
$$

4) The substitution $1+\ln x=v$ gives $\frac{d x}{x}=d v$ and

$$
\int \frac{\sqrt{1+\ln x}}{x} d x=\int \sqrt[v]{v} d v=\frac{2}{3} v^{\frac{3}{2}}+C=\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{(1+\ln x)^{3}}+C
$$

5) Taking the substitution $e^{y}+1=t^{2}$, differentiate $e^{y} d y=2 t d t$, determine $d y=\frac{2 t d t}{e^{y}}=\frac{2 t d t}{t^{2}-1}$, substitute into the integrand, integrate, and return to the variable $y$:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\int \frac{d y}{\sqrt{e^{y}+1}}=\int \frac{2 t d t}{t\left(t^{2}-1\right)}=2 \int \frac{d t}{t^{2}-1}=2 \cdot \frac{1}{2} \ln \frac{t-1}{t+1}+C= \\
=\ln \frac{\sqrt{e^{y}+1}-1}{\sqrt{e^{y}+1}+1}+C
\end{gathered}
$$

6) Let $t=\sin \varphi$, then $d t=\cos \varphi d \varphi$,

$$
\int \frac{d t}{\sqrt{\left(1-t^{2}\right)^{3}}}=\int \frac{d \varphi}{\cos ^{2} \varphi}=\operatorname{tg} \varphi+C=\frac{\sin \varphi}{\cos \varphi}+C=\frac{t}{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}+C
$$

Find the following integrals and verify the results by differentiation:

llm_response:
The problem involves solving multiple integral problems, which requires understanding the appropriate substitution techniques for each integral. The solutions given involve computation and the verification of the results through differentiation.

1) **Classification:** HARD  
   **Justification:** Each integral is not merely a straightforward computation; the solution relies on valid substitution techniques and then verifying the results through differentiation. These properties must be proved, thus the problem goes beyond simple execution of derivatives or integrals.

2) **Classification:** HARD  
   **Justification:** Similar to the first classification, the process involves substantiating the integral transformations and confirming correctness via differentiation, requiring establishing that the given methods lead to correct outcomes.

3) **Classification:** HARD  
   **Justification:** The computations involve integration techniques that have to be shown to hold true upon differentiation, indicating that it is not a straightforward computation.

4) **Classification:** HARD  
   **Justification:** Again, as with the others, this requires validating the method of integration employed and asserting the solution via differentiation, which cannot be done from mere execution without establishing the proof basis.

5) **Classification:** HARD  
   **Justification:** It requires integration strategies that must be backed by differentiation, confirming correctness through established integral properties.

6) **Classification:** HARD  
   **Justification:** The same rationale applies, as it requires using trig substitution and verifying through differentiation, marking it as a problem involving proof-like qualities rather than simple execution.

Overall, the essence of these problems is the combination of integrative techniques followed by verification, which elevates each to a 'HARD' classification due to the necessary proof-like feature involved in the solution verification.

original.solution:
Solution. 1) First, we determine the region of integration from the limits of integration. By setting $x$ equal to the limits of integration with the variable $x$, and $y$ equal to the limits of integration with the variable $y$, we obtain the equations of the lines bounding this region: $x=-2, x=2, y=x^{2}, y=4$.

Here, in the calculation of the double integral over the region \( O A B C D \), it was necessary to split it by the line \( B E \), parallel to the \( O x \) axis, into two parts.

2) The body bounded by the sphere \( x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}=2 z \) [with the center at the point \( (0 ; 0 ; 1) \)] and the cone \( x^{2}+y^{2}=z^{2} \) is shown in Fig. 180. Its volume is

\[
V=\iiint_{G} d x d y d z=\iint_{G_{x y}} d x d y \int_{i=z_{k}}^{z=z_{c}} d z=\iint_{G_{x y}}\left(z_{c}-z_{k}\right) d x d y
\]

where \( G \) is the region occupied by the given body; \( G_{x y} \) is its projection onto the \( x O y \) plane; \( z_{k} \) is the positive value of \( z \) from the equation of the cone, \( z_{k}=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \); \( z_{c} \) is the larger value of \( z \) from the equation of the sphere, \( z_{c}=1+\sqrt{1-x^{2}-y^{2}} \). The line bounding the planar region \( G_{x y} \) is the circle \( x^{2}+y^{2}=1 \); its equation is obtained by eliminating \( z \) from the given equations of the sphere and the cone.

Switching to polar coordinates, we find:

\[
\begin{gathered}
V=\iint_{x^{2}+y^{2} \leqslant 1}\left(z_{c}-z_{k}\right) d x d y=\iint_{k \leqslant 1}\left(1+\sqrt{1-\rho^{2}}-\rho\right) \rho d \varphi d \rho= \\
=\int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi \int_{0}^{1}\left(\rho-\rho^{2}+\rho \sqrt{1-\rho^{2}}\right) d \rho=\left.\int_{0}^{2 \cdot 1}\left[\frac{\rho^{2}}{2}-\frac{\rho^{3}}{3}-\frac{\left(1-\rho^{2}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}{3}\right]\right|_{0} ^{1} d \varphi=\pi
\end{gathered}
\]

3) The paraboloid of revolution \( 2 z=x^{2}+y^{2} \) and the plane \( y+z=4 \) (parallel to the \( O x \) axis) bound a body, as shown in Fig. 181.

By formula (1), the volume of this body is

\[
V=\iiint_{G} d x d y d z=\int_{G_{x y}} \int_{z_{1}} d x d y \int_{z_{1}}^{z_{2}} d z=\iint_{G_{x y}}\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) d x d y
\]

where \( G \) is the region occupied by the body; \( G_{x y} \) is the circle \( x^{2}+(y+1)^{2} \leq 9 \); \( z_{1}=\frac{1}{2}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right) \); \( z_{2}=4-y \).

To simplify the calculation of the double integral, we shift the origin of coordinates to the center of the specified circle - the point \( (0 ;-1) \), and then switch to polar coordinates. In this case, the variables \( x \) and \( y \) are replaced by the formulas \( x=\rho \cos \varphi, y=-1+\rho \sin \varphi \), the product \( d x d y \) is replaced by the product \( \rho d \varphi d \rho \), and the double integral is transformed into a simpler form:

\[
\begin{gathered}
V=\frac{1}{2} \iint_{\rho \leqslant 3}\left(9-\rho^{2}\right) \rho d \varphi d \rho=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi \int_{0}^{3}\left(9 \rho-\rho^{3}\right) d \rho= \\
\quad=\left.\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left(\frac{9 \rho^{2}}{2}-\frac{\rho^{4}}{4}\right)\right|_{0} ^{3} d \varphi=\frac{81}{8} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} d \varphi=\frac{81}{4} \pi
\end{gathered}
\]

( \(\rho=3\) is the polar equation of the circle \( x^{2}+(y+1)^{2}=9 \)).

It intercepts segments on the coordinate axes $a = 3 x_{0}, b = 3 y_{1}, c = 3 z_{0}$. These segments are mutually perpendicular edges of the tetrahedron formed by the tangent plane and the coordinate planes. Taking one of these edges as the height of the tetrahedron, we find that its volume $V = \frac{1}{6} a b c = \frac{9}{2} x_{0} y_{t} z_{0} = \frac{9}{2} m^{3}$ (since the point $P$ lies on the given surface) does not depend on the coordinates of the point of tangency $P$. From this, it follows that different tangent planes to the given surface form a tetrahedron of constant (the same) volume with the coordinate planes.

original.problem: 936. What is the greatest rate at which the function $u(M)=\frac{10}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+1}$ can increase as the point $M(x, y, z)$ passes through the point $M_{0}(-1 ; 2 ;-2)$? In what direction should the point $M$ move as it passes through the point $M_{1}(2 ; 0 ; 1)$, so that the function $u(M)$ decreases at the greatest rate?
original.solution:
Solution. The greatest in absolute value the rate of change (increase or decrease) of the function and (M) when the point $M$ passes through the point $P$ numerically equals the modulus of the gradient of the function at point $P$. In this case, the function will increase or decrease at the greatest rate, depending on whether the point $M$ when passing through point $P$ moves in the direction of the gradient of the function at point $P$ or in the directly opposite direction.

Guided by these principles, we find the partial derivatives of the function and and by formula (b) - its gradient at any point:

$$
\operatorname{grad} u=-\frac{20}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+\tilde{z}^{2}+1\right)^{2}}(x \ddot{i}+y \ddot{j}+z k)
$$

Next, we find: 1) $\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{6}\right)=\frac{1}{5}(\bar{i}-2 j+2 \bar{k})$; its modulus, numerically equal to the desired greatest rate of increase of the function $u(M)$ when $M$ passes through $M_{0}$, will be $\left|\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{0}\right)\right|==$ $=\sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^{2}+\left(-\frac{2}{5}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{2}{5}\right)^{2}}=\frac{3}{5}$.
2) $\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{1}\right)=-\frac{10}{9} i-\frac{5}{9} k ;$ the desired vector, having the directly opposite direction, will be $-\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{1}\right)=\frac{10}{9} \ddot{i}+\frac{5}{9} k$. For the function $u(M)$ to decrease at the greatest rate when passing through the point $M_{1}$, the point $M$ must move in the direction of the vector $-\operatorname{grad} u\left(M_{1}\right)$.

The solution includes the computation of partial derivatives, gradient, and modulus, which can be verified formally.
